item.title: Radicals
item.description:
Ring Radicals

We clarify some concepts about general theory of ring radicals.

Jacobson Radical

We show differences of semisimple rings and ring with $0$ Jacobson radical.

The Definitions

(Jacobson Radical). The Jacobson radical element $x âˆˆ R$ admits the following equivalent characterisations.

  1. $Sx = 0$ for any simple right $R$-module $S$;
  2. $x âˆˆ ğ”ª$ for any maximal right ideal $ğ”ª$;
  3. $1 - xr$ has a right inverse for all $r âˆˆ R$;
  4. $1 - sxr$ is a unit for all $r,s âˆˆ R$.

(1 â†’ 2). Note that $\mathrm{ann}(R/ğ”ª) âŠ† ğ”ª$ for every maximal ideal. If $x$ annihilators each simple modules, then it lies in any maximal ideal.
(2 â†’ 3). We show (2 âˆ§ Â¬ 3 â†’ False). If $1 - xr$ has no right inverse, then $1 - xr$ belongs to some maximal right ideal $ğ”ª$, and so is $rx$. Hence $1 âˆˆ ğ”ª$, a contradiction.
(3 â†’ 1). We show (3 âˆ§ Â¬ 1 â†’ False). When there is some simple module $S = (s_0)$ s.t. $Sx â‰  0$. Then $(s_0x) = (s_0)$. We take $r$ s.t. $s_0xr = s_0$. Now $s_0 (1-xr) = 0$, a contradiction.
(4 â†’ 3). Take $s = 1$.
(1 âˆ§ 2 âˆ§ 3 â†’ 4). Since $sx$ annihilates all simple modules, $1 - (sx)r$ has right inverse $t$. Now $t = 1 + sxrt$ has a right inverse. Since $t$ has bi-inverses, it is a unit.

The annihilator of a simple module is called primitive ideal.

  1. Primitive ideals are two-sided;
  2. Every maximal ideal contains some primitive ideal;
  3. The matrix ring $M_2 (â„‚)$ has non-trivial right maximal ideals, by only trivial primitive ideals.

For commutative rings, simple modules are precisely the residue fields of maximal ideals.

Note that the final definition is symmetric, hence

$J(R)$ is an intersection of two-sided ideals, thus it is two-sided.

$J(M_n (R)) = M_n (J(R))$ for any matrix ring.

On one hand, for any $X âˆˆ M_n (J(R))$, $(I - XA)$ has a right inverse $(\det (I - XA))^{-1} â‹… \mathrm{adj}(I - XA)$. Here $\det (I - XA) âˆˆ 1 + J(R)$ is a unit in $R$. On the other hand, $J(M_n (R))$ is a two-sided ideal of a full matrix ring, thus (consider entry $(1,1)$) it takes the form $M_n (I)$ for some two-sided ideal $I âŠ† R$. Taking diagonal matrices, we see $I âŠ† J(R)$, thus $I = J(R)$.

Corollary, the property $J(R) = 0$ is Morita invariant.

Let $U$ be the ring of upper triangular matrices over a field $k$. Then $J(U)$ consists of $0$-diagonal matrices. This indicates that the shift of $J(R)$ are units.

$J(R)$ is the maixmal left/right/two-sided ideal $I$ s.t. $1 + I âŠ† \text{Units}$.

(Left case). By analysis of units, $1 + J(R) âŠ† \text{Units}$. If $I$ is a left ideal s.t. $1 + I âŠ† \text{Units}$, then for any $x âˆˆ I$, $1 - x$ has a right inverse. Hence $I âŠ† J(R)$. Note $J(R)$ is the maximal left ideal with the property $1 + J(R) âŠ† \text{Units}$.
The right case is similar. The two-sided case follows since $J(R)$ is a two-sided ideal.

If $\text{Units} âˆª \{0\}$ is a (division) ring, then $J(R) = 0$. For instance, $D[S]$ (polynomial) and $DâŸ¨SâŸ©$ (free algebra) over division ring $D$ has $0$ radical.

$R$ and $R / J(R)$ has (up to a categorical equivalence) the same semi-simple modules. The finite-length modules may differs (e.g. for those $R / J(R)$ is a field).

Nakayama Lemma

We highlight this short-but-useful lemma. Recall the existence of maximal ideals.

F.g. modules has maximal submodules.

We show for cyclic modules $(x) â‰ƒ R / I$. Note that the submodules corresponds to ideals containing $I$. Zornâ€™s lemma complete the proof. Assume we show every $k$-generated module has maximal submodules. For every $k+1$-generated module $âŸ¨x_1, \ldots ,x_{k+1}âŸ©$, there exists a maximal submodule of $\frac{âŸ¨x_1, \ldots ,x_{k+1}âŸ©}{âŸ¨x_1, \ldots ,x_{k}âŸ©} â‰ƒ \text{some cyclic module}$. This is recovers maximal submodules of $âŸ¨x_1, \ldots ,x_{k+1}âŸ©$ containing $âŸ¨x_1, \ldots ,x_{k}âŸ©$. Induction completes the proof.

We show two variant forms of Nakayama lemma.

Let $J âŠ† J(R)$ be an ideal of $R$, and $N, L âŠ† M$ be submodule s.t. $M / N$ is f.g.. If $N + LJ(R) = M$, then $N = M$.

Let $K = \frac{M}{N}$ be f.g.. It suffices to show $(KJ(R) = K) â†’ (K = 0)$. Let $K'$ be any maximal submodule of $K$, then $(K/K')(R) = 0$, i.e., $KJ(R) âŠ† K'$. A contradiciton.

Let $I$ be a nilpotent ideal of $R$, and $N, L âŠ† M$ be any submodule. If $N + LI = M$, then $N = M$.

We take $K = \frac{M}{N}$. It suffices to show $(KI = K) â†’ (K = 0)$. Now $K = KI^{n} = K0$ for some $n$.

(Easy form). If $MI = M$ with either $I$ nilpotent or $(I âŠ† J(R)) âˆ§ (M \ \text{f.g.})$, then $M = 0$.

Remember the twin conditions for Nakayama lemma:

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{either nilpotent ideal, or f.g. module with ideal in Jacobson radical}} \end{equation}$$

(The origin form). Let $M$ be a f.g. module and $I$ be any ideal s.t. $MI = M$. Then there is $x âˆˆ I$ s.t. $M(x-1) = 0$.

Let $ğ¦$ be the row vector of generating elements of $M$. There is $I$-square matrix $ğ€$ s.t. $ğ¦ğ€ = ğ¦$. By characteristic polynomial, $(ğˆ - ğ€) â‹… \mathrm{adj}(ğˆ - ğ€) = \det (ğˆ - ğ€) â‹… \mathrm{id}$. Note that $\det (ğˆ - ğ€) = 1 - x$ for some $x âˆˆ I$. We see $(1 - x)$ annihilates the generating set of $M$, thus $M(1-x) = 0$.

We proof original lemma with Jacobson radical under good conditions.

We assume $I$ satisfies the Ore condition, i.e., for any $a âˆˆ I$ and $r âˆˆ R$, there is $a', a'' âˆˆ I$ s.t. $ra' = ar$ and $a''r = ra$. Then $S := (1 + I)$ is multiplicative, and $S^{-1} R$ is a filtered colimit of $R$â€™s. Hence, morphism $I âŠ— S^{-1}R â†’ S^{-1}R$ is an inclusion, where the image takes the form $a(1+a')^{-1}$ for some $a,a' âˆˆ I$. For any $Î¸ âˆˆ S^{-1} R$, Oreâ€™s condition shows

$$\begin{equation} a(1+a')^{-1} Î¸ + 1 = a'' (1 + a''')^{-1} + 1 = (1 + a'' + a''') (1 + a''')^{-1} âˆˆ \text{Units}. \end{equation}$$

Hence $I (S^{-1} R) âŠ† J(S^{-1} R)$. We obtain

$$\begin{equation} M âŠ— S^{-1} R = (M I) âŠ— S^{-1} R âŠ† (M âŠ— S^{-1} R) âŠ— (I S^{-1} R). \end{equation}$$

By elementwise verification, the inclusion is identical. By Nakayama lemma (radical form), $M âŠ— S^{-1} R = 0$. Since $M$ is f.g., there is $s âˆˆ S$ s.t. $Ms = 0$.

Small (Superfluous) Submodules

A small submodule $L â†ª M$ is a proper submodule s.t. $L + N = M$ implies $N = M$.

For chain inclusions $K âŠ† L âŠ† M$, the small subobject satisfies the usual properties of inclusions:

  1. If $L â†ª M$ is small, then $K â†ª M$ and $\frac{L}{K} â†ª \frac{M}{K}$ are small;
  2. If $K â†ª L$ and $\frac{L}{K} â†ª \frac{M}{L}$ are small, then $K â†ª M$ is small;
  3. The small inclusion is closed under transfinite compositions.

(1). Clear.
(2). For $K + X = M$, we have $K + (X âˆ© L) = L$, thus $X âˆ© L = L$. We obtain $L + X = M$. Taking $\frac{L}{K} + \frac{X}{K} = \frac{M}{K}$, we see $\frac{X}{K} = \frac{M}{K}$. Hence $\frac{M}{X} = 0$.
(3). We show $X_0 âŠ† â‹ƒ _{Î² < Î±} X_Î²$ is small for any ordinal $Î±$. If $X_0 + Y = X_Î±$, then $X_0 + (Y âˆ© X_Î²) = X_Î²$ for any $Î² < Î±$. By assumption, $(Y âˆ© X_Î²) = X_Î²$. AB5 condition shows $Y = X_Î±$.

The system of supersluous submodules is closed under finite sums and arbitrary submodules. Corollary, a f.g. submodule of arbitrary sum of supersluous submodules is superfluous.

The definition is highly connected to Nakayama lemma.

$MI âŠ† M \ (â‰  0)$ is small if either one of the following conditions holds:

  1. $M$ is f.g. and $I âŠ† J(R)$;
  2. $I$ is nilpotent.

Corollaries of Nakayama lemma.

An characterisation of lifting worth mentioning.

Let $f : L â†’ M$ be a morphism of modules, and $I$ be an ideal. Assume either one of the following conditions holds:

  1. $M$ is f.g. and $I âŠ† J(R)$;
  2. $I$ is nilpotent.

Then $(\widetilde f : L/LI â†  M/MI) â†” (f : L â†  M)$.

When $\widetilde f$ is surjective, we have $\mathrm{im}(f) + MI = M$. Nakayama lemma shows $\mathrm{im}(f) = M$. Hence $f$ is surjective. The other direction is given by universal property of cokernel.

Not all $M â‹… J(R)$ is small in $M$. Let $R = k[x] / (x^2)$ be an $2$-dimensional algebra over a field $k$. We take $M = R^{(Ï‰)}$ as the countable coproduct ring. Clearly $J(R) = (x)$. We take

$$\begin{equation} L = \mathrm{span}(e_k - (x) â‹… e_{k+1})_{k âˆˆ â„•}. \end{equation}$$

$L âŠ† M$ is proper submodule, whereas $L + MJ(R) = M$.

Radical of Modules

We show an observation of rings.

Every proper right ideal $I âŠ† R$ satisfies $I + J(R) â‰  R$.

$I âŠ† ğ”ª$ for some maximal right ideal $ğ”ª$, and $J(R) âŠ† ğ”ª$.

Corollary, $J(R)$ is the greatest superfluous submodule of $R$.

(Radical of a Module). The radical of a module $M$ admits the following equivalent definitions:

  1. the intersection of all maximal submodules of $M$;
  2. the sum of all superfluous submodules of $M$.

Note that $â‹‚_âˆ…$ is the entire set.

Note that superfluous submodules are closed under finite sum and submodules. Hence

$$\begin{equation} x âˆˆ âˆ‘ \ \text{superfluous submodules} \quad â†” \quad (x)\ \text{is superfluous}. \end{equation}$$

If $(x)$ is superfluous, then any maximal submodule (if exists) contains $x$. Conversely, if $x$ belongs to all maximal submodules, then for any identity $(x) + N = M$, one has either $N = M$, or $M / N$ is a quotient ring. For the latter case, $N$ belongs to some maximal submodule, a contradiction.

Clearly $MJ(R) âŠ† J(M)$. The converse doesnot holds true, i.e., $J(â„š) = â„š$ but $â„š J(â„¤) = 0$.

If $R / J(R)$ is semisimple, then $J(M) = MJ(R)$.

Since $\frac{M}{MJ(R)}$ is a module over semisimple ring, we have $J(\frac{M}{MJ(R)}) = 0$. In this case, superfluous submodules of $M$ are precisely those contained in $MJ(R)$. Hence $J(M) = M J(R)$.

If $R / J(R)$ is commutative, then all $Mğ”ª$ are vector spaces over $R / ğ”ª$, hence semi-simple.

  • Fact: for $N âŠ† M$ s.t. $\frac{M}{N}$ semisimple, $N$ is a intersection of maximal submodules. Proof: take $\frac{M}{N} = âˆ _{i âˆˆ I}S_i$ as a coproduct of simple modules. Then $N = â‹‚ \ker [M â†  S_i]$ is a intersection of maximal submodules.

Now $J(M) = â‹‚ _{\text{maximal}} M' âŠ† â‹‚ _{ğ”ª} (Mğ”ª)$. Hence $J(M) = â‹‚ _{ğ”ª} (Mğ”ª)$.

We show some functorial property of $J : ğŒğ¨ğ _R â†’ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$.

$J$ is a subfunctor of identity. Moreover, $J$ satisfies the following properties:

  1. $J(f) := f|_{J(M)} : J(M) â†’ J(N)$ by functoriality;
  2. if $f : M â†  N$ has superfluous kernel, then $J(f) : J(M) â†  J(N)$ and $\frac{M}{J(M)} â‰ƒ \frac{N}{J(N)}$ by cokernel;
  3. the quotient functor $1/J$ preserves and reflects the epimorphisms;
  4. $J(M / J(M)) = 0$;
  5. $J$ preserves arbitrary coproducts;
  6. $\ker J$ consists of $M$ s.t. $M âŠ† âˆ_i S_i$ ($S_i$â€™s are simple modules) and $(p_i)|_M â†  S_i$ for each $i$.

(1). Recall that $J(M)$ is the intersection of morphism of the type $Ï† : M â†’ S$ ($S$ is simple). We show $f(J(M)) âŠ† J(N)$.
(2). Is $f$ is an epimorphism with superfluous kernel, then $f$ and $f^{-1}$ shows a $1:1$ correspondence of maximal submodules of $M$ and $N$. The rest is clear. We show such corrrespondence:

  • If $Y âŠ† N$ is maximal, then $f^{-1}(Y) âŠ† M$ is proper. Assume $f^{-1}(Y)$ is not maximal, then there is $x âˆ‰ f^{-1}(Y)$ s.t. $(x) + f^{-1}(Y)$ is proper. Since $Y$ is maximal, $f^{-1}f((x) + f^{-1}(Y)) = f^{-1}(N) = M$. Note that $f^{-1}f((x) + f^{-1}(Y)) = (x) + f^{-1}(Y) + \ker f â‰  M$, a contradiction.
  • If $X âŠ† M$ is maximal, then $f(X)$ is proper as $\ker f âŠ† X$. Assume $f(X)$ is not maximal, then there is $y âˆ‰ f(X)$ s.t. $(y) + f(X)$ is proper. We take $x âˆˆ f^{-1}(y)$. Note that $x âˆ‰ X$ and $(x) + X$ is proper, a contradiction.

(3). When there is $f : M â†  N$, we see $\frac{M}{J(M)} â†  \frac{N}{J(N)}$ by cokernel. Conversely, if $\frac{M}{J(M)} â†  \frac{N}{J(N)}$, then $f(M) + J(N) = N$. Since $J(N) âŠ† J$ is superfluous, we obtain $f(M) = N$.
(4). If $\frac{M}{J(M)}$ has a superfluous submodule $\frac{X}{J(M)}$, then $X âŠ† M$ is superfluous. We must have $X = J(M)$.
(5). $J(X_âˆ™ ) âŠ† J(âˆ (X_âˆ™ ))$ shows $âˆ J(X_âˆ™ ) âŠ† J(âˆ X_âˆ™ )$. Conversely, for any maximal submodule $X_i' âŠ† X_i$, $X_i' âŠ• âˆ _{â‰  i}X_âˆ™$ is a maximal submodule of $âˆ X_âˆ™$. Hence $âˆ J(X_âˆ™ )$ is an intersection of some maximal submodules of $âˆ X_âˆ™$. We obtain $J(âˆ X_âˆ™ ) âŠ† âˆ J(X_âˆ™ )$.
(6). By previous analysis, $J(M) = 0$ if $M$ is a submodule of a product of simple modules. Conversely, if $J(M) = 0$, then any non-zero element $x âˆˆ M$ survives in some $M â†’ S$. Let $S$ be the product of all simple modules, then there is monomorphism

$$\begin{equation} Ï† âˆˆ (M, âˆ _{(M,S)} S) â‰ƒ âˆ_{(M,S)}(M,S) âˆ‹ 1_{(M,S)}. \end{equation}$$

By analysis on summands and $âˆ$, one has $J(P) = PJ(R)$ for $P$ projective.

In general, $J (âˆ M_âˆ™ ) âŠ† âˆ J(M_âˆ™ )$. The equality may fails.

Recall that

$$\begin{equation} J (âˆ M_âˆ™ ) = â‹‚ \text{some maximal submod} âŠ† â‹‚ \text{all maximal submod} = âˆ J(M_âˆ™ ). \end{equation}$$

A non-exmaple takes over $R := k[x_1, x_2, \ldots ]$. The radical is the unique maximal ideal $ğ”ª$. Note that

$$\begin{equation} (x_i)_{i âˆˆ â„•} âˆˆ âˆ_â„• J(R) âŠ‡ J(âˆ_â„• R) = ğ”ª âˆ_â„• R. \end{equation}$$

The equality fails.

In general, $J$ fails to be neither left nor right exact. It fails to preserves filtered colimits neither.

Note that for $Î¸ : â„¤ â†ª â„š â†  â„š / â„¤$, ses in $ğ€ğ›$, $J(Î¸)$ fails to be exact at $â„š$. Consider $â„š = \varinjlim ^{fil}_{\text{congruence}}â„¤$, the equality fails when taking $J(-)$ on both sides.

Jacobson Radical v.s. Nilpotents

(On descending chain). Let $R = \mathrm{End}(â„^{(Ï‰)})$, then $J(R)$ consisting of finite rank operators is a unique two-sided ideal. Note that $J(R)^2 = J(R) â‰  0$.

Artinian rings have nilpotent Jacobson radical.

Let $R$ be Artinian. There is a descending chain $J(R) âŠ‡ J(R)^2 âŠ‡ \cdots$ which stabilises at some $n$. We show $J^n(R) = 0$. By Artinian, there is some minimal non-zero ideal $I$ s.t. $J^n(R) â‹… I â‰  0$. Clearly, $J^n (R) â‹… I = I$ and $I = (x)$ is principal. We take $r âˆˆ J^n (R)$ s.t. $rx = x$. Since $(1-r) x = 0$, we see $x = 0$, a contradiction!

Corollary, $J(R)$ consisting of nilpotent elements for any Artinian ring $R$.

Clearly, any nilpotent element belongs to Jacobson radical.

The Jacobson radical may contains no nilpotent elements. For instance, note that the units in formal power series ring $R[[x]]$ are precisely those with unital constant terms. Hence $J(R[[x]]) = (x) + J(R)$.

In the rest of the subsection, we assume $R$ is an algebra over the field $k$.

The following lemma characterises nilpotent elements in $J(R)$.

For $x âˆˆ J(R)$, $x$ is nilpotent iff $x$ is algebraic over $k$, i.e., there is some $p(t) âˆˆ k[t] âˆ– \{0\}$ s.t. $p(x) = 0$.

A nilpotent element is annihilated by some polynomial $t^n$. Conversely, we take monic polymonial $p$ s.t. $p(x) = 0$ and assume $p$ is not monic. Assume the least term in $p(x)$ has degree $k$, then $(x^k) â‹… (x) = (x^k)$. By Nakayama lemma, $x^k = 0$.

The following theorem is due to Amitsur.

If $\dim R < |k|$. Then $J(R)$ consists of nilpotent elements.

We show any $x âˆˆ J(R)$ is nilpotent (= algebraic). Note that the collection $\{(Î» - x)^{-1} : Î» âˆˆ (k âˆ– \{0\})\}$ is linearly dependent, as $\dim R < |k|$. Clearing the denominators in a vanishing linear combination, we see $x$ is algebraic.

Propositions

We show some computations.

For $I âŠ† J(R)$, we have $J(R/I) = J(R) / I$.

$J(R / I)$ is the intersection of all maximal ideals of $R / I$. Since $I$ is contained in all maximal ideals of $R$, the maximal ideals of $R / I$ are in $1:1$ correspondence with those of $R$ containing $I$. Hence

$$\begin{equation} J(R / I) = \bigcap _{ğ”ª âŠ‡ I} ğ”ª / I = (\bigcap _{ğ”ª âŠ‡ I} ğ”ª) / I = J(R) / I. \end{equation}$$

Corollary, we have the following theorem:

$J(R / J(R)) = 0$.

VNR

To show the differences between semisimple rings and those satisfies $J(R)= 0$, we introduce von Neumann regular rings (vNR rings) which lay between

  • semisimple rings $>$ vNR rings $>$ rings with $0$ Jacobson radical.

Note that being semisimple/vNR/$J(R) = 0$ is two-sided, and Morita invariant.

Semisimple Rings

Wedderburn-Artin theorem characterises semisimple rings.

$R$ is semisimple iff the following equivalent conditions hold:

  1. $R$ is a finite product of simple Artinian rings (= matrix over division rings);
  2. $R$ is Artinian and $J(R) = 0$;
  3. $R$ is a left (or right) semisimple module;
  4. $ğŒğ¨ğ = ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$, i.e., every left (or right) module is projective;
  5. $ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R$ is a semisimple category;
  6. â€¦

Well-known.

Being semisimple is Morita invariant.

For any matrix ring $M_n (R)$, one has $ğ¦ğ¨ğ _{M_n (R)} = ğ¦ğ¨ğ _{R}$. Note that $R$ is semisimple iff $ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R$ is semisimple category.

Definition of vNR Rings

The followings are equivalent definition for $R$ to be a vNR ring. The first definition shows being vNR is a symmetric property. We proof for right modules only.

  1. $ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ = ğŒğ¨ğ$, i.e., all modules are flat.
  2. All f.g. ideals are projective.
  3. $ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£ = ğ¦ğ¨ğ$, i.e., finitely presented modules are projective.
  4. (von Neumannâ€™s original definition). For any $x âˆˆ R$, there exists some $y âˆˆ R$ s.t. $xyx=x$.

(1 â†” 3) is due to compact-$\varinjlim^{fil}$ argument. (1 â†’ 2) is clear. We show (2 â†’ 3). Note that the identity $ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£ = ğ¦ğ¨ğ$ is Morita invariant, and every $M âˆˆ ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R$ is the quotient ring of some $M_n (R)$ by a f.g. ideal.
(2 â†’ 4). Any principal ideal $(x)$ is generated by an idempotent element $e$. We write $x = ez$ and $e = xy$. Now

$$\begin{equation} x = ez = e(ez) = xyx. \end{equation}$$

(4 â†’ 2). Clearly, principal ideals are projective. By induction, it suffices to show that any $2$-generated ideal $(x,y)$ is principal. We assume

  • $x^2 = x$, since $(x)$ is projective;
  • $xy = 0$, since $(x,y) = (x, (1-x)y)$.

We take $\overline y$ s.t. $y \overline y y = y$, and consider the idempotent element

$$\begin{equation} e := y \overline y (1-x) ,\quad e^2 = e. \end{equation}$$

We show $(e + x) = (x,y)$. $e,x âˆˆ (x,y)$ is clear. Conversely,

  • $y = (e+x) y = ey = y \overline y y = y$, and
  • $x = (e+x)x = ex + x = 0 + x = x$.

Corollary,

Being vNR is two-sided and Morita invariant.

The final definition is two-sided. The identity $ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£ = ğ¦ğ¨ğ$ is Morita invariant.

Another symmetric (by rarely used) definition of vNR is that $I âˆ© J = IJ$ for any right ideal $I$ and left ideal $J$.

Clearly $I âˆ© J âŠ‡ IJ$. For any $x âˆˆ I âˆ© J$, there is some $y âˆˆ R$ s.t. $xyx = x$. Now $x âˆˆ I$ and $yx âˆˆ J$. Hence $x = (x)(yx) âˆˆ IJ$.

$J(R) = 0$ when $R$ is vNR.

For any $x âˆˆ J(R)$, we take $y$ s.t. $xyx = x$. Now $1 - xy$ is not a unit, a contradiciton.

Hence a vNR has no nilpotent elements.

The prime ideals coincides maximal ideals in a vNR ring.

Suppose $R / I$ has no non-zero divisor. For $[x] âˆˆ R / I$, there is some $y$ s.t. $[x][y][x] = [x]$. Hence $[y]$ is a two-sided inverse of $[x]$ when $[x] â‰  0$. Hence $R / I$ is a division ring.

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{Flat = Mod, and prime ideals = maximal ideals over vNR rings!}} \end{equation}$$

Examples of VNR Rings

Semisimple rings are special vNR rings.

Semisimple rings = left or right Noetherian vNR rings.

Semisimple rings are Noetherian and vNR. Conversely, any ideal in a Noetherian vNR ring is projective, thus the ring is semisimple.

The following example shows that vNR rings somehow generalise semisimple rings.

Let $M$ be any semisimple module. Then $\mathrm{End} _R (M)$ is a vNR ring.

For $f âˆˆ \mathrm{End} _R (M)$, one has $M = K âŠ• f(M)$. We define

$$\begin{equation} g : K âŠ• f(M) â†’ K âŠ• f(M),\quad (a,f(m)) â†¦ (0, f(m)). \end{equation}$$

Hence $fgf = g$.

In particular, $\mathrm{End} _R (M)$ is semisimple iff $M$ has finite length.

$J(\mathrm{End} _R (M)) = 0$ as it is vNR. $\mathrm{End} _R (M)$ is Artinian iff $M$ has finite length.

Taking $R = k$ (a field) and $M = k^{(Ï‰)}$, the endomorphism ring has a non-trivial right ideal consisting of finite rank operators. This shows

  • The Jacobson radical is not an intersection of maximal two-sided ideals, as the above ideal is the unique non-zero two-sided ideal;
  • There exists some f.g. flat module which is not projective.

Example: Banach Algebras

((Semi-)primitive ring). A ring $R$ is semi-primitive if $J(R) = 0$. Another definition for $R$ to be (semi-)primitive is that $\mathrm{ann}(M) = 0$ for some (semi-)simple module $M$.

It remains to show the differences between vNR rings and rings with semi-simple ones.

(For Banach spaces). Let $X$ be a real or complex Banach space. Let $\mathcal{B}(X)$ denote the endomorphism ring consisting of bounded linear operators. Then $J(\mathcal{B}(X)) = 0$, whereas $\mathcal{B}(X)$ is not vNR for most $X$.

By Hahn-Banach theorem, for any $x,y âˆˆ (X âˆ– 0)$ there is $Ï† âˆˆ \mathcal{B}(X)$ mapping $x$ to $y$. The $\mathcal{B}(X)$-module $X$ is generated by any non-zero element, thus it is simple. By definition, $\mathrm{ann}(X) = 0$. Hence $J(\mathcal{B}(X)) = 0$.
The ring $\mathcal{B}(X)$ is not vNR for most $X$. When $\mathcal{B}(X)$ is vNR, then all $T$ has a generalized inverse $S$ s.t. $TST = T$. Note that $\mathrm{Range}(T) = \mathrm{Range}(TS) = \ker (I - TS)$ is a closed subspace. However, not all continuous operators have closed range.

(Semi-)Local Rings

Recall that $J(R) + 1 âŠ† \text{Units}$. A local ring is precisely a ring s.t. $R = J(R) âŠ” \text{Units}$.

Local Rings

(Division rings, simple rings). A division ring $R$ has a unique maximal left or right ideal $0$. A simple ring $R$ has a unique maximal two-sided ideal $0$.

Division rings are simple; $M_2 (â„‚)$ is simple but not a division ring.

Now we equivalent definitions of local rings.

(Local rings). The following are equivalent definitions for $R$ to be local.

  1. Definitions by non-units:
    1. $R = J(R) âŠ” \text{Units}$;
    2. $R âˆ– \text{Units}$ is an ideal;
    3. $R âˆ– \text{Units}$ is an additive group;
    4. $x + y âˆˆ \text{Units}$ iff $x$ or $y$ is a unit;
    5. for any $x$, either $x$ or $1-x$ is a unit.
  2. Definitions by maximal ideals:
    1. $R$ has a unique maximal left ideal;
    2. $R$ has a unique maximal right ideal.
  3. $R / J(R)$ is a field.

Clearly (1.1 â†’ 1.2 â†’ 1.3 â†’ 1.4 â†” 1.5).
(2.2 â†’ 1.1). If $J(R)$ is the unique maximal right ideal, then $x âˆˆ (R âˆ– J(R))$ contains in no maximal ideal. Hence $x$ is a unit.
(3 â†” 2.1 â†” 2.2). $J(R)$ is a maximal right ideal iff the maximal right ideal is unique. Since $J$ commutes with $(-)^{\mathrm{op}}$, $(R/J(R))_R$ is a field iff $(R/J(R))_{R^{\mathrm{op}}}$ is a field.
(1.4 â†’ 3). It suffices show the maximal right ideal is unique. Since all non-units is closed under addition and multiplications, it is an ideal. Such ideal contains all maximal right ideals, hence it is the unique maximal right ideal.

A local ring has a unique two-sided ideal and only trivial idempotents. The converse is not true.

  1. The vNR ring $\mathrm{End}(â„ ^{(Ï‰ )})$ has a unique maximal two-sided ideal consisting of finite rank operators, but it is not local.
  2. The ring $â„¤$ has only trivial idempotents, it is not local neither.

(Artinian case). A right Artinian ring is local iff the idempotents are $\{0,1\}$.

The local ring has idempotent $\{0,1\}$. Conversely,

Corollary, a left Artinian local ring is right Artinian.

Semi-local Rings

(Generated and cogenerated). Say $M$ is finitely generated iff the following equivalent definitions hold:

  1. for any sum of submodules $M = âˆ‘ M_âˆ™$, there a finite sub-sum $M = âˆ‘ _{i=1}^n M_i$;
  2. any surjection $âˆ M_âˆ™ â†  M$, factors through a finite sub-coproduct $âˆ _{i=1}^n M_i â†  M$;
  3. any transfinite limit of inclusion of proper submodules is proper;
  4. for any cogenerator $E$ (e.g. $(_RR)^+$), there is an injection $M â†ª E^n$ for some $n$.

Dually, $M$ is finitely cogenerated iff the following equivalent definitions hold:

  1. for any intersection of submodules $0 = â‹‚ M_âˆ™$, there a finite sub-intersection $0 = â‹‚ _{i=1}^n M_i$;
  2. any injection $M â†ª âˆ M_âˆ™$, factors through a finite subproduct $M â†ª âˆ _{i=1}^n M_i$;
  3. any transfinite colimit of inclusion of proper submodules is non-zero;
  4. for any generator $Q$ (e.g. $R_R$), there is a surjection $Q^n â†  M$ for some $n$.

(Semi-local rings). The following are equivalent for $R$ to be semi-local:

  1. $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ is semisimple;
  2. $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ is right Artinian;
  3. $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ is finitely cogenerated;
  4. right semi-simple modules over $R$ are closed under $âˆ$.

(1 â†’ 2). By Wedderburn-Artin theorem.
(2 â†’ 3). For $M â†ª âˆ M_âˆ™$, we identify $M$ as a submodule of $âˆ M_âˆ™$. If this product never factors through a finite subproduct, then we obtain an infinite descending chain of submodules of $M$ by projection to finite subproducts. A contradiction!
(3 â†’ 2). Since $J(\frac{R}{J(R)}) = 0$, for any $\frac{R}{J(R)}$-module $M$, $â‹‚ _{f : M â†’ \text{simple}} \ker f = 0$. Hence the product of simple modules is a cogenerator. By assumption, $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ is a submodule of finite product of simple modules, it is right Artinian.
(1 â†’ 4). The product of semi-simple modules is a module over $\frac{R}{J(R)}$, hence it is semi-simple as both an $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ module and an $R$ module.
(4 â†’ 1). By analysis of (3 â†’ 2), we see $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ is a submodule of a product of simple modules, hence it is semi-simple.

Local rings and Artinian rings are semi-local.

Note that for $R = M_n(â„‚)$, $R / J(R)$ is simple but not a division ring. $R$ is semi-local but not local.

Being semi-local is two-sides and Morita invariant.

Being semi-local is preserved by taking quotients and finite products.

For $I âŠ† R$, one has $\frac{R}{J(R)} â†  \frac{R/I}{J(R/I)}$. If $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ is semisimple, then $\frac{R/I}{J(R/I)}$ is also semisimple. For finite products, note that $\frac{âˆ R_i}{J(âˆ R_i)} = âˆ \frac{R_i}{J(R_i)}$.

A ring with finitely many maximal right ideals is semi-local. The converse holds for commutative rings.

Note that $R' := R / J(R)$ has finitely many maximal right ideals with intersection $0$. Hence $R' â†ª âˆ _{i=1}^n ğ”ª _i$, yielding that $R'$ is semi-simple. Consequently $R$ is semi-local.
Conversely (for the case $R'$ is commutative), $R'$ is a product of finitely many fields, thus $R$ has finitely many maximal ideals.

More

A division ring is precisely $R / J(R)$ where $R$ is local.

A semisimple ring is precisely $R / J(R)$ where $R$ is left (or right) Artinian (or semi-local).

There is few study on the ring $R$ with $R / J(R)$ being vNR.

A semi-primitive ring is precisely $R / J(R)$ where $R$ is arbitrary ring.

(Semi-)Perfect Rings

This is another radical-based topic related to projective cover.

On Idempotents

Definitions

(Idempotents). Let $e âˆˆ R$. Say $e$ is idempotent if $e^2 = e$. Moreover,

  1. $e$ is central idempotent if $er = re$ for all $r âˆˆ R$;
  2. $e$ is primitive idempotent if $Re$ is indecomposable;
  3. (stronger than 2.) $e$ is local idempotent if $eRe$ is a local ring;
  4. (stronger than 3.) $e$ is (right) irreducible idempotent if $eR$ is a minimal (right) ideal.

TFAE for defining primitive idempotents:

  1. there are no idempotents $e_1$ and $e_2$ s.t. $e_1 e_2 = 0 = e_2 e_1$ and $e = e_1 + e_2$;
  2. $eR$ is indecomposable, or equivalently, $Re$ is indecomposable;
  3. the idempotents in $eRe$ are $0$ and the unit $e$.

Clear. Note that $\mathrm{End}_R(eR) â‰ƒ eRe$ as Abelian groups.

For idempotent $e$, $eRe$ is the corner part of the endomorphism matrix $\mathrm{End}_R(eR âŠ• (1-e)R)$.

The Ring $eRe$

A split monomorphism is related to pure embedding.

The homomorphism of rings $eRe â†ª R$ has the following property, for any right ideal $I âŠ† eRe$, $(I R) âˆ© eRe = I$.

Note that $I = Ie âŠ‡ IRe âˆ© eRee = I âˆ© eRe = I$. Hence the equality holds.

$J(eRe) = eJ(R)e$ for any idempotent $e âˆˆ R$.

Note that

$$\begin{equation} J(eRe) = â‹‚_{ğ”ª âŠ† eRe} ğ”ª = eRe âˆ© â‹‚_{ğ”ª âŠ† eRe} ğ”ªR âŠ† eRe âˆ© J(R) âŠ† eJ(R)e. \end{equation}$$

Conversely, for any $x âˆˆ J(R)$, we show $exe âˆˆ J(eRe)$. Note that any $e - exeeye = e(1-x(eye))$. We take $z$ s.t. $(1-xeye)z$ is a unit. Now $e - exeeye$ has right inverse $eze$.

We show some additive properties of Jacobson radical:

$$\begin{equation} \boxed {\text{Jacobson radical commutes with corner rings, products, and matrix rings!}} \end{equation}$$

Idempotents in $R / J$

We take $R â†  R/J =: R,\quad x â†¦ x'$. Recall that

(Idempotents). Let $e âˆˆ R$. Say $e$ is idempotent if $e^2 = e$. Moreover,

  1. $e$ is central idempotent if $er = re$ for all $r âˆˆ R$;
  2. $e$ is primitive idempotent if $Re$ is indecomposable;
  3. (stronger than 2.) $e$ is local idempotent if $eRe$ is a local ring;
  4. (stronger than 3.) $e$ is (right) irreducible idempotent if $eR$ is a minimal (=simple) (right) ideal.

We show some property of $e â†¦ e'$.

$e$ is local iff $e'$ is right irreducible.

We take the homomorphism of $eRe$-bimodules, and obtain

$$\begin{equation} eRe â†  e' R' e',\quad exe â†¦ e'x'e'. \end{equation}$$

The kernel is $eJ(R)e = J(eRe)$. Hence $eRe / J(eRe) â‰ƒ e' R' e'$. The ring $eRe$ is local iff $e' R' e'$ is a division ring. We show $e' R' e'$ is a division ring iff $e' R'$ is a minimal (=simple) right ideal.

  1. When $e'R'$ is simple, then $e'R'e'$ is a division ring by Schurâ€™s lemma.
  2. When $e'R'e'$ is a division ring, we show $e'R'$ is a simple right $R'$-module, i.e., $e'R'$ is cyclicly generated by arbitrary non-zero element $e'r'$. Note that $e's' = e'r'e (e'r'e')^{-1}(e's')$.

Corollary, $e' âˆˆ R/J$ is right irreducible iff it is left irreducible.

Note that $e'R' = \frac{eR}{eJ}$. Equivalently, $e$ is local idempotent iff $eJ$ is the unique maximal submodule of $eR$.

When $eJ$ is the unique maximal submodule of $eR$, then $e'R' â‰ƒ \frac{eR}{eJ}$ is simple. Conversely, suppose $e'R'$ is simple, and there is some ideal $I$ s.t. $I \notâŠ† eJ$. Then $0 â‰  \frac{I + eJ}{eJ} âŠ† e'R'$. Hence $I + eJ = eR$. By Nakayama lemma, $I = eR$, a contradiction.

This shows the $\text{local} â†” \text{division}$, $R â†” R/J$ correspondence.

Endomorphism Ring

Finite Length Modules

(Finite length module). Finite length modules are precisely the finite filtration of simple modules.

Note that:

  1. The category of finite length modules are closed under extensions, subobjects and quotient objects, which forms a Serre subcategory;
  2. Finite length modules are Artinian, Noetherian, and finitely generated (not necessary finitely presented, e.g., $k â†ª k[x_{â‰¥ 1}]$);
  3. Finite length modules over $ğŒğ¨ğ _{R}$ are precisely those over $ğŒğ¨ğ _{R/J(R)}$ (for $P$ semisimple, $PJ(R) = 0$).

In particular, f.g. modules over an Artinian ring are precisely the finite length modules.

The following theorem defines the length function.

(Jordan-HÃ¶lder). Any two composition series of a finite length module have the same length and the same simple factors (up to permutation and isomorphism). In short, the simple factors are unique.

Let $0 = X_0 âŠ† \cdots âŠ† X_m = M$ and $0 âŠ† Y_0 âŠ† \cdots âŠ† Y_n = M$ be two composition series. By Zassenhaus lemma, we define

$$\begin{equation} M_{i,j}^â†’ := \frac{X_{i+1} âˆ© (Y_{j+1} + X_i)}{X_{i+1} âˆ© (Y_j + X_i)} â‰ƒ \frac{Y_{j+1} âˆ© (X_{i+1} + Y_j)}{Y_{j+1} âˆ© (X_i + Y_j)} =: M_{i,j}^â†“. \end{equation}$$

The tessellation $(M_{i,j})$ has precisely one simple factor in each row and column. Hence $m = n$ and the simple factors are the same.

The theorem fails for non-finite length modules. We show an example where the indecomposable definitions existes but not unique. Note that the coordinate ring of a nonsingular (smooth), geometrically integral affine curve, hence $\frac{â„ [X,Y]}{(X^2 + Y^2 - 1)}$ is a Dedekind domain (the ideal class group is infact $â„¤/2â„¤$). The maximal ideal $I = (X-1, Y)$ is not principal, but $I^2 = (X-1)$ is principal. We obtain two distinct decompositions into indecomposable modules:

$$\begin{equation} I âŠ• I â‰ƒ R âŠ• I^2 â‰ƒ R âŠ• R. \end{equation}$$

This defined a length function.

(Length functor). We define the assignment $â„“(M) âˆˆ â„•^{\text{Simple Modules}}$, where $(â„“ (M))_{S}$ denote the number of $S$ in the composition series of $M$.

$â„“$ is compatible with ses, i.e., $â„“ (\frac{M}{L}) = â„“ (M) - â„“ (L)$.

(Fitting). An endomorphism of a finite length module, $f âˆˆ \mathrm{End}(M)$, yields a decomposition $M = \ker(f^n) âŠ• \mathrm{im}(f^n)$ such that $f$ has a matrix form $\binom{0 \ 0}{0 \ 1}$.

Note that $\{\ker (f^n)\}_{n â‰¥ 1}$ stables at some $n$. We show $\ker f^n âˆ© \operatorname{im} f^n = 0$.

  • Suppose $x = f^n (y) âˆˆ \ker f^n âˆ© \operatorname{im} f^n$. Then $y âˆˆ \ker f^{2n} = \ker f^n$. Hence $x = f^n (y) = 0$.

We also show that $\ker f^n + \operatorname{im} f^n = M$.

  • For any $x âˆˆ M$, there is $y$ s.t. $f^{2n}(y) = f^n (x)$. Now $x = (x-f^n(y)) + f^n (y)$ is the desired decomposition.

(KS). Any finite length module is a finite direct sum of indecomposable modules. Moreover, the indecomposable decomposition is unique up to permutation and isomorphism.

By finite length, any direct sum decomposition lies in a maximal one. For any two maximal decompositions $M = âˆ _i X_i = âˆ_j Y_j$. We show $X_1 â‰ƒ Y_j$ for some $j$. We define $x_i : M \overset {Ï€_i} â†  X_i \overset {Î¹ _i} â†ª M$ and $y_j$ (similarly). Note that all $x_i$ and $y_j$ are idempotents. Since $x_1 âˆ‘ y_j = x_1$, there is some $j$ s.t. $x_1 y_j â‰  0$. Note that $(x_1y_j)|_{Y_j} âˆ˜ (y_jx_1)|_{X_1} âˆˆ \mathrm{End}(X_1)$ is a non-zero idempotent, hence a unit. We see $X_1$ is a direct summand of $Y_j$. The rest of the proof is clear.

Now we consider endomorphism ring of finite length module.

Let $M$ be an indecomposable finite length module with $n$ composition factors. Then $\mathrm{End}(M)$ is a local artinian ring where $ğ”ª^n = 0$ for all maximal ideal. In particular,

$$\begin{equation} J(\mathrm{End}(M)) = \{f : \operatorname{im}(f) â†ª M \ \text{is superfluous}.\}. \end{equation}$$

Fitting lemma shows that non-units in $\mathrm{End}(M)$ are nilpotent. By Nakayama lemma, multiplying a nilpotent strictly decreases the length of a f.g. module. Hence, the multiplication of $n$ nilpotent endomorphisms is $0$. It remains to show $f$ is nilpotent iff $f(M)$ is a superfluous submodule.

  • Suppose $f^n(M) = 0$ for some minimal $n â‰¥ 1$, and $f(M) + N = M$ for proper submodule $N$. We see $0 â‰  f^{n-1}(M) = f^{n-1}(N)$. Nakayama lemma shows $f^{n-1}(N) = 0$, a contradiction.
  • Suppose $f(M) âŠ† M â‰  0$ is superfluous, then it is a proper submodule by existence of maximal submodules. Note that the surjection never increase the length, hence there is no $g$ s.t. $gf(M) = M$. We see $f$ is a non-unit, thus nilpotent.

The above indicates $M = M J(R)$. Moreover,

$$\begin{equation} J(\mathrm{End}(M)) â‰ƒ (M, J(M)) â‰ƒ (J(M), M). \end{equation}$$

Corollary, the statements holds for any finite length module $M$.

(Endolocal). A module $M$ is endolocal if $\mathrm{End}(M)$ is a local ring.

Any indecomposable injective module $I$ is endolocal. This holds for general Grothendieck categories.

To see any $S â†ª I$ is essential, we take $\mathcal{S} := \{T â†ª I âˆ£ T âˆ© S = 0\}$. We show the fully faithful embedding ${}_RğŒğ¨ğ â†ª (ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R, ğ€ğ› ), \quad M â†¦ \varinjlim {}^{fil} (- âŠ— M_âˆ™)$:

$$\begin{aligned} & (\varinjlim {}^{fil} (- âŠ— M_âˆ™), \varinjlim {}^{fil} (- âŠ— N_âˆ™)) â‰ƒ \varprojlim {}^{cofil} ( (- âŠ— M_âˆ™), \varinjlim {}^{fil}(- âŠ— N_âˆ™)) \\ â‰ƒ \ & \varprojlim {}^{cofil} ( (M'_âˆ™, -), \varinjlim {}^{fil}(N'_âˆ™, -)) â‰ƒ \varprojlim {}^{cofil} \varinjlim {}^{fil}(N'_âˆ™, M'_âˆ™ )_{ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R} \\ â‰ƒ \ & (\varinjlim {}^{fil} N'_âˆ™, \varinjlim {}^{fil} M'_âˆ™ )_{ğŒğ¨ğ _R} â‰ƒ (M, N)_{ğŒğ¨ğ _R}. \end{aligned}$$

We show injectives in $(ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R, ğ€ğ› )$ are precisely $- âŠ— E$ where $E$ is pure injective, and vise versa.

Hence, $Î¹ = - âŠ— e$ for some $e : E â†’ F(R)$ by fully faithful embedding. We see $e$ is a pure embedding, thus $E$ is a summand of pure injective module $F(R)$.

KSRA Theorem

The KS theorem admits a generalisation for modules with infinite length, wherein endolocal modules generalises indecomposable modules with finite length.

(Cancellable summands). Let $A âŠ• B = A âŠ• C$ as internal direct sums. Then $B â‰ƒ C$ via the canonical projection.

We take $Ï€ : A âŠ• B â†  C$. Note that $Ï€ ((a,b)) = Ï€ ((0,b))$. Hence $Ï€ |_B$ is epic. If $Ï€ ((0,b)) = 0$, then $b âˆˆ A$. Hence $b = 0$, yields $Ï€ |_B$ is also monic. We see $Ï€ |_B$ is an isomorphism.

This theorem fails for external direct sums, e.g., $â„¤ ^{(Ï‰)} âŠ• â„¤ â‰ƒ â„¤ ^{(Ï‰)} âŠ• 0$.

KS theorem comes form the unique factorisation. The key construction is

  • For any $M âŠ• N = âˆ_{i âˆˆ I} X_i$, there is a collection of submodules $Y_i âŠ† X_i$ s.t. $M âŠ• N = M âŠ• âˆ Y_i$.

When $I = 1$, we may take $Y = X âˆ© N$. Such construction fails even for the case $|I|=2$ when $R$ is a Dedekind domain with complicated ideal class group.

(Exchange property). Say $M$ is $Îº$-exchangable if for any decomposition $M âŠ• N = âˆ _{i âˆˆ I} X_i$ with $|I| = Îº$ there is a collection of submodules $Y_i âŠ† X_i$ s.t. $M âŠ• N = M âŠ• âˆ Y_i$.

  • Here we fixed $M âˆ N$ for arbitrary chosen $N$, and view $M âŠ• N = âˆ _{i âˆˆ I} X_i$ as internal direct sum.
  • By cancellable property, $N â‰ƒ âˆ Y_i$ via canonial projections.

The exchane property is compatible with the summand of $N$.

$Y_i$ are summands of $X_i$ in the above definition.

For each $i$, one has $Y_i âŠ† X_i âŠ† Y_i âŠ• Z_i$ for $Z_i = M âŠ• âˆ_{â‰  i} Y_j$. We see

  • $Y_i âˆ© (Z_i âˆ© X_i) = 0$, and
  • $X_i = (Y_i + Z_i) âˆ© X_i = Y_i + (Z_i âˆ© X_i)$ by modular law.

Hence $X_i = Y_i âŠ• (Z_i âˆ© X_i)$.

The decomposition writes

$$\begin{equation} M âŠ• N = âˆ _I X_i ,\quad X_i = Y_i âŠ• Z_i, \quad N â‰ƒ âˆ _I Y_i ,\quad M â‰ƒ âˆ _I Z_i. \end{equation}$$

In particular, if $X_i$ happens to be direct summand of $N$, then we have the following refinement.

When $M âŠ• N = âˆ _{i âˆˆ I} X_i$ for $N = X_0 âŠ• L$. Then we can take $Y_0 = X_0$.

Set $J = I âˆ– \{0\}$. We have $M âŠ• L âŠ• X_0 = âˆ _J X_âˆ™ âŠ• X_0$. Cancellable property yields $Ï† : âˆ _J X_âˆ™ â‰ƒ (M âŠ• L)$. Hence

$$\begin{equation} M âŠ• L \xleftarrow[âˆ¼ ]Ï† âˆ _J X_âˆ™ = Ï† ^{-1}(M) âŠ• âˆ _J Y_âˆ™ . \end{equation}$$

Now $M âŠ• L âŠ• X_0 = M âŠ• (âˆ _J Ï† (Y_âˆ™ )) âŠ• X_0$.

Being $|I|$-exchangable is closed under finite direct sums.

Let $M$ and $M'$ be $|I|$-exchangable. Suppose $\text{all} = M âŠ• M' âŠ• N = âˆ _I X_âˆ™$. We obtain

$$\begin{equation} M âŠ• (M'âŠ• N) = M âŠ• (âˆ _I Y_âˆ™),\quad Ï† : (M'âŠ• N) â‰ƒ âˆ _I Y_âˆ™. \end{equation}$$

By assumption, $âˆ _I Y_âˆ™ = Ï† (M)' âŠ• âˆ _I Z_âˆ™$. Hence

$$\begin{equation} M âŠ• M' âŠ• N = (M âŠ• M') âŠ• âˆ _I Ï† ^{-1}(Z_âˆ™). \end{equation}$$

Being $|I|$-exchangable is closed under finite direct summands.

Let $M = M_1 âŠ• M_2$ be $|I|$-exchangable. Suppose $M_1 âŠ• N = âˆ _I X_âˆ™$, then $M âŠ• N = (M_2 âŠ• X_0) âŠ• âˆ _{â‰  0} X_âˆ™$. We take $Y_0 âŠ† (M_2 âŠ• X_0)$ and $Y_{â‰  0} âŠ† X_{â‰  0}$ s.t. $M âŠ• N = M âŠ• âˆ Y_âˆ™$. Let $Ï€ : M âŠ• N â†  M_1 âŠ• N$ be canonical projection. It straightforward to check that $M_1 âŠ• âˆ _I Ï€ (Y_âˆ™) = M_1 âŠ• N$.

We show a criterion of $|I|$-changable modules on endomorphism rings.

$M$ is $|I|$-exchangable iff for any $(f_i)_{|I|} âˆˆ (M, âˆ M) âŠ† âˆ_I \mathrm{End}(M)$ summing up to $1_M$, there are orthogonal idempotents $\{g_i âˆ˜ f_i\}_I$ summing up to $1$.

  • Note that for each $m$, only finite many $f_i(m)$ are non-zero.

Suppose $M$ is $|I|$-exchangable. For any given $(f_i)$, there is a retract $M \xrightarrow {(f_âˆ™ )} âˆ _I M \xrightarrow{Î£ } M$. We take

$$\begin{equation} M âŠ• âˆ _I M_âˆ™ ^s = âˆ _I M_âˆ™ ,\quad M_âˆ™ = M_âˆ™ ^s âŠ• M_âˆ™ ^c. \end{equation}$$

Let $Ï„ : âˆ _I M_âˆ™ ^c â‰ƒ M$ denote the isomorphism by canonical projection. We take

$$\begin{equation} e_i : M \xrightarrow {(f_âˆ™ )} \underset{\text{induced by } \ Ï„ }{\underbrace{âˆ _I M_âˆ™ â†  M_i ^c â†ª âˆ _I M_âˆ™}} \xrightarrow {Î£ } M. \end{equation}$$

Conversely, suppose there is identity $M âŠ• N = âˆ_I X_âˆ™$, we take the composition

$$\begin{equation} f_i := M â†ª M âŠ• N â†  X_i â†ª âˆ _I X_âˆ™ â†  M. \end{equation}$$

This extends to $(f_âˆ™ ) âˆˆ (M, âˆ M)$ which summing up to $1$. By assumption, there are orthogonal idempotents $\{g_i âˆ˜ f_i\}_I$ summing up to $1$. Now $Y_i := \operatorname{im}(M â†ª M âŠ• N â†  X_i )$ is the desired summand of $X_i$.

Now we show a criterion for being finite exchangable.

$M$ is finite exchangable iff it is $2$-exchangable.

We show $M$ is $(k+1)$-exchangable when it is $k$-exchangable ($k â‰¥ 2$). We take $(f_i)_{i=0}^k$ summing up to $1$. We apply $2$-exchangable property to $f_0 + (âˆ‘ _{0<âˆ™ â‰¤ k}f_âˆ™)$, hence WLOG we assume $f_0$ is idenpotent. Set $e := (1-f_0)$. Now $âˆ‘ _{0< âˆ™ â‰¤ k}ef_âˆ™ e = e$. Note $Me$ is $k$-exchangable with endomorphism ring $e \mathrm{End}(M)e$. Now there is some idempotent decomposition in $e\mathrm{End}(M)e$:

$$\begin{equation} âˆ‘ _{0 < i â‰¤ k} e g_i e f_i e = e,\quad (e g_i e f_i e)(e g_j e f_j e) = Î´ ^{i,j} (e g_i e f_i e). \end{equation}$$

We set $F_i := e g_i e f_i e g_i e f_i$ for $0 < i â‰¤ k$, and $F_0 := 1 - âˆ‘ _{0<âˆ™ â‰¤ k}F_âˆ™$.

  • $F_i^2 = (e g_i e f_i e)^3 g_i e f_i = F_i$;
  • $F_i F_j = e g_i e f_i (e g_i e f_i e g_j e f_j e) g_j e f_j = 0$ when $i â‰  j$;
  • $F_0 F_{â‰  0} = F_{â‰  0} F_0 = 0$ and $F_0^2 = F_0$ follow from the construction;
  • $F_0 f_0 = F_0 - F_0e = F_0$. Hence $F_0 = ? âˆ˜ f_0$.

The following are equivalent for any module $M$:

  1. $M$ is endolocal;
  2. $M$ is indecomposable and finite exchangable;
  3. $M$ is indecomposable and $Îº$-exchangable for arbitrary $Îº$.

(1 â†’ 2). Endolocal modules are indecomposable by checking idempotents. When $\mathrm{End}(M)$ is local, any $x+y = 1$ implies $x$ or $y$ is a unit. WLOG we take $x^{-1}x = 1$ and $0y = 0$, hence $M$ is $2$-exchangable. By previous analysis, $M$ is finite exchangable.
(2 â†’ 3). We show $M$ is $|I|$ exchangable when it is finite exchangable. When $M âŠ• N = âˆ _I X_âˆ™$, we take non-zero $m âˆˆ M$ which lies in a minimal finite summand $âˆ _{I_0} X_âˆ™$. Now we consider $M âŠ• N = âˆ _{I_0} X_âˆ™ âŠ• (âˆ _{I âˆ– I_0}X_âˆ™ ) =: â¨ _{t=0}^{|I_0|} L_t$. By finite exchangable property, there is $L_t := Y_t âŠ• Z_t$ s.t. $M âŠ• âˆ_{t=0} Y_t = M âŠ• N$. Hence $M â‰ƒ â¨_{t=0}^{|I_0|} Z_t$ by cancellable property. Since $M$ is indecomposable, there is precisely one $t_0$ s.t. $Z_{t_0} â‰ƒ M$. We see $t_0 â‰  0$, as $X_{i_0} âˆ© M â‰  0$ for any $i _0 âˆˆ I_0$. In this case,

$$\begin{equation} M âŠ• N = M âŠ• L_{t_0} âŠ• (âˆ _{t â‰  t_0} X_t) âŠ• (âˆ _{I âˆ– I_0}X_âˆ™ ). \end{equation}$$

Hence $M$ is $|I|$-exchangable.
(3 â†’ 1). We take $Îº =2$ and show that $x + y = 1$ implies $x$ or $y$ is a unit.

(A kind of compactness). The finite direct sum of endolocal modules $K := â¨ M_âˆ™$ are somehow compact: for $K âŠ• N = âˆ _{I} X_âˆ™$,

  • there is a finite subset $I_0 âŠ† I$ s.t. $K âŠ• N = K âŠ• (âˆ _{I_0} Y_âˆ™) âŠ• (âˆ _{I âˆ– I_0}X_âˆ™ )$;
  • corollary, there is finite subset $I_0 âŠ† I$ and $Y âŠ• Z = âˆ _{I_0}X_âˆ™$ s.t. $K â‰ƒ Y$ and $K âŠ• N = Y âŠ• Z âŠ• (âˆ _{I âˆ– I_0}X_âˆ™)$;
  • corollary, the set $\{i âˆ£ K âˆ© X_i â‰  0\}$ is always finite.

Note that it is not true that $M âˆ© (X_1 âŠ• X_2) = (M âˆ© X_1) âŠ• (M âˆ© X_2)$ for endolocal modules. One may find non-examples in $â„ âŠ† â„ ^2$.

We complete the section with KSRA theorem.

(Krull-Schmidt-Remak-Azumaya). Let $M = âˆ M_âˆ™$ be a coproducts of endolocal modules. Then any indecomposable decomposition of $M$ is unique up to permutation and isomorphism.

Such decomposition exists by definition. We show any indecomposable summand is endolocal.

  • We take $L âŠ• N = âˆ M_âˆ™$. For any non-zero $x âˆˆ L$, there is a minimal finite summand $âˆ _{I_0} M_âˆ™$ containing $x$. Note that $âˆ _{I_0}X_âˆ™ âŠ• âˆ _{I âˆ– I_0}X_âˆ™ = L âŠ• N$ where $âˆ _{I_0}X_âˆ™$ is finite exchangable. Now $L âŠ• N = âˆ _{I_0}X_âˆ™ âŠ• L_0 âŠ• N_0$ for $L_0 âŠ† L$ and $N_0 âŠ† N$ are summands. $L_0 = 0$ as $L âˆ© (âˆ _{I_0}X_âˆ™ ) â‰  0$. Hence $L$ is isomorphic to a summand of finite exchangable module $âˆ_{I âˆ– I_0}X_âˆ™$, thus endolocal.

To see the uniqueness, we take $âˆ M_âˆ™ = âˆ N_âˆ™$. Clearly $N_âˆ™$â€™s are endolocal. We fix an endolocal module $E$ and take $G = \{i âˆ£ M_i â‰ƒ E\}$ and $H = \{j âˆ£ N_j â‰ƒ E\}$. We show $|G| = |H|$.
($|G| < âˆ$ iff $|H| < âˆ$). Suppose $|G| < âˆ$. There is finite $J_0 âŠ† J$ s.t. $âˆ _G M_âˆ™ âŠ† âˆ _{I_0} N_âˆ™$. Clearly $H âˆ© (I âˆ– I_0) = âˆ…$; otherwise $âˆ _{I âˆ– G}M_âˆ™$ has a summand isomorphic to $E$, and exchangable property shows contradiction. A symmetric analysis shows $|G| < âˆ$ iff $|G| < âˆ$.
($|G| = |H|$ for finite case). There are finite sets $I_0$ and $J_0$ s.t.

$$\begin{equation} âˆ _GM_âˆ™ âŠ† âˆ _{H âˆª J_0} N_âˆ™ âŠ† âˆ _{G âˆª I_0} M_âˆ™. \end{equation}$$

Hence, there is $âˆ _GM_âˆ™ âŠ• ? = âˆ _{H âˆª J_0} N_âˆ™$. By exchangable property, there are summands $N_âˆ™ '$ s.t. $âˆ _{H âˆª J_0} N_âˆ™ ' = âˆ _GM_âˆ™$. Hence $|H| â‰¥ |G|$. A symmetric analysis shows $|G| = |H|$.
($|G|$ and $|H|$ are infinite). For each $t âˆˆ G$, there are finite sets $H_t$, $I_t$ and $J_t$ s.t.

$$\begin{equation} M_t âŠ† âˆ _{H_t âˆª J_t} N_âˆ™ âŠ† âˆ _{G âˆª I_t} M_âˆ™. \end{equation}$$

Hence $âˆ _G M_âˆ™ âŠ† âˆ _{â‹ƒ H_t âˆª â‹ƒ J_t} N_âˆ™ âŠ† âˆ _{G âˆª â‹ƒ I_t} M_âˆ™$. By exchangable property, $âˆ _G M_âˆ™ âŠ† âˆ _{â‹ƒ H_t âˆª â‹ƒ J_t} N_âˆ™$ is a summand. Since $âˆ _{J âˆ– (â‹ƒ H_t âˆª â‹ƒ J_t)} N_âˆ™$ is isomorphic to a summand of $âˆ _{I âˆ– G} M_âˆ™$, it contains no summand isomorphic to $E$. Hence $â‹ƒ H_t = H$. Now $|G| â‰¤ Ï‰ |H| = |H|$. A symmetric analysis shows $|G| = |H|$.

From Nilpotent to Radical

We generalise several properties of nilpotent ideals to radicals, e.g., the idempotent lifting property, Nakayama lemma, etc.

Nil Lifting

(Nil ideal). The ideal with all elements nilpotent is called a nil ideal.

The maximal ideal of the commutative local ring $k[x_1, x_2, \ldots] / (\{x_k^k\}_{k â‰¥ 1})$ is nil but not nilpotent.

(Nil lifting). Let $I$ be a nil ideal. Then idempotent element $[x] âˆˆ R/I$ has an idempotent preimage in $R$. In particular, the lifting is unique for commutative rings.

Let $e$ be arbitrary preimage of $[x]$. There is $k$ s.t. $(e(1-e))^k = 0$. There is a polynomial $p = p(e)$ s.t. $e^k + (1-e)^k + p = 1$. Clearly $p âˆˆ I$, we take $q := (1-p)^{-1}$ (also a polynomial in $e$). Now

  • $e^kq$ is a preimage of $[x]$;
  • $e^kq + (1-e)^kq = (1-p)^{-1}q = 1$;
  • $e^kq (1-e)^kq = 0$;
  • $(e^kq)^2 = e^kq (1-(1-e^k)q) = e^kq$.

Let $e$ and $e'$ be liftings of $[x]$. When the ring is commutative, we conclude from $(e-e')^3 = (e-e')$ and $(e-e')^N = 0$ that $e = e'$. For non-commutative rings, the lifting is not unique in general. For instance, we take $M_2(â„¤ / 4â„¤) â†  \frac{M_2(â„¤ / 4â„¤)}{J(M_2(â„¤ / 4â„¤))} â‰ƒ M_2(ğ”½ _2)$, then $\mathrm{id}$ has distinct liftings $\mathrm{id}$ and $\binom{1 \ 2}{0 \ 1}$.

There are several generalisations of the property â€œnil liftingâ€.

Let $I$ be a nil ideal. Any lifting of the unit $[x] âˆˆ R / I$ is also a unit. The lifting is unique when $R$ is commutative.

Let $[y]$ be the inverse of $[x]$. Note that $(xy-1)^N = 0$ for some $N$. Hence $(x) = 1$, i.e., $x$ is a unit. The uniqueness of commutative case comes from $(x-x')^3 = (x-x')$.

The nil ideals are close to nilpotent ones. The following interesting theorem shows they are the same in Noetherian rings.

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{For CommRings, Nil lifting is always unique!}} \end{equation}$$

There is a concern whether nillifting preserves orthogonality.

Let $I âŠ† J(R)$ be a right ideal which admits idempotent lifting property. For any orthogonal idempotents $[e], [f] âˆˆ \frac{R}{J(R)}$ and any idempotent lifting $e$ of $[e]$, there exists an idempotent lifting $f'$ of $[f]$ s.t. $e,f'$ are orthogonal in $R$.

Let $f$ be any idempotent lifting of $f$. Then $fe âˆˆ I âŠ† J(R)$. We take $$\begin{equation} f' := (1-e)(1-fe)^{-1}f(1-fe) \end{equation}$$

We see that

  • $(f - f') â‰¡ (1-e)(f - (1-fe)^{-1}f(1-fe)) â‰¡ 0 \mod I$;
  • $ef' = (e-e^2)(1-fe)^{-1}f(1-fe) = 0$;
  • $f' e = (1-e)(1-fe)^{-1}(fe - ffee) = 0$;
  • $f' ^2 = (1-e)(1-fe)^{-1}\underset{= f}{\underbrace{f(1-fe)(1-e)(1-fe)^{-1}f}}(1-fe) =f'$.

For any countable set of orthogonal idempotents $\{[e_i]\}_{i âˆˆ â„•} âŠ† R / I$, where $I âŠ† J(R)$ admits the idempotent lifting property. Then there is a way to find orthogonal idempotent liftings $\{e_i\}_{i âˆˆ â„•} âŠ† R$. Moreover one can begin with any choice of lifting $e_{n_0} â†¦ [e_{n_0}]$.

By induction. Since being an othogonal idempotent set is verified by collection of finite sums, the induction extends to countable sets.

Hence, for nil ideals, idempotent lifting can be chosen to preserve orthogonality.

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{Nil idempotent lifting preserves orthogonality!}} \end{equation}$$

(Levitzki). Let $R$ be a right Noetherian ring. Then every nil right ideal is nilpotent.

Let $I$ be such nil ideal. By Noetherian conditions, there is a maximal nilpotent ideal $N âŠ† I$. Suppose $N â‰  I$, then $\{\mathrm{ann}(x) : x âˆˆ (I âˆ– N)\}$ has a maximal element $\mathrm{ann}(x_0)$. For any $r âˆˆ I$, there is $n$ s.t. $(x_0 r)^n = 0$. One has either $x_0rx_0 = 0$ or $\mathrm{ann}(x_0rx_0) = \mathrm{ann}(x_0)$ by maximality of $\mathrm{ann}(x_0)$. By induction, $x_0 r x_0 = 0$. Suppose $N^k = 0$, then $(N + (x_0))^{2k}$ is generated by elements of the types

  1. the monomial consisting of at least two $x_0$, or
  2. the monomial with letters in $N^k$.

Hence $(N + (x_0))$ is nilpotent, a contradiction!

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{For Noetherian rings, nil = nilpotent!}} \end{equation}$$

The commutative case is easy, which reveals $\mathrm{Spec}(R/I) â‰ƒ \mathrm{Spec}(R)$ induced by $R â†  R/I$ for any nil ideal $I$.

Nil Lifting f.g. Projectives

We show nil lifting for idempotents, which suggests a bijection between f.g. projective modules.

Let $I$ be a nil right ideal, then $Ï† : R â†  R / I$ induces a bijection between the isomorphism classes of f.g. projective modules via $Ï†^âˆ— : ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£(R/I) â†’ ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£ (R)$ and $P â†¦ P/PI$.

  • This shows isomorphism between the Grothendieck groups $K_0(R) â‰ƒ K_0(R/I)$.

If $P âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ is projective, then $P/PI âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{R/I}$ is projective.

  • (Surjective). Any projective module $Q$ over $R/I$ takes the form $[e] (R/I)^n$. By idempotent lifting, $Q = (eR^n)/I$.
  • (Injective). For projective $R$ modules $P$ and $P'$ s.t. $P/PI â‰ƒ P'/P'I$. We take $P â†  P/PI$ and $P' â†  P'/P'I$. The lifting property yields $P â†’ P'$. Note that $\operatorname{im}(P â†’ P') + P'I = P'$, and $P' I âŠ† P' J(R)$ is superfluous (by Nakayama lemma). Hence $P â†’ P'$ is surjective. By symmetric analysis, $P â‰ƒ P'$.

Semiperfect Rings

We generalise nil lifting to radical lifting.

(Semi-perfect rings). $R$ is semiperfect if it is semi-local (i.e., $R/J(R)$ is semi-simple) and idempotents lift modulo $J(R)$.

Any left or right Artinian ring $R$ is semiperfect.

$R / J(R)$ is Artinian with $J(R/J(R)) = 0$, hence semisimple. Note that $J(R)$ is nilpotent. The idempotent lifting follows from nil lifting.

Semi-primitive rings (= $J(R) = 0$) with finite many primitive orthogonal idempotents are semiperfect.

A semi-perfect ring looks like a matrix with finite many local diagonal blocks.

The following are equivalent:

  1. $R$ is semi-perfect;
  2. there are finite local orthogonal idempotents $\{e_i\}_{i=1}^n$. That is, $e_i e_j = Î´ _{i,j} e_i$ and each $e_i R e_i$ is local;
  3. $R â‰ƒ \mathrm{End}(â¨ M_âˆ™ )$ for $â¨ M_âˆ™$ is a finite direct sum of endolocal modules.

(1 â†’ 2). When $R$ is semi-perfect, then $R / J(R) â‰ƒ âˆ M_{n}(D)$ by Wedderburn-Artin theorem. It is clear to find a complete set of primitive orthogonal idempotents $\{e_i'\}_{i=1}^n âŠ† R / J(R)$ which lifts to $\{e_i\}_{i=1}^n âŠ† R$.

  1. If $n = 1$, then $R â‰ƒ \mathrm{End}(R)$ is local. We complete the proof.
  2. We show $n$ from $n - 1$. Let $e$ be any lifting of $e_1'$. By induction, there is $\{(1-e)e_i(1-e)\}_{i=2}^2 âŠ† (1-e)R(1-e)$ primitive orthogonal which lifts $(1-e_1')e_i'(1-e_1') = e_i$. We define $e_1 := (1-âˆ‘ _{i=2}^n e_i)$ serving as a lifting of $e_1'$. Clearly, each $\frac{\mathrm{End}(e_i R)}{J(\mathrm{End}(e_i R))}$ is a division ring (= diagonal entries of each $M_n(D)$).

(2 â†’ 3). Take $M_i := e_i R$.
(3 â†’ 1). We arrange $M_âˆ™$â€™s by isomorphism classes. By fitting lemma, $\frac{\mathrm{End}(â¨ M_âˆ™ )}{J(\mathrm{End}(â¨ M_âˆ™ ))} â‰ƒ âˆ M_{n_i} (\frac{\mathrm{End}(M_i)}{J(\mathrm{End}(M_i))})$, where $n_i$ is the multiplicity of the isomorphism class of $M_i$. Hence $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ is semi-simple. This also determined a finite complete set of orthogonal idempotents in $R / J(R)$. The lifting property of idempotents follows from the finite exchangable property of $â¨ M_âˆ™$.

The final definition shows $\mathrm{End}(M)$ is semi-perfect, when there is $M' = â¨ \text{endolocal}$ s.t. $\mathrm{End}(M) â‰ƒ \mathrm{End}(M)$. Indeed,

$\mathrm{End}(M)$ is semi-perfect iff $M$ is a finite direct sum of endolocal modules.

(â†’). Clear. (â†). Corollary of KSRA.

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{Semi-perfect = End (â¨ finite endolocal modules)!}} \end{equation}$$

There is another simple definition for commutative case.

Commutative semi-perfect rings are precisely finite products of commutative local rings.

(â†). Clear. (â†’). Conversely, $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ is a product to fields. The lifting property shows $R â‰ƒ âˆ R_i$ where each $R_i$ is local.

Note that an Artinian ring has radical lifting property. Hence, commutative Artinian rings are precisely finite products of commutative local Artinian rings.

Being semi-perfect if Morita invariant.

Note that semi-simple rings are precisely $\mathrm{End}(â¨ _{\text{finite}} \ \text{endolocal modules})$.

Transfinite Nilpotent Ideals

The concept of transfinite nilpotent ideals has to do with a kind of compactness characterised by Nakayama lemma.

(Transfinite nilpotent). The following are equivalent for an right ideal $I$ to be transfinite nilpotent:

  1. for any sequence $(r_i)_{i âˆˆ â„•} âŠ† I$, there is some $n$ s.t. $r_n x_{n-1} \cdots r_1 r_0 = 0$;
  2. for any non-zero left module $X$, there is some non-zero $x âˆˆ X âˆ– \{0\}$ s.t. $Ix = 0$;
  3. for any non-zero left module $M$, there is a transfinite sequence of submodules satisfies
    • $X_0 = 0$, $X_{k+1} âŠ† I X_{k}$ for any $k$;
    • $X_Î³ âŠ† â‹ƒ _{< Î³ } X_âˆ™$ for limit ordinal $Î³$;
    • $â‹ƒ X_âˆ™ = X$.
  4. there is a transfinite sequence of left ideals satisfies
    • $R_0 = 0$, $R_{k+1} âŠ† I R_{k}$ for any $k$;
    • $R_Î³ âŠ† â‹ƒ _{< Î³ } R_âˆ™$ for limit ordinal $Î³$;
    • $â‹ƒ R_âˆ™ = R$.

Transfinite Nilpotent Ideal (II)

We conclude a sufficient condition for $J(R)$ to be transfinite nilpotent.

$J(R)$ is right transfinite nilpotent

  • if every non-zero right module has a maximal submodule;
  • if every non-zero left module has a minimal submodule.

If any right module $M (â‰  0)$ has a maximal submodule, then $MJ âŠ† J(M) âŠŠ M$. Hence $J$ is transfinite nilpotent. The converse is not true (see following example).
If left module $X (â‰  0)$ has a minimal submodule $X_0$, then $X_0$ is simple. Note that $J$ contains the annihilator of any simple module. Hence $J X_0 = 0$. Hence, $J$ is transfinite nilpotent. Conversely, $â„¤$ over $â„¤$ is a non-example.

Now we use projective covers to characterise semi-perfect and right perfect rings.

The following are equivalent for a ring $R$:

We show anaglously the characterisation of right perfect rings.

The following are equivalent for a ring $R$:

(3 â†’ 4). Note that flat module with a projective cover is projective.
(4 â†’ 5). Clear.
(5 â†’ 6). We construct countably preserted flat module $F$ for any descending chain of principal left ideals. Such chain stabilises as $F$ is projective.
(6 â†’ 1). $\frac{R}{J(R)}$ satisfies descending chain condition of principal left ideals, hence semi-simple. We show $J(R)$ is transfinite nilpotent.
For any decsending principal left ideal $\{(r_n \cdots r_0)\}_{n âˆˆ â„•}$ with each $r_âˆ™ âˆˆ J$, there is $r_{n+1}$ s.t. $(r_n \cdots r_0) = (r_{n+1} \cdots r_0)$. We take $a$ s.t. $r_n \cdots r_0 = ar_{n+1} r_n \cdots r_0$. Note that $(1- ar_{n+1})$ is a unit, we see $r_n \cdots r_0 = 0$.

Coherency and Chase Theorem

The theorem shows when projective modules are closed under $âˆ$.

The following are equivalent for a ring $R$:

  1. $R$ is right perfect and left coherent;
  2. any product of projective left modules is projective;
  3. $âˆ _I R$ is projective for any set $I$.

(1 â†’ 2). Over a right perfect ring, any flat right modules are projective. Over a left coherent ring, any product of flat right modules is flat. Hence, any product of projective left modules is projective.
(2 â†’ 3). Clear.
(3 â†’ 1). The product of free right modules is flat iff the ring is left coherent.

Def via Bassâ€™ Chain Condition

DG Algebras and Categories

Abstract

We discuss DG algebras, DG-projective and injective modules.

DG Algebra

Throughout, $k$ is a commutative unital ring, all complexes are cochain complexes ($\cdots â†’ X^n \xrightarrow{d_X^n} X^{n+1} â†’ 0$). $C(R)$ is the category of chain complexes over right modules $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$. DG for differential graded.

Basics

DG Algebras

We assume the readers are familiar with bicomplexes and the closed monoidal structure $(C(A), A, âŠ—, \mathcal{HOM})$, where $A âˆˆ ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k$. We denote

  • $X âŠ— Y$ as the $âˆ$-total complex of the bicomplex $(p,q) â†¦ X^p âŠ— Y^q$;
  • $\mathcal{HOM}(X,Y)$ as $âˆ$-total complex of the bicomplex $(p,q) â†¦ (X^{-p},Y^q)$.

(DG algebra). Say $(A, d)$ is a DG algebra, provided

  1. $(A, d)$ is a chain complex over $k$;
  2. $âˆ _{n âˆˆ â„¤} A^n$ is a unital ring with such that $A^m A^n âŠ† A^{m+n}$;
  3. for homogeneous $a$, $d(ab) = d(a)b + (-1)^{|a|} a d(b)$.

We denote $ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k$ as the category of DG $k$-algebra.

Show the following simple corollaries:

  1. $1 âˆˆ A^0$, and $d(1) = 0$;
  2. the multiplication is a chain map $A âŠ— A â†’ A$.

We denote $A = (A,d)$ ($A = âˆ_{n âˆˆ â„¤ } A^n$) as the underlying chain complex (graded algebra).

There is an inclusion: $ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k â†ª ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k$, where $A$ maps to $\cdots â†’ 0 â†’ A â†’ 0 â†’ \cdots$. The forgotful functor $ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k â†’ ğ†ğ«ğ€ğ¥ğ $ (almost) has no adjunctions. The real forgotful functor is $ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ _k â†’ ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k, \quad A â†¦ A^0$, where the left adjoint is the following construction due to Cuntzâ€“Quillen (ref):

$$\begin{equation} ğ€ğ¥ğ _k â†’ ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ _k,\quad A â†¦ A âŠ• âˆ \limits_{k â‰¥ 1} Î©^1(A)^{âŠ— k}. \end{equation}$$

Here $Î© ^1 (A) = \ker \begin{bmatrix}A âŠ— A & â†’ & A\\ a âŠ— b & â†¦ & [a,b]\end{bmatrix} â‰ƒ A/k$ is the universal derivation. HKR shows that $HH_n(A) â‰ƒ Î©^n_{A/k}$ for smooth commutative $A/k$. In this case, the differential of $Î© ^âˆ™ (A)$ coincides bar resolution.

$Z^âˆ™ A â†ª A$ is an dg subalgebra, and $B^âˆ™ A â†ª A$ is a two-sided dg ideal. This defined a functor $H^âˆ™ : ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ _k â†’ ğ†ğ«ğ€ğ¥ğ _k$. The recovery is related to $A_âˆ$-algebra.

Let $R âˆˆ ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k$. Set $(-)^âˆ— := (-, k)$, $Î¼ : R âŠ— R â†’ R$ the multiplication. Suppose there are some finiteness condition s.t. $R^âˆ— âŠ— R^âˆ— â‰ƒ (R âŠ— R)^âˆ—$. The morphisms $f_0 : k \xrightarrow 0 T(R^âˆ—)$ and $f_1 : R^âˆ— \xrightarrow {Î¼ ^âˆ— } R^âˆ— âŠ— R^âˆ— â†ª T(R^âˆ— )$ extends to an $k$-endomorphism of tensor algebra, $Ï† : T(R^âˆ— ) â†’ T(R^âˆ— )$.

  1. $T(R^âˆ— )$ is a DG algebra vanishing on negative degrees;
  2. $Ï† : k â†’ 0, \quad R^âˆ— â†’ R^âˆ— âŠ— R^âˆ—$;
  3. Since $Î¼ âˆ˜ (1 âŠ— Î¼ ) = Î¼ âˆ˜ (Î¼ âŠ— 1)$, we see that $Ï† (f âŠ— g) = Ï† (f) âŠ— g - f âŠ— Ï† (g)$;
  4. Inductively, $Ï† (Î± âŠ— Î²) = Ï† (Î± ) âŠ— Î² + (-1)^{|Î±|} Î± âŠ— Ï† (Î² )$ for homogeneous $Î± âˆˆ T(R^âˆ— )$.

To conclude, derivative comes from dual multiplications.

DG Modules

Let $A$ be a DG algebra. We denote $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ as the category of DG modules.

(DG module). $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ is a chain complex of $A$-modules, such that

  1. $M^p A^q âŠ† M^{p+q}$;
  2. $d_M (ma) = (d_M m)a + (-1)^{|m|} m (d_Aa)$.

A functorial definition is based on DG categories.

(DG homomorphism). A homomorphism between DG modules $Ï† : M â†’ N$ is preserved gradings and differentials, i.e.,

  1. $Ï† : M^k â†’ N^k$ for arbitrary $k$;
  2. $Ï† âˆ˜ d_M = d_N âˆ˜ Ï†$.

This is anagolous to the definition of chain maps.

$C(R)$ is the category of DG $[\cdots â†’ 0 â†’ R â†’ 0 â†’ \cdots ]$-modules. A homomorphism of DG modules is precisely the chain maps.

To see functorial property of DG modules, we consider the following adjunctions.

Let $ğ†ğ«ğŒğ¨ğ _A$ denote the category of $A (âˆˆ ğ†ğ«ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k)$-modules. Then the forgetful functor $G: ğƒğ†ğŒğ¨ğ_k â†’ ğ†ğ«ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k$ admits bi-adjoints. Moreover, $G$ creates all small limits and colimits.

We show the left adjoint $F âŠ£ G$, the right adjoint $G âŠ£ H$ is dual.



The $1:1$ correspondence is clear, as a morphism of DG modules $F(X) â†’ (M,d)$ takes the form $f^âˆ™ (1,d)$. Moreover, $f$ preserves graded action iff $fâˆ˜ (1,d)$ does. This proves the adjunction.
The bi-adjoint $G$ preserves all small limits and colimits. To see that $G$ creates small limits and colimits, we show $\varinjlim$ and $\varprojlim$ in $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ admits a termwise computation. Let $\{M_Î»\} âŠ† ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ be an inverse system, we show $\varprojlim M_Î»$ is the limit. The derivation in $\varprojlim M_Î»$ is induced by universal property of limits. For Any cone $N â†’ M_Î»$, there is a unique morphism of graded modules $â„“ : N â†’ \varprojlim M_Î»$. Since for each $Î»$,

$$\begin{equation} d_{M_Î»} âˆ˜ p_Î» ^n âˆ˜ â„“ ^n = (p_Î» ^{n+1} âˆ˜ â„“ ^{n+1}) \circ d_{N}. \end{equation}$$

By universal property of limit, $d_{\varprojlim M_Î» } âˆ˜ â„“ ^n = â„“ ^{n+1} âˆ˜ d_N$.



To conclude,

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{The limits and colimits of DG modules are computed termwise!} } \end{equation}$$

Show the auto-equivalentce $Î£ : ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)} â†’ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$, where

$$\begin{equation} [\cdots â†’ \overset{\substack {\deg = n \\ â†“} } {M^n} \xrightarrow d M^{n+1} â†’ \cdots ] â†¦ [\cdots â†’ \overset{\substack {\deg = n \\ â†“} } {M^{n+1}} \xrightarrow {-d} M^{n+2} â†’ \cdots ]. \end{equation}$$

Hint: show that $Î£ f$ is a plain shift without sign change, and the middle square commutes:



Opposite Algebra

We show firstly the symmetry.

(Opposite ring). $A^{\mathrm{op}}$ and $A$ has the same underlying chain complex, but the multiplication is twisted by a sign: for homogeneous $a,b âˆˆ A$,

$$\begin{equation} a â‹…^{\mathrm{op}} b := (-1)^{|a||b|} ba. \end{equation}$$

Suppose $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$, while $a âˆˆ A$ and $m âˆˆ M$ are homogeneous. Let $a â‹… ^{\mathrm{op}} m := (-1)^{|m||a|} ma$ be the left action. Show basic results of $^{\mathrm{op}}$:

  1. $(a â‹… ^{\mathrm{op}} b) â‹…^{\mathrm{op}} m = a â‹… ^{\mathrm{op}} (b â‹…^{\mathrm{op}} m)$;
  2. $Ï† : ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)} â‰ƒ {}_{(A, d)}ğŒğ¨ğ$ is an equivalence of categories;
  3. $Î£ Ï† â‰ƒ Ï† Î£$ is a natural isomorphism.

Tensor and Hom

($âŠ—_A$). Let $M_A, {}_AN âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$. The tensor product $M âŠ— _k N$ has $n$-th term $âˆ _{p+q = n} M^p âŠ— N^q$ and differential $d_M âŠ— 1_N + 1_M âŠ— d_N$.

The above tensor product complex satisfies the universal property of tensor products, i.e., for any $X âˆˆ C(k)$, the balanced DG morphism $f : M âŠ— _k N â†’ X$ identifies a chain map $M âŠ— _A N â†’ X$. A balanced DG morphism $f$ satisfies

  1. $f (x a âŠ— y) = f (x âŠ— ay)$ for all $a$, $x$ and $y$;
  2. $f(d_{M âŠ— _k N} (x âŠ— y)) = d_X (f(x âŠ— y))$.

By closed monoidal structure of $C(k)$, $M âŠ— N$ is well-defined. We claim the exact sequence

$$\begin{equation} M âŠ— A âŠ— N \overset Ï† â†’ M âŠ—_k N â†’ M âŠ— _A N â†’ 0;\quad Ï† (m âŠ— a âŠ— n) = ma âŠ— n - m âŠ— an. \end{equation}$$

Unwinding the second condition (differential), we see from definition that

$$\begin{equation} (M âŠ— _k N, X)_{\text{balanced, graded}} = \ker [(M âŠ—_k A âŠ—_k N, X) \overset {Ï† }â†’ (M âŠ— _k N, X)]. \end{equation}$$

It remains to show that $Ï†$ preserves $d$. Then $M âŠ— _k N â†  M âŠ— N$ also preserves $d$, and $\widetilde f : M âŠ— _A N â†’ X$ preserves $d$ by tracking back the preimage.

$$\begin{aligned} d(m âŠ— a âŠ— n) & = (dm) âŠ— a âŠ— n + (-1)^{|m|} m âŠ— (da) âŠ— n + (-1)^{|m| + |a|} m âŠ— a âŠ— (dn) \\ & \xrightarrow Ï† (d m)a âŠ— n - (dm) âŠ— an + (-1)^{|m|} m da âŠ— n - (-1)^{|m|} m âŠ— (da)n\\ & \qquad + (-1)^{|m| + |a|} ma âŠ— dn - (-1)^{|m| + |a|} m âŠ— a(dn) \\ & = d(ma) âŠ— n + (-1)^{|m| + |a|} ma âŠ— dn - (dm) âŠ— an - (-1)^{|m|} m âŠ— d(an)\\ & = d (ma âŠ— n - m âŠ— an) = d (Ï† (m âŠ— a âŠ— n)). \end{aligned}$$

We show the right adjoint of $- âŠ— _A N_B : ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)} â†’ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(B,d)}$. Combined with tensor-hom adjunction for chain complexes, it suffices to show $\mathcal{HOM}(-, ?)$ is a bifunctor for DG modules.

$\mathcal{HOM} (_AN_B, -) : ğŒğ¨ğ _{(B,d)} â†’ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ is a functor.

We define the right action as $(f âˆ— a)(n) = f(an)$.

$$\begin{aligned} (d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(f âˆ— a) )(n) &= d (f âˆ— a) (n) - (-1)^{|f| + |a|} (f âˆ— a)(dn) \\ &= d (f(an)) - (-1)^{|f| + |a|} f (a (dn)) \\ &= d (f(an)) - (-1)^{|f|} f(d(an) - (da)n) \\ &= (d_{\mathcal{HOM}} f)(an) + (-1)^{|f|} f((da)n)\\ &= (d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(f) âˆ— a + (-1)^{|f|} f âˆ— (da))(n). \end{aligned}$$

Hence, $d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(f âˆ— a) = d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(f) âˆ— a + (-1)^{|f|} f âˆ— (da)$.

Endomorphism Algebra

Let $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$. The endomorphism algebra $\mathrm{End} _A (M)$ is defined as the DG algebra $\mathcal{HOM} _A (M,M)$, which is a DG algebra with multiplication given by composition of morphisms.

The endomorphism algebra $E:= \mathrm{End} _A (M) âˆˆ ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k$, where $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(E,d_{\mathcal{HOM}})^{\mathrm{op}}}$.

Clearly $E âˆˆ C(k)$, and $\deg 1_E = 0$. The multiplication if given by composition of morphisms. Hence $E^p E^q âŠ† E^{p+q}$. For homogeneous $f$,

$$\begin{aligned} d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(gf) & = gfd - (-1)^{|g|+|f|}dfg \\ & = gfd - (-1)^{|f|}gdf + (-1)^{|f|} gdf - (-1)^{|g| + |f|}dgf\\ & = d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(g)f + (-1)^{|g|} g d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(f). \end{aligned}$$

By definition, $Î¸ : E âŠ— M â†’ M, \quad f âŠ— m â†¦ f(m)$ maps $E^p âŠ— M^q$ to $M^{p+q}$. To show such it is compatible with $d$, we take homogeneous $f âˆˆ E^p$ and $m âˆˆ M^q$,

$$\begin{aligned} d_{E âŠ— M} (f âŠ— m) & = d_E(f) âŠ— m + (-1)^{|f|} f âŠ— d_M(m) \\ & \xrightarrow Î¸ d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(f)m + (-1)^{|f|}fd_M(m) \\ & = d_M (fm) - (-1)^{|f|} f (d_M m) + (-1)^{|f|}fd_M(m) \\ & = d_M(fm)\quad = f_M ( Î¸ (f âŠ— m) ). \end{aligned}$$

The Homotopy Category $K$

Frobenius Category

We define an exact category by dws (degreewise split) ses.

Say an ses in $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ dws, if it is isomorphic to

$$\begin{equation} 0 â†’ K \xrightarrow {\binom 10} M \xrightarrow {\binom 01} N â†’ 0. \end{equation}$$

In this case, $M = \mathrm{Cone}(s)$ for some $s : N â†’ Î£ K$.

$(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}, \text{dws})$ is a forbenius exact category.

Inflations (deflations) are precisely dws monomorphisms (epimorphisms).

  1. (EX0). Trivial ses are dws.
  2. (EX1, EX1â€™). Inflations and deflations are closed under compositions.
  3. (EX2, EX2â€™). Split monomorphisms (epimorphisms) are closed under pushout (pullback).
    • Recall that the forgetful functor $G: ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)} â†’ ğ†ğ«ğŒğ¨ğ _A$ creates all limits and colimits, pullbacks and pushouts in $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ are computated degreewise.

We show enough projective and injectives. Recall the adjoint $âˆ$-ple $\cdots âŠ£ F âŠ£ G âŠ£ H âŠ£ \cdots$, as a direct computation shows $F â‰ƒ Î£ H$. We claim that $\operatorname{im}F = \operatorname{im}H$ are precisely projectives and injectives.

  • $FX$ lifts dws epimorphism $p$, since $X$ lifts split epimorphism $Gp$. By the same analysis, $HX$ lifts dws monomorphisms.
  • If $P$ is projective, then $FGP â†  P$ splits. It suffices to show that $\operatorname{im} F$ is closed under summands. For $N âŠ• N' = FX$, we see $F\mathrm{coim}(N) âŠ• F\mathrm{coim}(N') = F\mathrm{coim}(FX) â‰ƒ FX$. By functoriality of $? â†¦ F\mathrm{coim}(?)$, $N â‰ƒ F\mathrm{coim}(N)$.
  • There are enough projectives, which coincides injectives.

The stable category of $(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}, \text{dws})$ is trianglated.

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{Two definition of homotopy category coincides!}} \end{equation}$$

Homotopy

(Mapping cone). Let $f : X â†’ Y$ be a morphism of DG modules. The mapping cone $\mathrm{Cone}(f)$ is defined as the DG module



Given morphisms of DG modules $f,g: M â†’ N$. Say $s : f âˆ¼ g$ is a homotopy, provided there is a morphism $s : M â†’ Î£ N$ in $ğ†ğ«ğŒğ¨ğ _A$, such that $f - g = d_N s + s d_M$.

Show that the homotopy relation $âˆ¼$ is a categorical equivalence. This gives $K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$.

We say an equality holds in $K$, whenever $(ğ‹ğ’ğ‡ - ğ‘ğ‡ğ’) âˆ¼ 0$.

The stable category $(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}, \text{dws}) / \operatorname{im} F$ is canonically isomorphic to $K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$.

Let $Q_1$ and $Q_2$ be quotient functors. We show there are induced $Î±$ and $Î²$ s.t. $Î± âˆ˜ Q_1 = Q_2$ and $Î² âˆ˜ Q_2 = Q_1$. Therefore $Î± âˆ˜ Î²$ and $Î² âˆ˜ Î±$ are identical.



($Î±$). When $s : f âˆ¼ 0$, we consider the 1:1 correspondence

$$\begin{equation} (s,f) âˆˆ \{s: f âˆ¼ 0 : X â†’ Y \} â‰ƒ \mathrm{Hom}(\mathrm{Cone}(1_X), Y) âˆ‹ (s \ f). \end{equation}$$

Here $(s \ f)$ is a chain map iff $(s \ f) â‹… \binom{-d \ \ 0}{\ 1 \ \ \ d} = d â‹… (s \ f)$, that is, $f = sd+ds$.
($Î²$). $\operatorname{im}F$ are null homotopic.

Triangles

We unify $(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}, \text{dws}) / \operatorname{im} F â‰… K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$. Then we find distinduished triangles.

(Shift). $Î£$ is the auto-equivalence of triangulated category $K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$.

Consider the dws ses $0 â†’ X \xrightarrow {\binom 10} HGX \xrightarrow {(0 \ 1)} Î£X â†’ 0$, where $HGX$ is injective.

(Suspension). Consider the following cone sequence

$$\begin{equation} X \xrightarrow f Y \xrightarrow {\binom 01} \mathrm{Cone}(f)\xrightarrow {\binom 01} \mathrm{Cone}\left(\substack {1\\0}\right). \end{equation}$$

Then $e_2 : Î£ X â†’ \mathrm{Cone}(\binom 01)$ is an isomorphism in $K$.

Note that $\mathrm{Cone}(\binom 01)$ is a chain complex



Now we show the following chain maps are homotopy inverses:

$$\begin{equation} \left(\substack{-f\\1\\0}\right) :\quad \mathrm{Cone}\left(\substack {1\\0}\right) â‡† Î£ X \quad : (0 \ 1 \ 0). \end{equation}$$

It suffices to show $1 - \left(\substack{-f\\1\\0}\right) â‹… (0 \ 1 \ 0)$ is null-homotopic. Consider

$$\begin{equation} \begin{pmatrix}1&f&0\\0&0&0\\0&0&1\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}-d&0&0\\0&-d&0\\1&f&d\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}0&0&1\\0&0&0\\0&0&0\end{pmatrix}+\begin{pmatrix}0&0&1\\0&0&0\\0&0&0\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}-d&0&0\\0&-d&0\\1&f&d\end{pmatrix}. \end{equation}$$

$X \xrightarrow f Y \xrightarrow {\binom 01} \mathrm{Cone}(f) \xrightarrow {(1 \ 0)} Î£ X$ is a distinguished triangle in $K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$.

By homotopy equivalence, the following diagram commutes in $K$:



By construction, every dws ses is a distinguished triangle. Hence $(\text{c234},\text{r1})$ and $(\text{c345},\text{r1})$ are parts of some distinguished triangles. By homotopy equivalence, $(\text{c2345},\text{r2})$ is a dintinguished triangle. By suspension, $(\text{c1234}, \text{r1})$ is a distinguished triangle.

Show that for any morphism $f$, there is some homotopy equivalences $g_âˆ™$ s.t. $g_1 âˆ˜ f âˆ˜ g_2$ is dws monic and $g_3 âˆ˜ f âˆ˜ g_4$ is dws epic.

Resolutions

The projectives and injectives in this section has nothing to do with the Forbenius exact category $(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}, \text{dws})$.

Projective and Injective Modules

For convention, projective chain complexes are defined as the degreewise projective ones; rather than the projective objects in $C$.

(Projective/Free (DG) module). $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ is projective/free, iff $GM âˆˆ ğ†ğ«ğŒğ¨ğ _A$ is a projective/free object.

There exist enough projective modules. Projective modules are precisely direct summands of coproducts of several $Î£^n A$ for $n âˆˆ â„¤$.

Note that the forgotful functor $ğ”˜ : ğ†ğ«ğŒğ¨ğ _A â†’ ğ†ğ«ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$ admits a free functor sending

$$\begin{equation} ğ”‰: ğ†ğ«ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ â†’ ğ†ğ«ğŒğ¨ğ _A, \quad â¨† \limits_{n âˆˆ â„¤ } S^n â†¦ âˆ\limits _{n âˆˆ â„¤ } Î£^n âˆ\limits _{S^n}A. \end{equation}$$

On one hand, $ğ”‰ğ”˜ X$ is projective. Recall that $ğ”˜$ preserves epimorphisms. Since $(ğ”˜ X, -)_{ğ†ğ«ğ’ğğ­ğ¬}$ lifts epimorphisms, and so is $(ğ”˜ X, ğ”˜ (-))_{ğ†ğ«ğ’ğğ­ğ¬} â‰ƒ (ğ”‰ ğ”˜ X, -)_{ğ†ğ«ğŒğ¨ğ _A}$. If $X$ is projective, then $ğ”‰ ğ”˜ X â†  X$ is is dws epic. Hence, projective modules are summands of $\operatorname{im} ğ”‰$.

The following lemma shows there are enough free modules.

$f : ğ”‰ S â†’ M$ is epic if $\widetilde f : S â†’ ğ”˜ M$ is epic.

If $[ğ”‰ S \xrightarrow f M \xrightarrow g N] = 0$, then $[S \xrightarrow {\widetilde f} ğ”˜ M \xrightarrow {ğ”˜ g} ğ”˜ N] = 0$. Since $\widetilde f$ is epic, we find $ğ”˜ g$ is epic. Hence, $g$ is epic.

Show anagolously that projective objects in $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ are precisely summands of $\operatorname{im} F ğ”‰$.

We introduce injective modules by character modules.

(Character module). We denote $(M, T) := \mathcal{HOM}(M,T)$ when $T = T^0$. The character module of $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ is defined as follows:

$$\begin{equation} M^+ := (M, â„š / â„¤ )_{C(â„¤)} âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)^{\mathrm{op}}}. \end{equation}$$

Note that $Î£ (M^+) = (Î£^{-1} M)^+$.

We introduce some lemma before showing the structure of injective modules.

Assume $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ is a free module, then $M^+ âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)^{\mathrm{op}}}$ is an injective module.

Recall that $(-^{\mathrm{op}})^+ : (ğŒğ¨ğ _R)^{\mathrm{op}} â†’ ğŒğ¨ğ _{R^{\mathrm{op}}}$ preserves and reflect the exactness, monomorphisms and epimorphisms. By degreewise analysis, so is $(-^{\mathrm{op}})^+ : (ğŒğ¨ğ_{(A,d)})^{\mathrm{op}} â†’ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)^{\mathrm{op}}}$. For any monomorphism $i$, we consider

Flat Modules

We state the definition of injective, projective and flat modules in a uniform way.

Say a DG module $M$ is

  1. DG-injective, provided $((-)^{\mathrm{op}}, M)$ preserves epic quasi-isomorphisms;
  2. DG-projective, provided $(M, -)$ preserves epic quasi-isomorphisms;
  3. DG-flat, provided $M âŠ— -$ preserves monic quasi-isomorphisms.

Show the following basic properties:

  1. DG-injective/DG-projective/DG-flat modules are closed under extensions, summands, and (de)suspensions.
  2. DG-projective/DG-flat modules are closed under $âˆ$ and $âŠ—$.
  3. DG-flat modules are closed under filtered colimits.
  4. DG-injective modules are closed under products.
  5. $M$ is DG-flat iff $M^+$ is DG-injective.

We seldomly use the definition of flat resolutions, due to the following considerations.

A quasi-isomorphism between DG-projective/DG-injective modules is homotopy equivalence; a quasi-isomorphism between DG-flat modules might not be a homotopy equivalence.

We show DG-projective case. Let $Ï† : P â†’ Q$ be a quasi-isomorphism between DG-projective modules. Since $(Q, -)_K$ preserves quasi-isomorphisms, we find a right inverse of $Ï†$ in the homotopy category. The left inverse of $Ï†$ exists by applying $(-, P)_K$. Hence $Ï†$ is a homotopy equivalence. The injective case is similar. A non-example of flat case is

$$\begin{equation} [\cdots â†’ 0 â†’ â„¤ â†’ â„š â†’ 0 \cdots \cdots] â†  [\cdots â†’ 0 â†’ 0 â†’ â„š / â„¤ â†’ 0 â†’ \cdots ]. \end{equation}$$

When $Ï†$ is a quasi-isomorphism between flat modules, then $Ï† ^+$ is a homotopy equivalence.

We follow Verdierâ€™s localisation of triangulated categories. Let $S$ denote the class of quasi-isomorphisms in $K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$.

$S$ is a saturated multiplicative system. $S^{-1} K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$ is the Verdier quotient $K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}) / K_{ac}$, where $K_{ac}$ the thick subcategory consists of acyclic complexes.

Enriched Category

Let $\mathcal{V}$ be a monoidal category (e.g. the sets $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$, the graded sets $ğ†ğ«ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$, pointed sets $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬_+$, modules over commutative rings $ğŒğ¨ğ _k$, chain complexes over commutative rings $C(k)$, the derived category of chain complexes $D(k)$, etc).

($\mathcal{V}$-enrichend). A category $\mathcal{C}$ is $\mathcal{V}$-enriched, provided for any $X,Y âˆˆ \mathcal{C}$, the set of morphisms $\mathrm{Hom}_\mathcal{C}(X,Y)$ is an object in $\mathcal{V}$. The composition of morphisms is a morphism in $\mathcal{V}$.

In some context, a monoidal category is assume to be $ğ”˜$-small for some universe $ğ”˜$. Here we view $\mathcal{V} = â‹ƒ \mathcal{V}^{â‰¤ Îº}$ as our category is concrete enough.

The $ğ€ğ›$-enriched category is preadditive, rather than additive. For instance, every ring is $ğ€ğ›$-enriched.

(Closed monoidal almost implies self-enriched). $ğ’ğğ­$ is $ğ’ğğ­$-enriched, $ğ’ğğ­ _+$ is $ğ’ğğ­ _+$-enriched, $ğŒğ¨ğ _k$ is $ğŒğ¨ğ _k$-enriched, etc.

Definition

(DG Category $ğƒğ†ğ‚ğšğ­(_k)$). A DG category is a category enriched over $C^{dg}(k)$ s.t.

  • the compositions are morphisms of DG modules.

($\mathcal{FUN}$). Let $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ be DG categories, then $\mathcal{FUN}(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B})$ is a DG category. An object $F âˆˆ \mathcal{FUN}(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B})$ is called a DG functor, if it is compatible with identity and compositions, and the followings are morphisms of DG modules:

$$\begin{equation} F_{X,Y} âˆˆ \mathcal{HOM}_k ((X, Y)_\mathcal{A}, (FX,FY)_\mathcal{B}). \end{equation}$$

For $F,G âˆˆ \mathcal{FUN}(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B})$, we define $\mathcal{HOM}(F,G) âˆˆ C^{dg}(k)$ as the complex of graded morphisms. The differential is computed elementwise in $\mathcal{B}$. Note that $\deg \mathrm{id}_âˆ™ = 0$, and the composition is a morphism of DG modules.

The only requirement for $Î± âˆˆ \mathcal{HOM}(F,G)$ to be a usual natural transformation is that $Î±$ preserves differentials. Hence, $Z^0 (\mathcal{FUN})$ is a category of DG functors along with usual natural transformations.
