  • $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg}$ as the category of DG modules whose morphisms are in $\mathcal{HOM}$.

Note that $Z^0 (-, ?)_{ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg}} = (-, ?)_{ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}}$.

Let $A âˆˆ ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k$. Then $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg}$ is a DG category.

The category $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg}$ is $C^{dg}(k)$-enriched. We show that $d_{\mathcal{HOM}}$ is compatible with the definition of DG categories. Clearly $d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(1_X) = 0$. The composition is a morphism of DG modules, since

$$\begin{aligned} & \ \ \quad d_{\mathcal{HOM}(\text{composition} (f âŠ— g))}\\ & = d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(f âˆ˜ g)\\ & = dfg - (-1)^{|f| + |g|} fgd\\ & = dfg - (-1)^{|f|} fdg + (-1)^{|f|} fdg - (-1)^{|f| + |g|} fgd\\ & = d_{\mathcal{HOM}}(f)g + (-1)^{|f|} fd_{\mathcal{HOM}}(g)\\ & = \text{composition} (d_{âŠ—} (f âŠ— g)) \end{aligned}$$

Hence, $C^{dg}(k)$ is a DG category. $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg}$ is indeed a Hom object in $ğƒğ†ğ‚ğšğ­_k$. Recall that

$$\begin{equation} ğŒğ¨ğ _R â‰ƒ (R^{\mathrm{op}}, ğŒğ¨ğ _k)_{ğ‚ğšğ­_k},\quad R âˆˆ ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k. \end{equation}$$

  • Here $â‹ƒ_Îº ğŒğ¨ğ^Îº _R â‰ƒ â‹ƒ _Î» (R^{\mathrm{op}}, ğŒğ¨ğ^Î» _k)_{ğ‚ğšğ­_k}$ is the actual expression. We omit the set-theoretic issues.

We show anagolous corollaries for DG algebras and DG modules.

For $A âˆˆ ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k â†ª ğƒğ†ğ‚ğšğ­ _k$, one has the equivalence

$$\begin{equation} \mathcal{FUN}(A^{\mathrm{op}}, C^{dg}(k)) â‰ƒ ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg}. \end{equation}$$

Let $ğ–®ğ–» (A)= \{âˆ— \}$. Any DG functor $F$ determined an underlying chain complex $F(âˆ— ) âˆˆ C^{dg}(k)$ and a morphism of DG algebras:

$$\begin{equation} A â†’ \mathcal{HOM}(F(âˆ—), F(âˆ—)). \end{equation}$$

This shows that $F(âˆ—)$ is a DG module. Conversely, any DG module $M$ corresponds to a homomorphism $A â†’ \mathcal{HOM}(M,M)$, which determined a DG functor from a singleton.
We show assignment is a functor. An $n$-natural transformation $Î± : F â†’ G$ corresponds to $Î± _âˆ— âˆˆ \mathcal{HOM}^n(F(âˆ— ), G(âˆ— ))$ with $$\begin{equation} Î± _âˆ— âˆ˜ F(r ) = G(r ) âˆ˜ Î± _âˆ—,\quad âˆ€ r âˆˆ A. \end{equation}$$

This shows that $Î± _âˆ— : F(âˆ— ) â†’ G(âˆ— )$ is an $n$-morphism of DG modules.
We already show the functor is essentially surjective. It remains to show the fully-faithful property. To see it is full, we take any $Ï† âˆˆ \mathcal{HOM}(F(âˆ— ), G(âˆ— ))$. This determined a natural transformation as $Ï†$ preserves $A$-action. To see it is faithful, we take any $Î± : F â†’ G$ s.t. $Î± _âˆ— = 0$. Then $Î± = 0$.

We show the base change.

For morphism of DG algebras $Ï† : A â†’ B$, we have the base change functor

$$\begin{equation} \mathcal{FUN}(A^{\mathrm{op}}, C^{dg}(k)) â†’ \mathcal{FUN}(B^{\mathrm{op}}, C^{dg}(k)),\quad F â†¦ Ï† ^âˆ— F = F(Ï† (-)). \end{equation}$$

Thanks to the closed monoidal structure, it is a DG functor.

Note that this induce a functor between $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg}$, $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}$ and $K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$.

Show the adjoint triple of base change



Recall that

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{DG modules are DG functors from a certian DG algebra.}} \end{equation}$$

The embedding $ğƒğ†ğ€ğ¥ğ  _k â†ª ğƒğ†ğ‚ğšğ­ _k$ suggests a general definition of DG modules.

(DG module). The category of (right) DG modules over $\mathcal{A}$ is $\mathcal{FUN}(\mathcal{A}^{\mathrm{op}}, C^{dg}(k))$. We use the notion $ğŒğ¨ğ _{\mathcal{A}}^{dg}$.

$ğŒğ¨ğ _{\mathcal{A}}^{dg}$ is bicomplete, and also admits an auto-equivalence $Î£$.

The right action of $\mathcal{A}$ over $F âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{\mathcal{A}}^{dg}$ is given by

$$\begin{equation} F(X) âŠ— (X', X)_\mathcal{A} â†’ F(X'),\quad s âŠ— f â†¦ s âˆ˜ f. \end{equation}$$

By (enirched) Yoneda lemma, one has the embedding

$$\begin{equation} \mathcal{A} â†ª ğŒğ¨ğ _{\mathcal{A}}^{dg},\quad X â†¦ (-, X)_\mathcal{A}. \end{equation}$$

A computation shows that

$$\begin{equation} H^n (FX) \xrightarrow[\text{Yoneda}] âˆ¼ H^n(\mathcal{HOM}((-, X)_\mathcal{A}, F)) â‰ƒ ((-, X)_\mathcal{A}, Î£^nF)_K. \end{equation}$$

The bi-modules correspond to bi-functors.

(Bi-modules). $\mathcal{A}$-$\mathcal{B}$-bi-module coincides $\mathcal{A}^{\mathrm{op}} âŠ— \mathcal{B}$ modules.

The Homotopy

For a triangulated structure over the homotopy category of $\mathcal{A} âˆˆ ğƒğ†ğ‚ğšğ­ _k$, we assume $\mathcal{A}$ is additive and admits a shift $Î£$ s.t.

$$\begin{equation} (X,Î£ Y) _\mathcal{A} â‰ƒ Î£ (X,Y)_\mathcal{A} â‰ƒ (Î£ ^{-1}X,Y)_\mathcal{A}. \end{equation}$$

$C(\mathcal{A})$, the category of chain complexes over $\mathcal{A}$, admits a Forbenius exact structure. The ses are dws.

The construction of adjoint $âˆ$-ple between $C(\mathcal{A})$ and $\mathcal{A}^{â„¤}$ is still valid. By the same diagram chasing, the forgotful functor created all limits and colimits. The projectives = injectives are exactly the image of free functor $\mathcal{A}^{â„¤} â†’ C(\mathcal{A})$.

The homotopy category admits two definitions

$$\begin{equation} \frac{C(\mathcal{A})} { {\text{homotopy} } } â‰ƒ \frac{(C(\mathcal{A}), \ \text{dws})}{\text{acyclic splits complexes}}. \end{equation}$$

Hence $K(\mathcal{A})$ is triangulated. The distinct triangles are of the form $X \xrightarrow f Y \xrightarrow{\binom 01} \mathrm{Cone}(f) \xrightarrow{(1 \ 0)} Î£ X$.

See $K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)})$.

Derived Module Category

We focus the base change of derived categories and derived equivalences.

Resolutions

The resolutions are discussed over bimodules.

The previous definition of bi-modules (by tensor algebra) coincides our usual definition.

Note that $\mathcal{FUN}(A^{\mathrm{op}} âŠ— B, C^{dg}(k)) â‰ƒ \mathcal{FUN}(A^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathcal{FUN}( B, C^{dg}(k)))$. We show that for any left $B$ modules $_BM$, the compatible $A$-module structure corrsponds to a homomorphism of DG algebras, i.e,

$$\begin{equation} Ï† : A â†’ \mathcal{HOM}_{B^{\mathrm{op}}}(M, M)\quad â†” \quad m.a â†¦ m Ï† (a). \end{equation}$$

The verification is easy. We underscore the signrule

$$\begin{equation} m (a âŠ— b) = (-1)^{|a| + |m|} amb. \end{equation}$$

Now we define derived Hom.

$\mathcal{HOM}(_AM_B, -) : K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(B,d)}^{dg}) â†’ K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg})$ yields a localised functor

$$\begin{equation} ğ‘ \mathcal{HOM}(_AM_B, -) : D(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(B,d)}^{dg}) â†’ D(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg}). \end{equation}$$

Here $ğ‘ \mathcal{HOM}(_AM_B, -) := (Ï(_AM_B), -)_K$, and $Ï((_AM_B)) â†’ M$ is a resolution of bi-modules.

$\mathcal{HOM}(_AM_B, -) : K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(B,d)}^{dg}) â†’ K(ğŒğ¨ğ _{(A,d)}^{dg})$ is triangulated as it preserves cones. A quasi-isomorphism

To be continued.

item.title: CT5
item.description:
• Lecture 5
  • Pure Revisited
    • Example: Tor-torsion Theory
    • Pure World

Lecture 5

Pure Revisited

Example: Tor-torsion Theory

A tor-torsion theory induces a cotorsion theory with good proeprty.

Say $(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B})$ consists of a tor-torsion theory, provided

$$\begin{equation} \mathcal{A}^âŠº := \ker \mathrm{Tor}(\mathcal{A}, -) = \mathcal{B}; \quad {}^âŠº\mathcal{B} := \ker \mathrm{Tor}(-, \mathcal{B}) = \mathcal{A}. \end{equation}$$

Show that both $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ are closed under summands, extensions, and filtered colimits.

  • In general, the left derives of the left adjoint commutes with filtered colimits.

The following lemma embeds the tor-torsion theory into general cotorsion theory.

For any $X âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ and $Y âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{R^{\mathrm{op}}}$, $\mathrm{Ext}^1(X,Y^+) =0$ iff $\mathrm{Tor}_1(X,Y) = 0$.

Note that $(-)^+$ preserves and reflects exactness and zero-objects.

$$\begin{equation} \mathrm{Ext}^1(X, Y^+) = H^1((P(X), Y^+)) â‰ƒ (H^1(P(X) âŠ— Y))^+ = \mathrm{Tor}_1(X, Y)^+. \end{equation}$$

A tor-torsion theory $(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B})$ induces a cotorsion theory $(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{A}^âŸ‚ )$ where $\mathcal{A}$ is closed under filtered limits.

Note that $\mathcal{A} = {}^âŸ‚ (\mathcal{B}^+) = {}^âŠº\mathcal{B}$.

$(ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ , \mathcal{A})$ and $(\mathcal{A}, ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ )$ are tor-torsion theories. Hence $(ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ , ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚ )$ is a cotorsion theory. $ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚$ is known as Enochâ€™s cotorsion module.

$$\begin{equation} \mathcal{A}^+ âŠ† \text{Pure Injective} âŠ† ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚. \end{equation}$$

Note that $ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ = ^âŸ‚ (\mathcal{A}^+) = ^âŸ‚ (\text{Pure Injective}) = ^âŸ‚ (ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚)$.

(Torsion-free module). Recall that

$$\begin{equation} 0 â†’ \mathrm{Tor}_1(X, R/(r)) â†’ X âŠ— (r) â†’ X â†’ X âŠ— R/(r) â†’ 0. \end{equation}$$

If $R$ has no zero-divisor, then $\mathrm{Tor}_1(X, R/(r)) = \{xr = 0 âˆ£ x âˆˆ X\}$ is a subgroup. If $R$ is commutative domain with factional field $K$, then

$$\begin{equation} \mathrm{Tor}_1(X,K/R) = \varinjlim_{r âˆˆ R âˆ– \{0\}} \! \!\! ^{fil} \ \ \mathrm{Tor}(X,R/(r)) = \text{torsion subgrp of } \ X. \end{equation}$$

A torsion-free tor-torsion theory (for general rings) is cogenerated by cyclic modules, i.e.,

$$\begin{equation} ğ“ğ… = {}^âŠº ğ‚ğ²ğœğ¥ğ¢ğœ = {}^âŸ‚ \{(R/(r))^+ : r âˆˆ R\}. \end{equation}$$

Pure World

We revisit some pure-related concepts.

(Pure $\mathrm{Ext}^1$). The pure extension group $\mathrm{Ext}_p^1$ is a well-defined additive subbifunctor of $\mathrm{Ext}^1$.

Firstly split ses are pure. Recall that

  1. pure embeddings are stable under pushout of ses, since the pushout of pure embeddings is pure;
  2. pure embeddings are stable under pullback of ses, since $gf$ is a pure embedding only $f$ is a pure embedding.

Pure ses are closed under sum and summands of ses. Hence the operation of Yoneda groups is well-defined.

(Pure orthogonality). Recall that

  1. $\mathrm{Ext}_p^1(X,-) = \mathrm{Ext}^1(X,-)$ iff $X$ is flat;
    • Flat = filtered colimit of projectives.
  2. $\mathrm{Ext}_p^1(-,Y) = \mathrm{Ext}^1(-,Y)$ iff $Y$ is FP-injective;
    • FP-injective = $(ğ¦ğ¨ğ)^âŸ‚ = ğğ®ğ«ğğ’ğ®ğ› (ğˆğ§ğ£)$.
  3. $\mathrm{Ext}_p^1(X,-) = 0$ iff $X$ is pure projective;
    • Pure projective = $ğ’ğ¦ğ (âˆ (ğ¦ğ¨ğ))$.
  4. $\mathrm{Ext}_p^1(-,Y) = 0$ iff $Y$ is pure injective.
    • Pure injective $âŠ‡ \operatorname{im}((-)^+)$.

Pure-projective cover may not exists.

We show a narrow proof.

  • Lemma: Every pure projective module over a semi-perfect ring has a projective cover. Proof: Note that $ğ¦ğ¨ğ$ has projective covers, and projective covers are stable under summands and coproducts. Hence $ğ’ğ¦ğ (âˆ (ğ¦ğ¨ğ))$ has projective covers.

Assume every module $M$ has a pure-projective cover $Q â†’ M$ over a semiperfect ring. Let $P(Q) â†’ Q$ denote the projective cover, we claim that $P(Q) â†’ M$ is a projective cover.

item.title: CT4
item.description:
• Lecture 4
    • Abstract
  • Definable Subgroups
    • PP Condition
    • PP Lattice
    • Herzogâ€™s Pairing
    • Presentation
    • Purity
    • Examples of Pure ses
  • Pure-Relative Homological Algebra
    • Pure Proj
    • Recollection: ML Conditions
    • ML Module Revisited
    • Pure Injective and Compactness
    • Fp-Injective

Lecture 4

Abstract

We discuss purity and its cotorsion theory. We introduce definable subgroups and pp conditions, as a threshod for purity. We study pure exact sequence, pure projectives (and ML modules), pure injectives (= algebraically compact modules). A general pure-relative homological theory is based on cotorsion pairs which is discussed in the forthcoming lectures.

Definable Subgroups

We refer to Zieglerâ€™s foundational article for model theory of modules. The theory established a equivalence between

  • axiomatisable subcategories (aka definable subcategory) of some $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$, and
  • the category of exact functors $\mathcal{A} â†’ ğ€ğ›$ for $\mathcal{A}$ essentially small.

A typical example: the categry of injective (= divisible Abelian groups) is equivalent to the category of exact functors $\mathrm{Exact}(ğšğ›^{\mathrm{op}}, ğ€ğ›)$.

PP Condition

We explain axiomatisable in positive primitive (pp for short) formula. All modules are right modules for convention, and all vectors are row vectors.

Consider ses of multiplicating $r$:

$$\begin{equation} 0 â†’ \mathrm{ann}_r(M) â†’ M \xrightarrow{Ã— r} Mr â†’ 0. \end{equation}$$

We axiomise

  • $\mathrm{ann}_r(M) = \{x âˆˆ M^1 : x â‹… r = 0\}$;
  • $Mr = \{x âˆˆ M^1 : âˆƒ y âˆˆ M^1 \ (x - y â‹… r = 0)\}$.

(Another definition of f.p. modules). Once we fix the expression $R^m \xrightarrow {â‹… ğ‚ } R^n â†’ M â†’ 0$, then $(M, -)_R$ is a subfunctor of $(R^n, - ) : ğŒğ¨ğ _R â†’ ğ€ğ›$ defined by sending

$$\begin{equation} X â†¦ \{ğ± âˆˆ X^n : ğ± â‹… ğ‚^T = \mathbf 0\}. \end{equation}$$

We may rewrite the conditions as $â‹€_{j=1}^m âˆ‘ _{i =1} ^n c_{j,i} x _i = 0$.

We shall axiomatise such assignments (functors). Recall a structure over the language $\mathcal{L}$ (e.g. $\mathcal{N} = (â„•, 0, ++)$ due to Peano) consists of an underlying set $M$, some chosen constants, together with some operations.

Our language $M_R$ consists of first order logic and right module operations, e.g., $âˆ§$, $Â¬$, $âˆƒ$, $âˆ€$ and $â‹…_R$, $+_R$, $1_R$, $0_R$.

((pp-)definable subgroup). A definable subgroup of $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ given by positive primitive (p.p) formula $Ï†$

$$\begin{equation} Ï† (M) := \{ğ± âˆˆ M^k : M âŠ§ Ï† [ğ± , ğ²]\}, \end{equation}$$

where $Ï†$ takes the form $âˆƒ ğ² \ ((ğ± \ ğ²) â‹… \binom{ğ€}{ - ğ} = \mathbf 0)$, or simply $ğ âˆ£ ğ± ğ€$. The formula consists of $k = |ğ±|$ free variables and $(n-k) = |ğ²|$ bounds.

We write $Ï† [-]$ for a formula, and $Ï† (-)$ for functors.

$Ï†(-)$ is a subfunctor of the forgotful one $(R^n, -)_R : ğŒğ¨ğ _R â†’ ğ€ğ›$.

For morphism of modules, $f : M â†’ N$, we define

$$\begin{equation} Ï† (f) : \{ğ± âˆˆ M^k : ğ âˆ£ ğ± ğ€ \} â†  \{f(ğ±) âˆˆ N^k : ğ âˆ£ ğ± ğ€ \} â†ª \{ğ±' âˆˆ N^k : ğ âˆ£ ğ±' ğ€ \}. \end{equation}$$

We obtain the natural inclusion $Ï† â†ª (R^n,-)$, which shows the functoriality.

We notice that

  1. $Ï†$ preserves monomorphisms: larger underlying set implies larger solution set.
    • For submodule $L â†ª M$, one has $Ï† (L) âŠ† (Ï† (M) âˆ© L)$. The equality does not hold in general (unless $L â†ª M$ is a pure submodule), e.g. $2â„¤ â†ª â„¤$ with condition $Ï† [x , y] := âˆƒ y \ (x = y â‹… 2)$.
  2. $Ï†$ does not preserve epimorphisms, e.g. $Ï† [x , y] := (xâ‹…2 = 0)$ and $â„¤ â†  â„¤ / 2â„¤$.
  3. $Ï†(M)$ is not necessary an $R$-submodule of $M^k$, but instead a $\mathrm{End}(M_R)$-submodule (under diagonal action).

Recall that $M$ is flat iff $ğ¦ â‹… ğ‚ = \mathbf 0$ implies the existence of $ğ€$ s.t. $(A âˆ£ ğ¦) âˆ§ (ğ€ğ‚ = 0)$. Show that $M$ is flat iff $M â‹… Ï• (R) âŠ† Ï• (M)$ holds equality for all pp formula with $1$ free variable.

PP Lattice

We denote $Ï† [ğ±, ğ²]$ by $âˆƒ ğ² \ (ğ± , ğ² )â‹… H = \mathbf 0$, and $H = \binom{A }{-B}$. We use

  • $A$, $B$ and $H$ for matrices in determing pp conditions,
  • $k = |ğ±|$ the number of free variables, $n = |ğ±| + |ğ²|$ the number of total variables.

in the procedding analysis without mentioning.

As how we learn linear algebra, we write $x$ (instead of $ğ±$) for general vectors (row vectors for default).

Before we proceed, we introduce a criterion for $Ï†' â‰¤ Ï†$.

$Ï†' â‰¤ Ï†$ iff there are matrices $X$, $Y$ and $Z$ s.t. $\binom{I \ X}{O \ Y} â‹… H = H' â‹… Z$.

(â† ). Consider

$$\begin{aligned} (x âˆˆ Ï† '(M)) â†” (B' âˆ£ xA') â†’ (B'Z âˆ£ xA'Z) â†” (YB âˆ£ x(A-XB))\\[6pt] â†’ (B âˆ£ x(A-XB)) â†’ (B âˆ£ xA) â†” (x âˆˆ Ï† (M)). \end{aligned}$$

(â†’). We take $Ï†' (M) = \{x : B' âˆ£ xA'\}$ as the projection of the first $k$ coordinates of f.p. module $M: = \{(x,y) : (x,y)\binom{A'}{-B'}=O\} = \operatorname{cok}(A'^T, -B'^T)$. Let $\{z_k\}_{k=1}^n$ denote the image of coordinal basis along $R^n â†  M$ generating set of $M$, which is a generating set of $M$. By definition, $(z_{[1,k]}, z_{(k,n]})\binom{A'}{-B'} = O$. Hence $(z_{[1,k]}, w)\binom{A}{-B} = O$ for some $w$. We write $w = z_{(k,n]}\binom{X}{Y}$ which recovers the construction.

(Lattice). All pp condition (with $k$ free variabels) forms a lattice. For pp conditions

$$\begin{equation} Ï† _i[ğ± ,ğ²_i] := âˆƒ ğ²_i \ ((ğ± , ğ² _i)â‹… H_{i} = \mathbf 0)\quad (i =1,2), \end{equation}$$

one has

  1. $(Ï†_1 âˆ§ Ï† _2) [ğ± , ...] = âˆƒ ğ² _1, ğ² _2 \ ((ğ±, ğ²_1 ) â‹… H_{1} = 0 âˆ§ (ğ±, ğ²_2 ) â‹… H_{2} = 0)$, and
  2. $(Ï†_1 âˆ¨ Ï† _2) [ğ± , ...] = âˆƒ ğš,ğ›,ğœ,ğ \ (ğ± = ğš + ğ› âˆ§ (ğš, ğ›) â‹… H_{1} = 0 âˆ§ (ğœ, ğ) â‹… H_{2} = 0)$.

The lattice is modular.

We show for $Î±' â‰¤ Î±$, one has $(Î± âˆ§ Î² ) âˆ¨ Î± ' = Î± âˆ§ (Î² âˆ¨ Î± ')$. By universal property of $âˆ§$ and $âˆ¨$, we obtain $âŠ†$. Conversely, consider

$$\begin{equation} Î± âˆ§ (Î² âˆ¨ Î± ') [ğ± ,...]= âˆƒ \ ((ğ±,ğš )H_Î± =0 âˆ§ (ğ› ,ğœ )H_Î² =0âˆ§ (ğ, ğŸ )H_{Î± '} =0 âˆ§ ğ±=ğ›+ğ ). \end{equation}$$

We see $ğ±=ğ›+ğ$ satisfies

$$\begin{equation} (ğ› , ğš - ğŸ ) H_Î± = 0 âˆ§ (ğ› , ğœ ) H_Î² = 0 âˆ§ (ğ , ğŸ ) H_{Î± '} = 0. \end{equation}$$

(Galois connection). Once we fix $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$, there is a pairing to truth value

$$\begin{equation} \text{definable subgrps} \ Ã— \ \text{pp formula} â†’ ğ”½ _2,\quad (G, Ï†) â†¦ \{G âŠ† Ï† (M) \ ?\}. \end{equation}$$

We define the vanishing set of $ğ± âˆˆ M^k$ as $pp^M_k(ğ± ) := \{Ï† : ğ± âˆˆ Ï† (M)\}$. We write $pp(x)$ for simplicity.

Show that $pp(ğ± )$ is a filter, i.e.,

  1. if $Î± , Î² âˆˆ pp(ğ± )$ then $(Î± âˆ§ Î² ) âˆˆ pp(ğ± )$,
  2. if $Î± âˆˆ pp(ğ± )$ then $Î± ' âˆˆ pp(ğ± )$ for all $Î± ' â‰¥ Î±$.

In particular, $pp(ğ±)$ is either principal (generated by one element) or infinitely generated.

  • A filter on the finite poset is always principal; note that the filtered colimit over finite index category is the valuation at the terminal object.
  • The assignment $X â†¦ \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{P}(X)), \quad x â†¦ \{A : x âˆˆ A\}$ takes each element in the set $X$ to its generating principal ultrafilter (ultra = maximal). Each filter is contained in some ultrafilter, as each ideal in $(ğ”½_2)^X$ is contained in some maximal ideal. However, there exists some non-principle ($â‰ˆ$ unconstructable) ultrafilter. Set $X = â„¤ _{â‰¥ 1}$, then any ultrafilter containing $\{k â„¤ \}_{k â‰¥ 1}$ is non-principal. Such unconstructable ultrafilter yields a fruitful field of non-standard analysis.

Fortunately, such filter of pp conditions is always principal for f.p. modules.

Let $M$ be f.p.. For any $x âˆˆ M^k$, $pp(x)$ is principal.

We write $R^m \overset {C^T} â†’ R^n \overset Ï€ â†’ M â†’ 0$, then $\{z_k = Ï€ (e_k)\}_{k=1}^n$ generates $M$. Now $z C = 0$. We set $x + z X = 0$ and define

$$\begin{equation} Ï†_m [x,y] := âˆƒ y \ ((x,y)\binom{I \ O}{X \ C} = 0). \end{equation}$$

To see $Ï† _m$ is the least pp condition, we take any $x âˆˆ Ï†(M)$ and show that $Ï†_m â‰¤ Ï†$. There is $y'$ s.t. $(x,y')\binom{A}{-B} = 0$. Since $z$ is a generating set, there is $(x,y') = (x,z)\binom{I \ O}{O \ Q}$. Hence,

$$\begin{equation} \binom{I\ O}{O \ Q} â‹… \binom{A}{-B} = \binom {A}{-QB} âˆˆ \ker ((x,z) â‹… ) \overset â‹†= \operatorname{im} (\binom{I \ O}{X \ C}â‹… ). \end{equation}$$

Here $â‹†$ is equivalent to $\ker ((0, z)â‹…) = \operatorname{im}(\binom{I \ O}{O \ C} â‹…)$, which is more over equivalent to $\ker Ï€ = \operatorname{im} (C^T)$.

Herzogâ€™s Pairing

The tensor pairing yields the duality. Assume $M âŠ— N = 0$, then $M$ is $r$-annihilated iff $N$ is $r$-divisible. The dualised pp conditions are

By the proof of Kaplansky theorem, a summand of coproducts of countably generated modules is also a coproduct of countably generated modules.

The following tensor-product argument characterise the f.g. modules, f.p. modules and Mittag-Leffler modules. The latter contains all pure projective modules.

(Mittag-Leffler module in sense of Raynaud and Gruson). $M$ is said to be Mittag-Leffler (ML for short), provided the above natural transformation is monic.

We care about the structure of countably generated pure projective modules, as they are the building blocks of pure projectives.

This shows that pure projective modules are exactly the coproducts of countably generated Mittag-Leffler modules.

A tower is a countable cocomposition of morphisms $$\begin{equation} \cdots â†’ X_2 \overset{Ïˆ _1}â†’ X_1 \overset{Ïˆ _0}â†’ X_0 â†’ 0. \end{equation}$$

$\varprojlim {}^1$ is the right derived functor of $\varprojlim_{Ï‰ \text{-tower}}$.

The functor $X â†¦ [\cdots = X = \overset{\deg n} X â†’ 0 = 0 â†’ \cdots â†’ 0]$ has left adjoint $(Y_âˆ™, Ïˆ_âˆ™) â†¦ Y_n$. Since an exact left adjoint preserves injective objects, the category of $Ï‰$-towers has enough injectives, i.e.,

By injective resolution $Y \overset Î¹ â†ª I^0 \overset {g_0}â†’ I^1\overset {g_1}â†’ \cdots$,

$$\begin{equation} (\mathrm R^1 \varprojlim) Y = \frac{\ker [\varprojlim (g_1)]}{\operatorname{im} [\varprojlim (g_0)]} â‰ƒ \frac{\varprojlim \ker (g_1)}{\operatorname{im} [\varprojlim (g_0)]}â‰ƒ \frac{\varprojlim C}{\operatorname{im} [\varprojlim I^0 â†’ \varprojlim C]} â‰ƒ \varprojlim {}^1 C \end{equation}$$

$\varprojlim{}^1$ is closely related to the completion. Consider a descending sequence of submodules $\cdots âŠ† M_{k+1} âŠ† M_{k} âŠ† \cdots âŠ† M_0$, aka open neighbourhoods. Applying $\varprojlim$ to the ses $0 â†’ M_k â†’ M â†’ \frac{M}{M_k} â†’ 0$, we obtain the following exact sequence

Some remarks:

(Mittag-Leffler condition). An inverse directed system is said to be Mittag-Leffler provided

$$\begin{equation} âˆ€ X \ âˆƒ (Y \overset f â†’ X) \ âˆ€ (Z \xrightarrow g Y) \ (\operatorname{im} (g âˆ˜ f) = \operatorname{im}(f)). \end{equation}$$

  • The ML condition is talked over inverse directed systems. There is no worry to talk about ML conditions over the system of cofiltered limits, as every filtered category is cofinal to a directed category.

(Mittag-Leffler tower). Let $(X, Ïˆ)$ be tower. For each $m$, the descending sequence of image $\{\operatorname{im}(Ïˆ _{n+k, n})\}_{k â‰¥ 1}$ stabilises for large $k$. Hence, the tower is cofinal to (has the same limit as) the surjective system of images:

Countable ML condition guarentees the vanishing of $\mathrm R^1\varprojlim _{Ï‰}$. It is NOT ture that $\mathrm R^1 \varprojlim ^{ML}_I$ vanishes for uncountable $I$!

This note explains the Mittag-Leffler theorem in analysis.

We show some examples of the above comparision.

  1. (Â¬ 1 âˆ§ 2 âˆ§ 3). Any f.p. module is countably generated and ML, but not flat in general.
  2. (1 âˆ§ Â¬ 2 âˆ§ 3). $â„š âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _â„¤$ is countably generated flat. $â„š$ is never ML, since $â„š âŠ— âˆ_{n â‰¥ 1} â„¤ / n â„¤ â‰  0 = âˆ _{n â‰¥ 0}(â„š âŠ— â„¤ / n â„¤)$.
  3. (1 âˆ§ 2 âˆ§ Â¬ 3). $â„¤ ^Ï‰ âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _â„¤$ is flat and ML, but not a coproduct of countably generated module. $â„¤ ^Ï‰$ is flat since $â„¤$ is coherent. To see it is ML, we take any turple $x = (x^s)_{s âˆˆ Ï‰} âˆˆ (â„¤^Ï‰ )^k$. By commuting of pp condition and $âˆ$, $\min pp(x) = â‹€ _{s âˆˆ Ï‰ } pp (x^s)$ exists. Hence $pp^{â„¤ ^Ï‰ }(x)$ is principal. We finally show that $â„¤^Ï‰$ is not a coproduct of countable abelian groups. Sperkerâ€™s theorem shows $(â„¤ ^Ï‰ ,â„¤ ) â‰ƒ â„¤ ^{(Ï‰)}$. If $â„¤ ^ Ï‰ = âˆ_{i âˆˆ I} A_i$ is coproduct of countable Abelian groups, then $â„¤ ^{(Ï‰ )}$ is a product of the dual groups. Since $|2^Ï‰| > Ï‰$, there are exactly finite many $i$ s.t. $(A_i, â„¤ ) â‰  0$. Hence, there is some uncountable summand $M â†ª â„¤ ^Ï‰$ s.t. $(M, â„¤) = 0$. Consider the projection $M \xrightarrow{p_k} â„¤$, a contradiction.

Show the local property of ML module $M$:

  • any finite subset $S âŠ† M$ is contained in some pure projective submodule $P âŠ† M$;
  • any countable subset $S âŠ† M$ is contained in some countably generated pure projective submodule $P âŠ† M$.

Pure Injective and Compactness

Anagolously to pure projectives, a pure injective module $X$ is such that $(Î¸ , X)$ is exact for any pure exact sequence $Î¸$.

For any injective module $I$ and any module $X$, $(X, I)$ is pure exact. Note that $(Î¸ , (X , I)) â‰ƒ (Î¸ âŠ— X , I)$ is exact.

Show basic properties of pure injective module:

  1. $M$ is pure injective iff any pure exact sequence $0 â†’ M â†’ X â†’ Y â†’ 0$ splits.
  2. $M$ is injective iff the canonical pure embedding $M â†ª M^{++}$ splits.
  3. Pure injective modules are closed under $âˆ$, $ğ’ğ¦ğ$ã€‚
  4. If $X$ is pure injective, then $\mathrm{Ext}^k(M,X)$ are pure injective for any $k â‰¥ 0$.

We show pure injective means algebraically compact. We show some examples before explaining the definitions

(Bohrâ€™s compactification for Toplogical Abelian Groups). Let $T = â„ / â„¤$ be the torus group. We endow $X^c := (X,T)_â„¤$ with discrete topology. In this case $X^{cc}$ is compact Hausdorff with dense subspace $X$.

  1. Note that $X^{cc} â†ª (X^c, T)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬} = T^{X^c}$ is a product of compact Hausdorff space. $X^{cc} = \{(t_f) : t_{f+g} = t_{f}+t_{g}\}$ is clearly a closed subspace, thus it is compact hausdorff.
  2. We show the essnetial image $X â†ª X^{cc},\quad x â†¦ (f(x))_{f âˆˆ X^c}$ is dense. If not, then $\overline {X} â‹ X^{cc}$ is compact subset. We take non-zero continuous character $Ï‡ : X^{cc} â†’ T$ which vanishes on $\overline {X}$. By Pontryagin-duality theorem, $Ï‡$ is evaluation of some $f âˆˆ X^c$. Since $Ï‡ : \overline {X} â†’ 0$, we have $f = 0$. It yields $Ï‡ = 0$, a contradiction.

Hence, for any compact group $G$, the group homomorphism $X â†’ G$ uniquely extends to a continuous homomorphism $X^{cc} â†’ G$. Note that $(-)^{cc}$ is a left adjoint to the inclusion $ğ€ğ›ğ“ğ¨ğ©ğ†ğ«ğ© â†’ ğ‚ğ©ğ­ğ‡ğšğ®ğ¬ğ€ğ›ğ“ğ¨ğ©ğ†ğ«ğ©$. The adjuntion is generalised to the non-commutative case, see here for the general theory.

(Scalar-compact). A module $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ is scalar-compact iff there is some compact Hausdorff space over $M$ making each

$$\begin{equation} M â†’ M,\quad m â†¦ mr\quad (r âˆˆ R) \end{equation}$$

a continuous map.

$X^{cc}$ is scalar-compact. We identify $r : X â†’ X$ as a continuous endomorphism of discrete space $X$. The scalar maps extends to a continuous endomorphism of $X^{cc}$ by the universal property of Bohrâ€™s compactification.

(Algebraically compact). The definition is related to ÅoÅ›â€™s theorem, we provide a simple definition here. Say $M$ is algebraically compact, iff for any linear system

$$\begin{equation} \mathcal{S} := \left\{âˆ‘ _{j âˆˆ J} m_i r_{i,j} = 0 âˆ£ i âˆˆ I\right\},\quad (âˆ€ i âˆˆ I, \{r_{i,j}â‰  0 âˆ£ j âˆˆ J\} \ \text{is finite}). \end{equation}$$

when any finite subset of $\mathcal{S}$ has a solution, then the whole system $\mathcal{S}$ has a solution.

  • Any such system identifies an element in $âˆ _{i âˆˆ I} âˆ _{j âˆˆ J} R$.

Show that algebraically compact modules are closed under summands.

  • We shall see that the idempotent completion of scalar-compact modules are algebraically compact ones.

Now we show equivalent definition of pure injective modules.

$M$ is pure injective iff the following equivalent definitions are satisfied.

  1. $(-, M)$ preserves the exactness of pure exact sequences.
  2. $M â†’ M^{cc}$ or $M â†’ M^{++}$ splits.
  3. $M$ is a summand of some scalar-compact module.
  4. $M$ is algebraically compact.
  5. The summation $Î£ : âˆ_{Î» âˆˆ Î› }M â†’ M$ extends to $âˆ_{Î» âˆˆ Î› }M â†’ M$.

Recall that $M â†ª M^{++}$, $M â†ª M^{cc}$, and $âˆ _{Î» âˆˆ Î› } M â†ª âˆ _{Î» âˆˆ Î› } M$ are pure embeddings. Hence, (1 â†” 2 â†’ 3 âˆ§ 5). is clear.
(3 â†’ 4). It suffices to show all scalar-compact modules are algebraically compact. We take arbitrary system $r_{âˆ™,âˆ™} âˆˆ âˆ _I âˆ _J R$. Note that for each finite $I_0 âŠ† I$, $M^{I_0}$ is zero of a continuous map, which is closed. Hence the solution set (with $I_0$ linear equations) is a closed subset of $M^I$, thus it is compact. By finite intersection argument of compact sets, $M$ is algebraically compact.
(4 â†’ 1). For any pure submodule $X â†ª Y$, we show $h : X â†’ M$ extends to $Y â†’ M$. We take infinite turple $f âˆˆ M^Y$ with the following set of equations

$$\begin{equation} \{f_{y}r+f_{y'}r'-f_{yr+y'r'}=0\}_{y,y' âˆˆ Y, \text{and} \ r,r' âˆˆ R} âˆª \{f_y = h(y)\}_{y âˆˆ X âŠ† Y}. \end{equation}$$

When these equality holds, we obtain a homomorphism $f : Y â†’ M$ with $f|_X = h$. Any finite subset of the above equations are of the form $ğ¦ â‹… ğ‘ = ğ¦ _0$, which has a solution in the pushout $M âŠ” _A B$. Since $M â†’ M âŠ” _A B$ pure embedding, any such finite set of equation has a solution in $M$. By assumption of algebraically compactness, the global solution exists.
(5 â†’ 4). A linear equation of the form $ğ±_{I_k} â‹… ğ‘ ^{n Ã— m} = ğ±_0$ determines a composition of morphism

$$\begin{equation} âˆ _{I_k} M \xrightarrow{â‹… ğ‘ \ \text{termwise}} âˆ _{I_k}âˆ _{J_k} Mâ†ªâˆ _{I}âˆ _{J_k} M \xrightarrow {âˆ _{J_k}Î£} âˆ _{J_k}M. \end{equation}$$

We assume $J_âˆ™$ to be the juxtaposition of constant terms, i.e., for $i â‰  j$, we take $J_i âˆ© J_j = âˆ…$. By lifting property of $Î£$, we obtain



Since $\coprod_{J_0}\Sigma$ is surjective, $\coprod_{J_i}\widetilde {\Sigma}$ is surjective. The colimit functor of $\varinjlim _{J_i}$ preserves surjection, thus $\coprod_{J}\widetilde {\Sigma}$ is surjective. We denote $ğ²$ as the disjoint union of the constant part of the equation, taking $I$-projection of any $(\coprod_{J}\widetilde {\Sigma})^{-1}(ğ²)$ yields the solution.

Any additive functor preserving both $âˆ$ and $âˆ$ preserves pure injective modules.

Let $F$ be such a functor. Let $\widetilde {Î£} : âˆ _I X â†’ X$ denote any lifting map of $Î£ : âˆ _I Xâ†’ X$. Now $âˆ _I (FX) \xrightarrow Î£ FX$ has a lifting map

$$\begin{equation} âˆ_I FX â‰ƒ Fâˆ_I X \xrightarrow {F\widetilde {Î£}} FX. \end{equation}$$

Fp-Injective

Another name for FP-Injective module is absolutely pure module. It is a dual notion of flat module.

Recall that, $M$ is flat iff any ses $0 â†’ K â†’ X â†’ M â†’ 0$ is pure.

(Fp-Inj). The following are equivalent for $M$.

  1. Any ses $0 â†’ M â†’ X â†’ Y â†’ 0$ is pure exact;
  2. $M âˆˆ (ğ¦ğ¨ğ_R)^âŸ‚$ (standard $\mathrm{Ext}^1$-orthogonality);
  3. $M$ is a pure submodule of some injective module.

(1 â†’ 2, 3). Clear.
(3 â†’ 1). Assume $M â†ª I$, is pure embedding, then any monomorphism $M â†ª X$ passes through $X â†’ I$. Recall that

  • if $gf$ is pure embedding, then so is $f$.

Hence $M â†ª X$ is a pure embedding.
(2 â†’ 3). Let $M â†ª I$ be any injective preenvelope. Since $\mathrm{Ext}^1(ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R, M) = 0$, for any $K âˆˆ ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R$ the morphism $K â†’ I/M$ lifts up to $K â†’ I$. Hence $M â†’ I â†’ I/M$ is pure exact.

Show that $(ğ’ğ¦ğ (ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (ğ¦ğ¨ğ _R)), \text{fp-Injective})$ is cogenerated by set, thus it is complete.

item.title: Topological Six Functors
item.description:
This is a concrete and elementary introduction to topological six functors of (pre)sheaves over general algebraic structures.

Here is the PDF file.

item.title: CT3
item.description:
• Lecture 3
    • Abstract
  • All Covers are Projective Covers
    • The Projective Cover
    • Functorial Approach
    • A Tautological Comparison
    • Example: vNR Rings
    • Example: Torsion Theory
    • Envelopes and Examples
  • Set-theoretic Consideration
    • Flat Cotorsion Pair
    • Precover â‡’ Cover
    • Special Preenvelope â‡’ Special Envelope
    • Envelope â‡’ Preenvelope
    • Special Precover â‡’ Special Cover
    • Remarks

Lecture 3

Abstract

A wide range of cotorsion pairs are constructed via covering and enveloping. We analyse the existence of projective covers at the outset, and identify where the obstacle arises. Subsequently, we introduce criteria for the existence of covers and envelopes.

All Covers are Projective Covers

We explain the general theory of (pre)covers with projective (pre)covers in a functorial approach.

The Projective Cover

For an Abelian category with enough projectives, we provide two equivalent definitions of projective cover.

(Small/superfluous). A subobject $i : K â†ª X$ is small if, for any subobject $j : L â†ª X$ with $L + K = X$, then $j$ must be an isomorphism.

A subobject is characterised by a morphism, rather than a plain object. The expression $L + K = X$ means that the following $Î¸$ induced by the pushout is an isomorphism



One may also write $L Ã— _X K =: L âˆ© K$ for convenience.

Show that $i : k â†ª X$ is small if there exists some pushout pullback square of the form , then $j$ must be an isomorphism.

Suppose $p : P â†’ M$ is a projective cover if the following equivalent conditions hold (projective cover = $ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$-cover!):

  1. (Projective cover). $p$ is an epimorphism, and $\ker p$ (as a morphism) is small;
  2. ($ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$-cover). Any morphism $Q â†’ M$ ($Q$ projective) factors through $p$, and any $p âˆ˜ Î± = p$ implies $Î±$ is a(n)
    1. epimorphism;
    2. monomorphism;
    3. automorphism.

(1 â†’ 2-(3)). Clearly, $Q â†’ M$ factors through $p$ by the lifting property of projectives. We show that $p âˆ˜ Î± = p$ implies $Î±$ is an automorphism. We construct the pullback square of monomorphisms:



By $p âˆ˜ Î± = p$, the morphism $p|_{\operatorname{im}Î± }$ is epic, thus the first row is a short exact sequence. By exercise, the subobject $\operatorname{im}(Î± ) â†ª P$ is an isomorphism. This shows $Î±$ is epic. We show $Î±$ is also monic. Let $j$ be the right inverse of $Î±$ (by the lifting property of projectives). Then $p âˆ˜ j = p âˆ˜ Î± âˆ˜ j = p$. Hence $j$ is epic. Since $j$ is also split monic, $j$ is an isomorphism. Therefore $Î±$ is an automorphism.
(2(1) â†’ 1). $p$ is epic, since any epimorphism $Q â†  M$ factors through $p$. We show $\ker p$ is small. If not, there exists a proper subobject $N â†ª P$ such that $N + \ker p = P$. Therefore we have the pullback pushout square of short exact sequences. We introduce $l$ by the lifting property of projectives, then $Î± : Î» âˆ˜ l$ is a non-epimorphism such that $p âˆ˜ Î± = p$, a contradiction.




We show 1 â†’ 2(3) â†’ 2(1,2), and 2(1) â†’ 1. It remains to show 2(2) â†’ 2(3). If there is a strict monomorphism $Î±$ s.t. $p âˆ˜ Î± = p$, then there is an induced monomorphism $Î±|_{\ker p} : \ker p â†’ \ker p$.



In the above diagram, the left square is pullback-pushout. Hence $\operatorname{im}Î± + \ker p = P$. A contradiction.

Here we do not require that the objects are well-powered, which means that all subobjects of a certain object form a set.

Show another equivalent definition of projective cover: say $p : P â†’ A$ is a projective cover if and only if it is an essential epimorphism, i.e., $p âˆ˜ g$ is epic if and only if $g$ is epic.

Functorial Approach

The Yoneda embedding $\mathcal{A} â†ª ğğ’ğ¡ (\mathcal{A})$ via $X â†¦ (-, X)_\mathcal{A}$ is fully faithful and left exact. In particular, the representable functor $(-, X)_\mathcal{A}$ are projective in $ğğ’ğ¡ (\mathcal{A})$.

The Yoneda embedding yields a bijection $(X,Y) â†” [(-, X), (-, Y)]_{ğğ’ğ¡ (\mathcal{A})}$, which identifies $f$ with a collection of natural transformations $\{(A, f)\}_{A âˆˆ \mathcal{A}}$.

  • The assignment $? â†¦ (-, ?)$ preserves all limits, and is thus left exact;
  • For any surjection $Î¸ : F â†’ G$ of presheaves, we observe $[(-, ?), Î¸_-] â‰ƒ Î¸_?$ is surjective. Hence, representable functors are projective in $ğğ’ğ¡ (\mathcal{A})$.

We now provide a functorial characterisation of (pre)cover. Throughout, $\mathcal{F}$ denotes a replete (= closed under isomorphism) class of objects.

((Pre)cover). Let $X âˆˆ \mathcal{A}$ and $F âˆˆ \mathcal{F}$. We say $f : F â†’ X$ is an $\mathcal{F}$-precover if the following equivalent conditions hold:

  1. Any morphism $g : G â†’ X$ with $G âˆˆ \mathcal{F}$ factors through $f$;
  2. There exists an epimorphism $f_âˆ— : (- , F)_\mathcal{F} â†  (-, X)_\mathcal{A}$ from the projective object $(-, F)_\mathcal{F} âˆˆ ğğ’ğ¡ (\mathcal{F})$.

A precover $f : F â†’ X$ is termed a cover if the following equivalent conditions hold:

  1. Any endomorphism $Î± : F â†’ X$ such that $f âˆ˜ Î± = f$ implies $Î±$ is an automorphism;
  2. The epimorphism $f_âˆ— : (-, F)_\mathcal{F} â†  (-, X)_\mathcal{A}$ is a projective cover.

Note that for $2$, $\mathrm{End}_\mathcal{F}(F) â‰ƒ \mathrm{End}_{ğğ’ğ¡ (\mathcal{F})}((-, F)_\mathcal{F})$ via $Î± â†¦ Î± _âˆ—$.

Show that projective precovers are precisely those epimorphisms from projective objects.

Show that if $M$ has a $\mathcal{F}$-cover, then it is a summand of any $\mathcal{F}$-precover.

From a categorical perspective, to study covers, it suffices to study projective covers.

The functorial construction yields remarkable results for AR theory, e.g., this note, or a general theory of Auslander algebra.

A Tautological Comparison

From the above, we deduce that

  • both projective precovers and covers are epic;
  • if $M$ admits a projective cover, then it is unique up to isomorphism, and is always a summand of $Q â†  M$;
  • $p : P â†  M$ is a (pre)cover whenever $p_âˆ— : (-, P)_{ğğ«ğ¨ğ£} â†  (-|_{ğğ«ğ¨ğ£}, M)_{\mathcal{A}}$ is.

We are pleased to compare the projective covers with those arising in the functorial context.

(Idempotent obstacle). There exist cases where an idempotent morphism $e : X â†’ X$ does not split. In this case, $\mathrm{im}(-, e)$ is a non-representable finitely generated projective object.

Assuming $\mathcal{A}$ is idempotent complete, we begin with a well-known lemma.

(Special Yoneda lemma). This is a standard result in representation theory. Let $T'$ be a summand of finite biproducts of $T$. There is an isomorphism

$$\begin{equation} (T', M)_{\mathcal{A}} â†’ ((T,T')_\mathcal{A}, (T, M)_\mathcal{A})_{\mathrm{End}(T)}, \quad f â†¦ f_âˆ— . \end{equation}$$

The right module structure of $(T,M)$ is given by $f â‹… Î± = f âˆ˜ Î±$ for $Î± âˆˆ \mathrm{End}(T)$.

(Projectivisation). Let $ğšğğ (T)$ denote the full subcategory containing $T$ and closed under isomorphisms, finite biproducts and summands. Then there is an equivalence(s):

$$\begin{aligned} (T,-) : ğšğğ (T) &â†’ ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£ (ğ¦ğ¨ğ _{\mathrm{End}(T)}),\quad T_0 â†¦ (T, T_0)\\ ğ€ğğ (T) &â†’ ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ (ğŒğ¨ğ _{\mathrm{End}(T)}),\quad T_0 â†¦ (T, T_0). \end{aligned}$$

The first equivalence holds due to special Yoneda lemma. The full subcategory $ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£ â†ª ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$ is a $\{âˆ, ğ’ğ¦ğ\}$-closure of the $ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£ â†ª (ğğ’ğ¡(ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£ ^{\mathrm{op}}))^{\mathrm{op}}$. Note that direct summands are determined by image of idempotent morphism in endomorphisms algebras. Hence the second isomorphism holds.

The tautological comparison is as follows.

We assume idempotent completeness. Let $p : P â†’ M$ be a $\mathcal{P}$-precover, then the following are equivalent.

  1. $p : T â†’ M$ admits a $\mathcal{P}$-cover;
  2. $p_âˆ— : (-, P)_{\mathcal{P}} â†  (-|_{\mathcal{P}}, M)$ admits a projective cover;
  3. $p_âˆ— : (-, P)_{ğšğğ (P)} â†  (-|_{ğšğğ (P)}, M)$ admits a projective cover;
  4. $p_âˆ— : (P, P)_{\mathrm{End}(P)} â†  (P, M)_{\mathrm{End}(P)}$ admits a projective cover.

Note that the last three are projective precovers as they are epimorphisms.

(1 â†” 2) follows from the definition. In the case of $1$, a $\mathcal{P}$-cover must be a summand of $p$. Since there is no differences between $\mathcal{P}$-cover and $ğšğğ (P)$-cover for $M$, we show (1 â†” 3). (3 â†’ 4) is given by the special Yoneda lemma. It remains to show (4 â†’ 1).
When $p_âˆ— : (P, P)_{\mathrm{End}(P)} â†  (P, M)_{\mathrm{End}(P)}$ admits a projective cover, it takes the form

$$\begin{equation} (P, P)_{\mathrm{End}(P)} â†  Q â†  (P, M)_{\mathrm{End}(P)}. \end{equation}$$

Note that $Q â‰ƒ (P, P_0)_{\mathrm{End}(P)}$ for $P_0 âˆˆ ğ’ğ¦ğ (P)$ by projectivisation. With the special Yoneda lemma, we may write the mapping sequence as

$$\begin{equation} (P, P)_{\mathrm{End}(P)} \overset {a_âˆ— } â†  (P, P_0)_{\mathrm{End}(P)} \overset {b_âˆ— } â†  (P, M)_{\mathrm{End}(P)}. \end{equation}$$

We show that $b : P_0 â†’ M$ is a $\mathcal{P}$-cover. By special Yoneda lemma, $(ba)_âˆ— = p _âˆ—$ yields $ba = p$. As $a$ is split epic, $b$ and $p$ factors through each other, which shows that $b$ is a $\mathcal{P}$-precover. If there exists $b âˆ˜ Î³ = b$, we have $b_âˆ— âˆ˜ Î³ _âˆ— = b_âˆ—$. Now $Î³ _âˆ—$ is an isomorphism as $b_âˆ—$ is a projective cover. By projectivisation, $Î³$ is an automorphism. Hence $b$ is a $\mathcal{P}$-cover.

It is a local property to exhibit a projective cover. For idempotent complete cases, a $\mathcal{P}$-precover $P â†’ M$ admits a $\mathcal{P}$-cover when $\mathrm{End}(P)$ is right semi-perfect (where f.g. modules admits a projective cover).

Example: vNR Rings

A ring $R$ with such that $ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ = ğŒğ¨ğ_R$ is known as a semisimple ring. In comparison with this, the ring $R$ with $ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ = ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ is called vNR (von Neumann regular).

  • The property of being either semisimple or vNR is a symmetric property, i.e., there is no need to distinguish left and right modules.
  • This is not the original definition in sense of von Neumann; but it is a beautiful coincidence that these two definitions coincide.

The followings are equivalent definition for $R$ to be a vNR ring. The first definition shows being vNR is a symmetric property. We proof for right modules only.

  1. (von Neumannâ€™s original definition). For any $x âˆˆ R$, there exists some $y âˆˆ R$ s.t. $xyx=x$.
  2. All modules are flat.
  3. All f.g. ideals are projective.

(2 â†’ 3). Clear.
(3 â†’ 2). All modules are filtered colimit of f.p. modules. Note that $ğ¦ğ¨ğ âŠ† ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$ in this case.
(3 â†’ 1). Any principal ideal $(x)$ is generated by an idempotent element $e$. We write $x = ez$ and $e = xy$. Now

$$\begin{equation} x = ez = e(ez) = xyx. \end{equation}$$

(1 â†’ 3). Clearly, principal ideals are projective. By induction, it suffices to show all $2$-generated ideals are principal and projective. Let $(x,y)$ be such ideal. Then $(x)$ and $(y)$ are projective. Since $(x,y) = (x,(1-x)y)$, we assume $xy = 0$. We take $\overline y$ s.t. $y \overline y y = y$. We take idempotent element

$$\begin{equation} e := y \overline y (1-x) ,\quad e^2 = e. \end{equation}$$

We show $(e + x) = (x,y)$. $e,x âˆˆ (x,y)$ is clear. Conversely, $y = (e+x) y$, and $x = (e+x)x$. Since $(e+x)$ is principal,it is projective.

We show a class of examples of vNR rings.

Let $V$ be a vector space over a field $ğ”½$, then $\mathrm{End}_ğ”½(V)$ is vNR. Since $Ï†$ has the matrix form $\binom {0 \ 0}{0 \ 1}$ over $V â‰ƒ (\ker Ï† âŠ• \operatorname{im}(Ï† ))$.
In particular, once $\dim_ğ”½ (\operatorname{im}(Ï† )) = Îº$ is an infinite cardinal, then the left (right) ideal generated by $Ï†$ contains precisely the endomorphisms with $\dim_ğ”½ (\operatorname{im}(Ï† )) â‰¤ Îº$. Therefore,

  1. $\mathrm{End}_ğ”½ (V)$ is simple iff $\dim _ğ”½ V < âˆ$;
  2. $\mathrm{End}_ğ”½ (V)$ has a non-trivial ideal iff $\dim _ğ”½ V â‰¥ Ï‰$.

This example shows the non-projective f.g. flat modules.

We show some vNR-invariant operations.

Show that for idempotent $e âˆˆ R$. $eRe$ is vNR if $R$ is vNR.

(Kaplansky). When $R$ is a vNR ring, then so is the matirx ring $\mathrm{M}_n (R)$.

  • Hence, being vNR is Morita invariant (i.e., it passes up from $R â†¦ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$).

Let $P_k$ denote the proposition that $\mathrm M_n (R)$ is vNR. The previous problem shows that $P_{n+1} â†’ P_n$. Once we show $P_{n} â†’ P_{2n}$, the lemma is proved by induction.
It suffices to show $P_2$. We write $[p; q] := p - pqp$ for simplicity. Note that $R$ is vNR iff $\ker [x; (-)] â‰  âˆ…$ for each $x$. Note that

$$\begin{equation} [[a;b];c] = [a; b+c-cab-bac+bacab]. \end{equation}$$

Hence, if $[a ; b]$ is a vNR element, then so is $a$. We shall show that

$$\begin{equation} \binom {âˆ— \ âˆ— }{âˆ— \ âˆ—}\ \text{are vNR} \overset {Î±}â† \binom {âˆ— \ âˆ— }{0 \ âˆ—}\ \text{are vNR} \overset {Î²}â† \binom {0 \ âˆ— }{0 \ 0}\ \text{are vNR} \overset {Î³} â† \ \text{True}. \end{equation}$$

(Î±). If we take arbitrary $[c; \overline c] = 0$, then

$$\begin{equation} \left[\binom {a \ b}{c \ d} ; \binom {0 \ \overline c}{0 \ 0} \right] âˆˆ \binom {âˆ— \ âˆ— }{0 \ âˆ— }. \end{equation}$$

(Î²). If we take arbitrary $[a; \overline a] = [d; \overline d] = 0$, then

$$\begin{equation} \left[\binom {a \ b}{0 \ d} ; \binom {\overline a \ 0}{0 \ \overline d} \right] âˆˆ \binom {0 \ âˆ— }{0 \ 0 }. \end{equation}$$

(Î³). By the same procedure as Î±.

Show that over vNR,

Example: Torsion Theory

The covering need not be epimorphisms! A trivial example is that every additive category admits a $\{0\}$-covering. A general kind of examples is known as the torsion theory.

Show that every f.g. Abelian group is a unique direct sum of finite Abelian groups and a f.g. free group.

Let $t : ğšğ› â†’ ğšğ›^{\text{finite}}$ be the functor of taking maximal torsion subgroup. Then $t(M) â†ª M$ is an $ğšğ›^{\text{finite}}$-cover.

The f.g. torsion groups ($ğšğ›^{\text{finite}}$) and f.g. free Abelian groups ($ğšğ›^{\text{f.g. free}}$) are orthogonal with respect to the $\mathrm{Hom}$-functor. We write $X âŸ‚_o Y$ for $\mathrm{Hom}(X,Y) = 0$, and denote $(-)^o := (-)^{âŸ‚_o}$ and $^o(-) := {}^{âŸ‚_o}(-)$ for simplicity.

Unwinding a brief introduction, we enumerate some closure properties of a torsion class as follows.

(Torsion theory). Let $\mathcal{A}$ be an Abelian category which is well-powered and subobjects are closed under transfinite filtrations. Then the following are equivalent for defining a torsion theory $(\mathcal{T}, \mathcal{F})$:

  1. There is a subfunctor $t âŠ† 1_\mathcal{A}$ such that $t âˆ˜ t = t$ and $t(\frac{M}{tM}) = 0$. Here $t âˆ˜ t = t$ means that $t(tM) = tM$ when identifying subobjects of $tM$ as that of $M$. Set $\mathcal{T} = \operatorname{im} t$ and $\mathcal{F} = \ker t$.
  2. $\mathcal{T}âŸ‚ _o \mathcal{F}$, and every object $M$ fits into a short exact sequence $0 â†’ tM â†’ M â†’ M/tM â†’ 0$. In this case, such a sequence is functorial in $M$.
  3. $\mathcal{T}^o = \mathcal{F}$ and $\mathcal{T} = {}^o \mathcal{F}$, or other equivalent form given by Galois connection.
  4. $\mathcal{F} = \mathcal{T}^o$, and $\mathcal{T}$ is closed under taking transfinite filtrations (including extensions) and quotient objects.
  5. $\mathcal{F} = \mathcal{T}^o$, and there is a class of objects $\mathcal{X}$ such that $\mathcal{T}$ consists of objects which are transfinite filtrations of quotient objects in $\mathcal{X}$.

We explain $1 \leftrightarrow 2 \rightarrow 3 \rightarrow 4 \leftrightarrow 5$ in a few words, and show $5 \rightarrow 1$ (which requires supplementary conditions).
($1 \leftrightarrow 2$). A canonical injection refers to a canonical short exact sequence $t$. ($2 \rightarrow 3$). For instance, we show $\mathcal{F} = \mathcal{T} ^o$. We claim $\mathcal{T} âŸ‚ _o \mathcal{F}$; if there is a non-zero $f : T â†’ F$, then $\operatorname{im}(f) âˆˆ \mathcal{T}$ is a subobject of $F$, yielding $tF â‰  0$. Conversely, we show $\mathcal{T} ^o âŠ† \mathcal{F}$; notice that every $X âˆˆ \mathcal{T} ^o$ has no subobjects in $\mathcal{T} âˆ– \{0\}$. ($3 \rightarrow 4$). Note that any $^o\mathcal{X}$ is closed under extensions and quotients. ($4 \leftrightarrow 5$). Clearly, $â†’$ is by taking $\mathcal{X} = \mathcal{T}$. Conversely, any particular class $ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\text{quotients of } \ \mathcal{X})$ is closed under transfinite filtrations and quotient objects.
($4 \rightarrow 2$). We show $X âˆˆ \mathcal{A}$ has a maximal subobject in $\mathcal{T}$, which is also the greatest. Let $\mathcal{S}$ denote the set of subobjects of $X$ lying in $\mathcal{T}$. $0 âˆˆ \mathcal{S}$ is non-empty. Notice that,

  • Every chain in $\mathcal{S}$ has an upper bound, as $\mathcal{T}$ is closed under transfinite filtrations.
  • Any two maximal objects $T_1, T_2 âˆˆ \mathcal{S}$ coincide. If not, then $(T_1 + T_2) âˆˆ \mathcal{T}$, a contradiction.

Let $tX$ denote such a maximal subobject in $\mathcal{T}$; we complete the proof.

We call $\mathcal{T}$ a torsion class, and $\mathcal{F}$ a torsion-free class.

The above are equivalent for either $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ or $C(R)$. Note that these categories are well-powered and cocomplete.

Show that subobjects in either $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ or $C(R)$ are closed under transfinite filtrations. Hint:

  2. $i_âˆ™ : M_âˆ™ â†ª X$ induces a monomorphism $\varinjlim ^{fil} M_âˆ™ â†ª X$.

Recall that $\mathcal{C}^o = \mathcal{F}$ and ${}^o\mathcal{C} = \mathcal{F}$ holds in $\frac{\mathcal{A}}{\mathcal{C} âˆ© \mathcal{F}}$. When $\frac{\mathcal{A}}{\mathcal{C} âˆ© \mathcal{F}}$ has exact structure, we almost done.

Envelopes and Examples

This is the dual statement of covers. The general theory of envelopes also translates to that of projective covers.

Let $\mathcal{E}$ be a replete class of objects. For any $E âˆˆ \mathcal{E}$, say $j : X â†ª E$ is

There might (the writer has never encountered it before) be a dual concept called co-small quotient module or co-superfluous quotient module. Say $p: X â†  C$ is co-small, provided for any quotient object $q: X â†  C'$ such that $X \xrightarrow âˆ¼ C' Ã— _{C âŠ” _X C'} C$, $q$ is an isomorphism.

For set-theoretic consideration, we substitute the expression co-small with essential extension.

$p : X â†  C$ is co-small, if and only if $\ker p â†ª X$ is an essential extension which is defined as follows:

  • any non-zero submodule $L â†ª X$ has a non-zero intersection with $\ker p$.

($\rightarrow$). Suppose $p : X â†  C$ is co-small, while there exists a non-zero submodule $L â†ª X$ such that $L âˆ© \ker p = 0$. Then we shall see contradictions. By definition, one has the following pushout-pullback square



By definition of co-small, $X = \frac{X}{L \cap \ker p} â†  \frac{X}{L}$ is an isomorphism, yielding $L = 0$, a contradiction.
($\leftarrow$). Conversely, suppose that $\ker p â†ª X$ is essential yet $p : X â†  \frac{X}{\ker p}$ is not co-small. Then it is possible to find a non-zero submodule $L$ such that the above diagram is a pushout-pullback square. Now $L âˆ© \ker p = 0$, a contradiction.

Show $i : X â†’ E$ is an injective envelope, provided the following equivalent conditions:

  1. $i$ is injective with a co-small cokernel;
  2. $i ^âˆ— : (E, -)_\mathcal{E} â†  (X, -|_\mathcal{E})_{\mathcal{A}}$ is a projective cover.

Unlike projective covers, the injective envelopes always exist.

Every module $X âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ has an injective envelope.

Set $\mathcal{S} : \{i : X â†ª Y âˆ£ i \ \text{is essential}\}$. We claim every ascending chain in $\mathcal{S}$ has an upper bound. Note that

$$\begin{equation} â‹ƒ _{i âˆˆ I} (L âˆ© Y_i) = L âˆ© (â‹ƒ_{i âˆˆ I} Y_i)\qquad (â‡” \text{AB5 condition}). \end{equation}$$

We take any maximal object $Q âˆˆ \mathcal{S}$. Clearly $Q$ has only trivial essential extensions. We claim that $Q$ is injective by showing any short exact sequence $0 â†’ Q â†’ E â†’ E/Q â†’ 0$ splits. Again by AB5, there is a maximal subobject $T â†ª E$ such that $T âˆ© Q = 0$. By definition, $Q â†ª \frac{E}{T}$ is essential, thus $Q â†ª E â†  \frac{E}{T}$ is an isomorphism. Now $Q+T = E$ and $Q âˆ© T = 0$, hence $E = Q âŠ• T$.
Finally, $X â†ª Q$ is an injective envelope as it is monic with co-small cokernel (= essential extension).

Set-theoretic Consideration

We show few results of the existence of (special) cover/envelope, provided the existence of (special) precover/preenvelope. The analysis holds for general well-powered Abelian category closed under some (co)limits. To conclude, we have the following theorem.

Suppose $(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{F})$ is a complete cotorsion theory such that either

  • $\mathcal{C}$ is closed under filtered colimits, or
  • $\mathcal{F}$ is closed under cofiltered limits.

Then $\mathcal{C}$ is a covering class and $\mathcal{F}$ is an enveloping class.

Flat Cotorsion Pair

The example comes from flat cotorsion pair.

Flat modules are closed under transfinite filtrations.

We prove with transfinite induction. Suppose $\{M_Î³\}_{Î³ < Î±}$ is a transfinite filtration of flat modules.

  1. $M_0 = 0$ is flat.

$ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­$ is closed under filtered colimits, as $(\varinjlim^{fil}F_âˆ™ âŠ— -) â‰ƒ \varinjlim^{fil}(F_âˆ™ âŠ— -)$ is exact.

It is straightforward to show that $(ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ , ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚ )$ is a cotorsion theory. Since

Hence, $ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ = ğ’ğ¦ğ (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­)) = {}^âŸ‚ (ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­^âŸ‚ )$.

We call $(ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ , ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚)$ a flat cotorsion theory.

We call $ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚$ Enochs cotorsion modules. There are analogous definitions, e.g., Warfield cotorsion modules stands for the right orthogonal class of torsion-free modules.

It has long been a conjecture that whether the flat cotorsion pair is cogenerated by a set. The existence of flat covers (Enochsâ€™s flat covering theorem) solves the problem.

Let $\mathcal{P}$ is a replete class of modules or chain complexes. We assume $\mathcal{P}$ is closed under filtered colimits and summands, e.g. $\mathcal{P} = ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­$ or the entire category.

We show (3 â†’ 4). If not, then there exists a stricly injection $i : P â†’ P$ such that $p âˆ˜ i = p$. We shall construct a transfinite composition which terminates at $Îº â‰« |P|$:

$$\begin{equation} |\{Î³ âˆˆ Î± âˆ£ âˆƒ Î² \ \text{s.t.} \ Î³ = Î²^+\}| = |Î±|. \end{equation}$$
