Say $Î±$ is a relative envelift, provided $\operatorname{im}(Î± ^â™¯)$ is a singleton $\{\ker Î±\}$.

We show firstly the existence of relative envelift.

If $Î´$ has a preenvelift, then $Î´$ has a relative envelift.

If not, then there is a transfinite composition of morphisms of extensions:

$$\begin{equation} Î´ = Î¸ _0 \xrightarrow {f_{1,0}} Î¸ _1 \xrightarrow {f_{2,1}} \cdots Î¸ _Î³ \xrightarrow {f_{Î³ +1,Î³ }} \cdots Î¸ _{Îº}, \end{equation}$$

such that

  1. $Î¸ _{Î³ + 1} âˆ˜ f_{Î³ +1, Î³ } = Î¸ _Î³$ for each $Î³$;
  2. if $Î³$ is a successor ordinal, $Î¸ _Î³$ is a $\mathcal{C}$-preenvelift;
  3. if $Î³$ is a limit ordinal, then $Î¸ _Î³$ is induced by colimit;
    • Remark: $0 â†’ M â†’ \varinjlim^{fil}X_âˆ™ â†’ \varinjlim^{fil}C_âˆ™ â†’ 0$ is again exact. Meanwhile, $\varinjlim^{fil}C_âˆ™ âˆˆ \mathcal{C}$ by assumption.
  4. $\{\ker f_{Î³ , 0}\}$ strictly ascends when composing $f_{Î² +2, Î² +1}$.

Let $Îº â‰« |Î¸|$, we see the contradiction.

When $Î´$ (of the type $\mathrm{Ext}^1(\mathcal{C}, M)$) admits a $\mathcal{C}$-preenvelift $Î¸$, then it has a $\mathcal{C}$-envelift.

We construct a transfinite composition of relative envelifts:

$$\begin{equation} Î¸ = Î¸ _0 \xrightarrow {Î± _0} Î¸ _1 \xrightarrow {Î± _1} \cdots Î¸ _Î³ \xrightarrow {Î± _Î³} \cdots Î¸ _{Îº}. \end{equation}$$

For every limit ordinal $Î³$, we firstly take $\overline {Î¸ _Î³ }$ by colimit, then take $\overline {Î¸ } â†’ Î¸$. The stablised image $Îµ$ sequence is a summand of some preenvelift, thus $Îµ$ is a preenvelift.



In this case, any endomorphism $Î± : Îµ â†’ Îµ$ is injective. Since all objects are well-powered, $Î±$ is an automorphism. Once we show that the middle term of $Îµ$ ($Îµ _2$) lies in $C^âŸ‚$, we complete the proof. We take Noetherâ€™s isomorphism:



$C' âˆˆ ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\mathcal{C}) = \mathcal{C}$. Hence $q : Îµ â†’ Îµ '$ is a morphism of extensions of type $\mathrm{Ext}^1(M, \mathcal{C})$. Since $Îµ$ is a $\mathcal{C}$-preenvelift, there is another morphism $s : Îµ ' â†’ Îµ$. Since $s âˆ˜ q$ is an automorphism, $Îµ_2 âˆˆ ğ’ğ¦ğ (\mathcal{C}^âŸ‚) = \mathcal{C}^âŸ‚$.

Envelope â‡’ Preenvelope

Suppose $\mathcal{E}$ is a class of modules closed under summand, along with the following concession.

(Concession). If there is a preenvelope $i : M â†’ E$, then any morphism from $M$ to the cofiltered limit $\varprojlim^{cof} E_âˆ™$ factors through $i$.

  • In particular, the concession holds if $\mathcal{E}$ is closed under cofiltered limits.

We denote $\widetilde {\mathcal{E}}$ as the $\varprojlim ^{cof}$-completion of $\mathcal{E}$, and introduce the relative cokernel (or relative image for convenience).

(Image). For a general morphism of the type $j : M â†’ \widetilde {\mathcal{E}}$, we define

$$\begin{equation} \mathrm{IM}(j) := \{\operatorname{im}(Î± ) âˆ£ Î± : i â†’ j,\ i \ \text{ is a preenvelope}\}. \end{equation}$$

We also have the cobase change. Say $Î± âˆˆ \mathrm{IM}(j)$ is a relative envelope, provided

$$\begin{equation} Î± _â™¯ : \mathrm{IM}(i) â†’ \mathrm{IM}(j), \quad \operatorname{im}(?) â†¦ \operatorname{im}(Î± âˆ˜ ?),\ \text{such that} \ \operatorname{im}(Î± _â™¯ ) = \{\operatorname{im}(Î± )\}. \end{equation}$$

We show the existence of relative envelope.

Any morphism of the type $j : M â†’ F âˆˆ \widetilde {\mathcal{E}}$ has a relative envelope.

If not, then there is a transfinite composition of towers

$$\begin{equation} \cdots \overset {f_{Î³ +1, Î³+0}}â†’ (E _{Î³ +1}, i _{Î³ +1}) \overset {f_{Î³,Î³+1}} â†’ (E_Î³, i _Î³ ) \cdots \overset {f_{1,2}}â†’ (E_1, i _1) \overset {f_{0,1}}â†’ (E_0, i _0) = (F, j), \end{equation}$$

such that

  1. for any $Î²$, $i_Î² âˆ˜ Î± _Î² = i_{Î² +1}$;
  2. if $Î²$ is a successor ordinal, then $i_Î²$ is a preenvelope;
  3. if $Î²$ is a limit ordinal, then $i_Î²$ is induced by limit;
  4. $\{\operatorname{im}(f_{0, Î³})\}$ strictly descends when composing $f_{Î² +1, Î² +2}$.

Let $Îº â‰« |F|$, we see the contradiction.

We leave the dual procedure to readers.

Show that

  1. Any preenvelope $i : M â†’ E$ admits a trasnfinite tower of relative envelopes;
  2. The stablised image $Îµ$ is a preenvelope;
  3. Any endomorphism $Î± : Îµ â†’ Îµ$ is surjective, hence bijective.

Special Precover â‡’ Special Cover

Suppose $\mathcal{F}$ is a class of modules closed under summands, extensions, and cofiltered limits. A special ${}^âŸ‚\mathcal{F}$-(pre)cover is an epic ${}^âŸ‚ \mathcal{F}$-(pre)cover with kernel in $\mathcal{F}$.

For $M$ admits a special ${}^âŸ‚\mathcal{F}$-precover, $M$ there has a special ${}^âŸ‚ \mathcal{F}$-cover.

Recall in the subsection Special Preenvelope â‡’ Special Envelope, we did not use AB5 property.

Remarks

We are interested in cogenerating construction for set-theoritic issuse. For instance,

(Shelah). It is independent of ZFC that every whitehead group ($^âŸ‚â„¤$) is a free group. A minicourse.

Completion (with ideal-metric) is a special case of cofiltered limit. We might see that in the study of (Enochâ€™s) cotorsion modules, etc.

One can similarly define $\mathrm{Tor}$-cotorsion theory. Note that the left and right class of modules are closed under extensions, summands, coproducts, and filtered colimits. In this case, any $\varinjlim^{fil}$-closed $\mathcal{C}$-class corresponds to a $\mathrm{Tor}$-torsion theory.

item.title: CT2
item.description:
• Lecture 2
    • Abstract
  • Remarks on E-T Lemma
    • Functorial Approximations
    • Reconstruction Lemma
    • Kaplansky Class
  • Acyclic Complexes
    • $({}^âŸ‚C_{ac}, C_{ac})$
    • $(C_{ac}, C_{ac}^âŸ‚)$
  • Cotorsion Triple
    • Relative DG
    • C. H. Cotorsion Pair
    • C. H. Cotorsion Triple
  • A Note on Resolutions
    • The Definitions
    • Resolutions ($K^-(ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£)$)
    • Resolutions via Brownâ€™s Rep
    • Semi-(DG-)free Complexes
    • DG-Flat
    • Derived Category and Its Closed Monoidal Structure

Lecture 2

Abstract

We analysis a criterion on a cotorsion pair cogenerated by set, which complete the counter part of Eklof-Trlifajâ€™s theorem. We introduce DG-projective complexes over the construction of $(^{âŸ‚ }C_{ac}, C_{ac}, C_{ac}^âŸ‚ )$.

Remarks on E-T Lemma

Functorial Approximations

We show in the previous lecture that

(Eklof-Trlifaj lemma). For any object $S âˆˆ C(R)$, the cotorsion pair cogenerated by $S$ is complete. In paricular, any objects $X$ admits a ses

$$\begin{equation} Î¸ _X : 0 â†’ X â†’ X_F â†’ X_C â†’ 0,\quad (X_F âˆˆ {}^âŸ‚ S, \ X_C âˆˆ ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)). \end{equation}$$

The construction is functorial as the $|S|$-filtered ordinal $Î±$ is fixed.

Note that $C(R)$ has enough projectives. Any chain complex $X$ admits a functorial epimorphism $p_X$ from the free complex $ğ…ğ«ğğ(X)$:

$$\begin{equation} 1_X âˆˆ (X,X)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬} â‰ƒ (ğ…ğ«ğğ(X), X)_{C(R)} âˆ‹ p_X. \end{equation}$$

Show that for $X âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _R â†ª C(R)$, the above $p_X$ is $R^{(X)} â†  X, \quad e_x â†¦ x$, where $ğ…ğ«ğğ (X) = R^{(X)}$. In general,



It is also convenient to give a functorial $Ï„_X : 0 â†’ X^F â†’ X^C â†’ X â†’ 0$ by



Hence we give a functorial approximations

$$\begin{equation} X âˆˆ \mathrm{coCone}(S^âŸ‚ , ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)) = \mathrm{coCone}(S^âŸ‚ , ğ…ğ«ğğ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)). \end{equation}$$

In particular, $ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S) âŠ† (ğ…ğ«ğğ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)) âŠ† {}^âŸ‚ (X^âŸ‚)$.

Any $X âˆˆ {}^âŸ‚ (S^âŸ‚)$ is a summand of some $X' âˆˆ (ğ…ğ«ğğ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S))$.

This follows from the split ses $Ï„ _X$.

$$\begin{equation} (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)) = ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ âˆª \{S\}). \end{equation}$$

We show $âŠ‡$. When $M$ is filtrated by either $S$ or some free object $F$ in each step. We denote $M_{Î±} \overset {\boxed X} â†ª M_{Î± + 1}$ for the filtration step $(M_{Î± +1} / M_Î±) â‰ƒ X$. We construct $M' â†ª M â†  M''$ by inducting on the following cases:



Note that filtered colimits preserves exactness. Hence,

$$\begin{equation} 0 â†’ \varinjlim{}^{fil} M_Î³ ' â†’ \varinjlim{}^{fil} M_Î³ â†’ \varinjlim{}^{fil} M_Î³ '' â†’ 0 \end{equation}$$

If $X âˆˆ {}^âŸ‚(S^âŸ‚)$, then $Ï„ _X$ splits. Hence,

$$\begin{aligned} \ &ğ’ğ¦ğ (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)) = ğ’ğ¦ğ (ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ âˆª \{S\})) \\ = \ &ğ’ğ¦ğ (ğ…ğ«ğğ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)) = ğ’ğ¦ğ (ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (ğ…ğ«ğğ âˆª \{S\})) \end{aligned}$$

Therefore, one obtains ${}^âŸ‚ (S^âŸ‚ )$ from $S$ via either of the precedures



Reconstruction Lemma

We ask when a cotorsion theory (over $C(R)$) is cogenerated by a set $\mathcal{S}$ (or equivalently, a single element $âˆ \mathcal{S}$).

Once $(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{F})$ is cogenerated by a subset $\mathcal{S}$, we take $Îº _0 := |â‹ƒ \mathcal{S}|$. Now $(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{F})$ is cogenerated by $\{M âˆˆ \mathcal{C}âˆ£ |M| â‰¤ Îº _0\}$. Indeed,

  • The isomorphisms classs in $\{M âˆˆ \mathcal{C}âˆ£ |M| â‰¤ Îº _0\}$ form of a set. Given an infinite set $X$, the number of ordered $â„¤$-partition over $X$ is controlled by $|X|^{Ï‰}$. For each component $L$, the number of $R$-modules structures over over it is controlled by $|L|^{|R| â‹… |L|}$, as a module is characterised by a morphism of the type $R â†’ \mathrm{End}(L)$.

($Îº$-constructable). Say a class $\mathcal{X}$ is $Îº$-constructable, provided $$\begin{equation} \mathcal{X} = ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº}) := ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\{M âˆˆ \mathcal{X} âˆ£ |M| â‰¤ Îº\}). \end{equation}$$

(Reconstruction lemma). Let $\mathcal{X} âŠ† C(R)$ be a subclass such that

  1. $\mathcal{X}$ is closed under taking summands and filtrations;
  2. $\mathcal{X}$ consists of all $\{Î£ ^k (\overline R)\}_{k âˆˆ â„• }$;
  3. $\mathcal{X}$ is $Îº$-constructable for some cardinal $Îº$.

Then $(\mathcal{X}, \mathcal{X}^âŸ‚ )$ is a cotorsion pair cogenerated by a set.

$\mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº}$ is essentially a small set. Note that $\mathcal{X} âŠ† ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº})$. Taking $ğ…ğ¢ğ¥$ on both sides yields $ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\mathcal{X}) = ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº})$. Notice that

$$\begin{equation} {}^âŸ‚ ((\mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº})^âŸ‚ ) = ğ’ğ¦ğ (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº})) = ğ’ğ¦ğ (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ âˆ— ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\mathcal{X})) = \mathcal{X}. \end{equation}$$

By Galois connection, $\mathcal{X}^âŸ‚ = (\mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº})^âŸ‚$.

Kaplansky Class

In practice, it is hard to determine whether a class is $Îº$-constructable. The main obstackle is to determined whether the transfinite filtration terminates as

$$\begin{equation} M_{Î³} = M_{Î³ + 1} = \cdots \quad âŠŠ M. \end{equation}$$

We give a slightly stronger definition, which is called $Îº$-Kaplansky class.

($Îº$-Kaplansky class). A class $\mathcal{X}$ is called $Îº$-Kaplansky, provided for any $x âˆˆ M âˆˆ \mathcal{X}$, there is $x âˆˆ M' âŠ† M$ such that $M' âˆˆ \mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº}$ and $(M/M') âˆˆ \mathcal{X}$.

Clearly, $M$ in a $Îº$-Kaplansky class admits a transfinite $\mathcal{X}_{â‰¤ Îº}$-filtration with length $|M|$. In short, a $Îº$-Kaplansky class is a $Îº$-constructable class where the induction starts anywhere.

Show that $ğŒğ¨ğ_R$ is an $|R|$-Kaplansky class.

Acyclic Complexes

We denote $C_{ac}(R)$ or simply $C_{ac}$ as the class of acyclic complexes in $C(R)$. $C_{ac}$ is closed under symmetric opetations, e.g. taking extensions, summands, coproducts and products, transfinite filtrations and cofiltrations.

The symmetric behaviours are due to the cotorsion triple $({}^âŸ‚ C_{ac}, C_{ac}, C_{ac}^âŸ‚)$. Trivial examples of cotorsion triples includes $(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ , \mathcal{A}, ğˆğ§ğ£)$, and (over Frobenius category) $(\mathcal{A}, ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ , \mathcal{A})$.

For complexes, there are lots of good subcategories containing $ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ âˆª ğˆğ§ğ£$.

$({}^âŸ‚C_{ac}, C_{ac})$

We show that $({}^âŸ‚C_{ac}, C_{ac})$ is cogenerated by sets with a straightforward construction.

$\mathcal{S} := \{Î£ ^k (\underline R)\}_{k âˆˆ â„¤ }$ is cogenerates $({}^âŸ‚C_{ac}, C_{ac})$.

Recall that $Z^d (-) â‰ƒ (Î£ ^d (\underline R), -)$ has right derivation $\mathrm R^âˆ™ (Z^d) â‰ƒ H^{k+d}$. Hence $\mathcal{S}^âŸ‚ = C_{ac}$.

$(C_{ac}, C_{ac}^âŸ‚)$

We show that $(C_{ac}, C_{ac}^âŸ‚)$ is cogenerated by sets by showing that $C_{ac}$ is a $\max (Ï‰ , |R|)$-Kaplansky class.

For any $(x_n)_{n âˆˆ â„• } âˆˆ E âˆˆ C_{ac}$, there is a subcomplex $x âˆˆ E' âˆˆ (C_{ac})_{â‰¤ Îº}$. Here $Îº = \max (Ï‰ , |R|)$.

We construct first $Ï‰$ filtration of $E$ as follows $$\begin{equation} 0 = E_0 âŠ† E_1 âŠ† E_2 âŠ† \cdots âŠ† E_Ï‰ âŠ† E, \end{equation}$$

such that $|E_{n+1} / E_{n}| â‰¤ Îº$ and $E_Ï‰$ is acylic. We take $$\begin{equation} E_1 = [\cdots â†’ âŸ¨x^k, d(x^{k+1})âŸ© â†’ âŸ¨x^{k+1}, d(x^{k+2})âŸ© â†’ \cdots]. \end{equation}$$

We construct $E_{k+1}$ from $E_k$ s.t. $Z(E_{k}) âŠ† B(E_{k+1})$, thus $â‹ƒ_{k âˆˆ â„•} E_{k}$ is exact. We construct $Q^{p-1} â‰ƒ \mathrm{ker}(d_{E_k}^{p}) Ã— _{Z^p(E)} E^{p-1}$ by a pullback diagram



Here $Q^{p-1}$ reads the preimage of $\mathrm{ker}(d_{E_k}^{p})$ along $d_E^{p-1}$. It suffices to find $M âŠ† Q^{p-1}$ such that $$\begin{equation} |M| â‰¤ Îº , \quad (E_k)^{p-1} âŠ† Q^{p-1},\quad d_E^{p-1} (M) = \ker (d_{E_k}^p). \end{equation}$$ We take any subset $X^{p-1} âŠ† Q^{p-1}$ so that $X^{p-1} \overset âˆ¼ â†  \ker (d_{E^k}^p)$ is a bijection. Now $|âŸ¨X^{p-1}âŸ©| â‰¤ Îº â‹… Îº = Îº$. Now $M = E_{k+1}^{p-1} := ((E_k)^{p-1} + âŸ¨X^{p-1}âŸ©)$ is our desired construction. In particular $Z(E_k) = B(E_{k+1})$.

$(^{âŸ‚}(C_{ac}^âŸ‚ ), C_{ac}^âŸ‚)$ is a complete cotorsion pair cogenerated by a set.

Note that $C_{ac}$ is a $\max (Îº , Ï‰)$-Kaplansky class which contains all projective objects, and is closed under taking summands and transfinite filtrations.

One can similarly show that the DG-construction preserves completeness. Moreover, the construction preserves and reflects the hereditary cotorsion pairs (triples).

Cotorsion Triple

We are curious about the cotorsion triple $(^âŸ‚ (\mathcal{S}^âŸ‚), \mathcal{S}^âŸ‚ , (\mathcal{S}^âŸ‚ )^âŸ‚)$, where $\mathcal{S}^âŸ‚ = C_{ac}$. In fact, there are much more examples

  • $(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ , \mathcal{A}, ğˆğ§ğ£)$, the most elementary one. It is complete and hereditary.
  • $(\mathcal{G}\mathcal{P}, \mathcal{W}, \mathcal{G}\mathcal{P})$, aka the Gorenstein cotorsion triple, where $\mathcal{W} = \{M âˆ£ p.d. < âˆ\}$. The triple is complete and hereditary under some good conditions (e.g., $R$ is Iwanaga-Gorenstein).
  • $(\mathcal{D}\mathcal{P}, \mathcal{W}, \mathcal{D}\mathcal{I})$, aka the ä¸ cotorsion triple, where $\mathcal{W} = \{M âˆ£ f.d. < âˆ\}$. The triple is complete and hereditary over ä¸-é™ˆ ring.
  • â€¦

Relative DG

By a note on projectives in the end, we know that $^âŸ‚ (\mathcal{S}^âŸ‚)$ is the collection of DG-projective complexes with another two equivalent definitions

  1. The complex lifts surjective quasi-isomorphisms;
  2. The $K$-projective complex with projective terms.

Give equivalent definition of $(\mathcal{S}^âŸ‚ )^âŸ‚$, (called the DG-injective complexes).

J. Gillespie introduce introduce a procedure which construct cotorsion pairs in $C(R)$ from a cotorsion pair in $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$.

Let $(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{F})$ be a cotorsion pair over an Abelian category.

  1. ($\widetilde {\mathcal{C}}$). $\mathcal{C}$ complexes are those acyclic with boundaries in $\mathcal{C}$;
  2. ($\text{DG-}\widetilde {\mathcal{F}}$). DG-$\mathcal{C}$ complexes consist of $X âˆˆ C(\mathcal{C})$ such that $\mathcal{HOM}(X, F)$ is acyclic for all $\mathcal{F}$ complexes.

Notice that the cotorsion pair $(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ , \mathcal{A})$ creates two cotorsion theories:

  • $(\widetilde {ğğ«ğ¨ğ£}, \text{DG-}\widetilde {\mathcal{A}})$, which is $(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ (C(\mathcal{A})), \mathcal{A})$, and
  • $(\text{DG-}\widetilde {ğğ«ğ¨ğ£}, \widetilde {\mathcal{A}})$, which is $({}^âŸ‚ C_{ac}, C_{ac})$.

Show that the $\mathcal{F}$-complexes are precisely right othogonal to any of the following classes:

  1. all stalk complexes $\{Î£ ^d (\underline C) âˆ£ C âˆˆ \mathcal{C}, d âˆˆ â„¤\}$,
  2. all bounded complexes taking values in $\mathcal{C}$,
  3. all bounded below complexes taking values in $\mathcal{C}$,
  4. all DG-$\mathcal{C}$ complexes ($\text{DG-}\widetilde {C}$).

Moreover, show that $(\text{DG-}\widetilde {C}, \widetilde {\mathcal{F}})$ is a cotorsion pair.
Hint: the above generates the same cotorsion classes ($(\text{DG-}\widetilde {C})^âŸ‚$). By 4., and $\underline {(-)} âŠ£ Z^0 (-)$, we see $X âˆˆ \text{DG-}\widetilde {C}$ has cycles in $\mathcal{F}$. Deriving $Z^k (-)$, $X$ is acyclic. Clearly $(\text{DG-}\widetilde {C})^âŸ‚ = \widetilde {\mathcal{F}}$. Conversely, ${}^âŸ‚(\widetilde {\mathcal{F}})$ consists of complexes lifting epimorphisms with kernel in $\widetilde {\mathcal{F}}$. The analysis is similar to that in the note below.

C. H. Cotorsion Pair

(Hereditary). Say a cotorsion pair $(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{F})$ is hereditary, provided

  1. $\mathcal{C}$ is a resolving subcategory, i.e., contains projectives, closed under extensions, and closed under kernel of epimorphisms, and
  2. $\mathcal{F}$ is coresolving subcategory, i.e., contains injectives, closed under cokernels of monomorphisms, and closed under cokernel of monomorphisms.

Let $P$ be any property of cotorsion pair. Say the cotorsion triple $(\mathcal{A},\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C})$ is $P$, provided $(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B})$ is $P$ and $(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C})$ is $P$.

Show that $(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ , \mathcal{A}, ğˆğ§ğ£)$ is complete and hereditary.

  • Although the terminology hereditary originates from the vanishing of $\mathrm{Ext}^2$; it has nothing to do with the global dimension of $\mathcal{A}$.

There is a $1$-sided criterion for a complete cotorsion pair to be hereditary.

Let $(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{F})$ be a complete cotorsion pair. Then $\mathcal{C}$ is resolving iff $\mathcal{F}$ is coresolving.

We show â†’ only. Let $0 â†’ F_1 â†’ F_2 â†’ X â†’ 0$ be ses. We show that any ses $0 â†’ X â†’ A â†’ C â†’ 0$ splits. We complete the Noether square from the the compostion $A^C â†  A â†  C$. $C' âˆˆ \mathcal{C}$ by assumption. Then we denote $Î´ âˆˆ \mathrm{Ext}^1(C,C')$ and $q_âˆ— Î´ âˆˆ \mathrm{Ext}^1(C,X)$.



We notice that $(C', F_2) â†’ (C', X) â†’ \mathrm{Ext}^1(C', F_1) = 0$. Hence $q$ we can write $q : [X' \xrightarrow a F_2 \xrightarrow b X]$. Clearly $a_âˆ— Î´ âˆˆ \mathrm{Ext}^1 (C, F_2)= 0$. We obtain $q_âˆ— Î´ = 0$.

Recall that $\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{A}/Ï‰ }(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{F}) = 0$. For hereditary cases,

$$\begin{equation} \ker \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{A}/Ï‰ }(\mathcal{C}, - ) = \mathcal{F}, \quad \ker \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{A}/Ï‰ }(-, \mathcal{F}) = \mathcal{C}. \end{equation}$$

We show $âŠ†$ part of the second identity only. Suppose that any $X â†’ F$ factors through $Ï‰$. We consider the induced dashed ses



$Q âˆˆ \mathcal{F}$ as $(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{F})$ is hereditary. By assumption, $q$ factors through $W âˆˆ Ï‰$. Since $W âˆˆ \mathcal{C}$, $q$ factors through $p$. Now $X âˆˆ ğ’ğ¦ğ (X^C) âŠ† \mathcal{C}$.

Under some good conditions, $(\mathcal{C} , \mathcal{F})$ is a torsion theory in $\mathcal{A} / Ï‰$.

C. H. Cotorsion Triple

Suppose that $(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B}, \mathcal{C})$ is a complete cotorsion triple. Then,

  1. it is hereditary iff $\mathcal{B}$ is closed thick subcategory of $\mathcal{A}$, i.e., closed under taking summands, two-out-three property of ses (extensions, kernel of epimorphisms, and cokernel of monomorphisms);
  2. $\mathcal{A} âˆ© \mathcal{B} = ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$, and $\mathcal{B} âˆ© \mathcal{C} = ğˆğ§ğ£$.

We mentioned that, there is no need to assume $\mathcal{A}$ to have enough $ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$ or $ğˆğ§ğ£$.

$1$ is clear by one-sided definition of complete hereditary cotorsion pair.
For $2$., we show any $T âˆˆ \mathcal{A} âˆ© \mathcal{B}$ is projective. Any ses $0 â†’ M â†’ N â†’ T â†’ 0$ admits a diagram



Since $\mathcal{B}$ is thick, $E âˆˆ \mathrm{coCone}(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{B}) = \mathcal{B}$. Since $\mathrm{Ext}^1(T,E) = 0$, pushing out $q$ yields the original split ses.

There are some connections between $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{C}$. We commence with the definition of left approximations, or preenvelopes.

(Left approximation = preenvelope). Let $\mathcal{E}$ be a class (closed under isomorphisms). For any $E âˆˆ \mathcal{E}$ and arbitrary $X$, a morphism $Ï† : X â†’ E$ is called a left $\mathcal{E}$-approximation, or an $\mathcal{E}$-preenvelope, provided it the following equivalent conditions:

  1. any $Ï†' : X â†’ E'$ extends along $Ï†$,
  2. the natural transformation $Ï† ^âˆ— : (E, -)_\mathcal{E} â†  (X, (-)|_{\mathcal{E}})_\mathcal{A}$ is a projective precover.

Show that for complete cotorsion pair $(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{F})$, any $X$ admits

  • a left $\mathcal{F}$-approximation ($X â†’ X_F \ \color{grey}{â‡¢ X_C}$), and
  • a right $\mathcal{C}$-approximation (${\color{grey}{X^F â‡¢}} \ X^C â†’ X$).

Such approximations are special due to their (co)kernels. Moreover, show that

  • any left $\mathcal{F}$-approximation $Ï† : M â†’ F$ has a summand $i _F : M â†ª M_F$,
  • any right $\mathcal{C}$-approximation $Ïˆ : C â†’ N$ has a summand $p_C : N^C â†  N$.

Now we characterise $\mathcal{A}$ with the lifting property of left $\mathcal{C}$-approximations, and vise versa.

Let $(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B}, \mathcal{C})$ be a complete hereditary cotorsion triple. Then $X âˆˆ \mathcal{A}$ iff

  • for any monic left $\mathcal{C}$ approximation $Ï† : M â†ª C$, any morphism $f : X â†’ \operatorname{cok}(Ï†)$ lifts along $C â†  \operatorname{cok}(Ï†)$.

(â†’). Consider the commutative diagram of ses



Since $X âˆˆ \mathcal{A}$, the morphism $X â†’ \operatorname{cok}(i) â†’ M_B$ factors through some $P âˆˆ \mathcal{A} âˆ© \mathcal{B}$. The lifting property yields $P â†’ M_C$. A pullback diagram yields $X â†’ C$.
(â†). We show that for any such $X$, ses $0 â†’ B â†’ E â†’ X â†’ 0$ splits. Notice that $\mathcal{B} âˆ© \mathcal{C} = ğˆğ§ğ£$, we have the commutative diagram of sesï¼š



Notice that $i$ is induced by lifting property of $ğˆğ§ğ£$, $j$ is induced by cokernel. The right square is both a pullback and pushout. By property of $X$, there is a dashed arrow $s$. Hence $0 â†’ B â†’ E â†’ X â†’ 0$ splits.

Throughout, we make no assumption that the category has enough projectives or injectives. However, for a complete hereditary cotorsion triple $(\mathcal{A},\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C})$, there are enough projectives for $\mathcal{A}$, and enough injectives for $\mathcal{C}$.

A Note on Resolutions

The objects in ${}^âŸ‚C_{ac}$ has the name dg-projective, Dold projective, homotopically projective objects, etc. We summarise projective related definitions in this note.

The Definitions

(Projective complex). $C(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£(\mathcal{A}))$, the complex with projective terms.

($ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ (C(\mathcal{A}))$). The projective objects in $C(\mathcal{A})$ are precisely the split acyclic projective complexes.

$âŠ‡$ is clear. For $âŠ†$, the split ses $0 â†’ P â†’ \mathrm{Cone}(1_P) â†’ Î£ P â†’ 0$ shows $P â‰ƒ 0$ in $K(\mathcal{A})$. An termwise verification yields $P$ is has projective terms.

Show the complex $\cdots \xrightarrow {Ã— 2}â„¤ / 4â„¤ \xrightarrow {Ã— 2}â„¤ / 4â„¤ â†’ \cdots$ in $C(â„¤ / 4â„¤)$ is acyclic with projective terms, but it is not a projective object.

Show that $\mathcal{HOM}(X,-) : K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ K(ğ€ğ›)$ is well-defined. Hint: show that

$$\begin{equation} C(\mathcal{A}) \xrightarrow{\mathcal{HOM}(X,-)} C(ğ€ğ›) â†  K(ğ€ğ›),\quad C_{\text{null homo}} â†¦ 0. \end{equation}$$

This shows that $(K(\mathcal{A}), âŠ— ,\mathcal{HOM})$ is again closed monoidal.

($K$-projective). $K$-projective complexes are defined in $K(\mathcal{A})$ with the following equivalent conditions:

  1. $\mathcal{HOM}(P, - ): K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ K(ğ€ğ› )$ preserves acyclic complexes;
  2. $\mathcal{HOM}(P, - ): K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ K(ğ€ğ› )$ preserves quasi-isomorphisms;
  3. $H^k (\mathcal{HOM}(P, - )) : K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ ğ€ğ›$ sends quasi-isomorphisms to isomorphisms for each/some $k âˆˆ â„¤$;
  4. $H^k (\mathcal{HOM}(P, -)) : K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ ğ€ğ›$ annihilates acyclic complexes for each/some $k âˆˆ â„¤$.

We use either each/some in the last two statemtents, as $Î£^Â±$ preserves and reflects quasi-isomorphisms and acyclic complexes.

(1 â†’ 2). Note that any quasi-isomorphsm $f$ fits into a distinguished triangle $â‹… \xrightarrow f â‹… â†’ \mathrm{Cone}(f)$. Applying $\mathcal{HOM}(P, - )$ yields the long exact sequence. Since $\mathcal{HOM}(P, \mathrm{Cone}(f))$ is acyclic, $\mathcal{HOM}(P, f)$ is a quasi-isomorphism.
(2 â†’ 3). Taking $H^k$ kills the statement.
(3 â†’ 4). Notice that $E$ is acyclic iff $0 â†’ E$ is an quasi-isomorphism.
(4 â†’ 1). For any acyclic complex $E$, $H^âˆ™ \mathcal{HOM}(P, E) â‰¡ 0$. Hence $\mathcal{HOM}(P, E)$ is acyclic.

($Ï€$-projective). A complex $P âˆˆ C(\mathcal{A})$ is called $Ï€$-projective, provided it is $K$-projective in $K(\mathcal{A})$.

  • Note that $P$ is $Ï€$-projective iff $\mathcal{HOM}(P, -) : C(\mathcal{A}) â†’ C(ğ€ğ›)$ preserves either all quasi-isomorphisms or all acyclic complexes.

(Easy). Find a $Ï€$-projective complex with no projective terms.

(DG-projective). A complex $P$ is called DG-projective, provided the following equivalent conditions hold:

  1. $(P, -)_{C(\mathcal{A})} : C(\mathcal{A}) â†’ ğ€ğ›$ lifts epic quasi-isomorphisms;
  2. $P$ is $Ï€$-projective with projective terms;
  3. $\mathrm{Ext}^1(P, E) = 0$ for acyclic complexes $E$.

(1 â†’ 3). Every ses in $\mathrm{Ext}^1(P, E)$ splits.
(3 â†’ 2). We show $P$ has projective terms. If $P^1$ is not projective, then there is a non-split ses $0 â†’ E â†’ T â†’ P^1 â†’ 0$. Hence we have



Here $T \times _{P^1}P^0$ is pullback, and the dashed arrow $P^{-1} â†’ T \times _{P^1}P^0$ is induced by $d_P^{-1}$ and $0_{T,P^{-1}}$.
We also show $P$ is $Ï€$-projective, i.e., $(P, C)_{K(\mathcal{A})} = 0$ for any acyclic complex $C$. We pullback the partial projective resolution $0 â†’ Î© (C) â†’ P(C) â†’ C â†’ 0$ along any $Ï† : P â†’ C$. Since $Î© (C)$ is acyclic, the pullback ses splits. Thus $Ï†$ factors through $P(C)$, which is the zero object in $K(\mathcal{A})$.
(2 â†’ 1). For any epic quasi-isomorphism $p : A â†  B$ and $f : P â†’ B$, we have the pullback ses $0 â†’ \ker p â†’ P Ã— _BA â†’ P â†’ 0$ which

  • split termwise ($(P^i)$â€™s are projective), and
  • $P Ã— _BA â†’ P$ is a homotopy equivalence ($P$ is $K$-projective in $K(\mathcal{A})$).

By homotopy invariance of ses, it splits.

Resolutions ($K^-(ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ£)$)

We begin with resolution of chain complex bounded above.

Let $X âˆˆ C^-(\mathcal{A})$ be a complex bounded above. Then $X$ has a projective resolution.

By Eilenburg-Cartan resolution, we obtain a locally finite double complex with projective terms and exact columns. The total complex ($âˆ$) is again exact and quasi-isomorphic to $X$.

There is ususall no easy constructions for unbounded complexes. We enumerate some special cases.

  1. If an unbounded chain complex has uniform projective/injective dimensions, then Eilenberg-Cartan resolution yields a projective/injective resolution, as the total complex is locally finite.
  2. By Chaseâ€™s theorem, $R$ is right perfect and left coherent if and only if projective right modules are closed under $âˆ$. In this case, we take Eilenberg-Cartan resolution of an unbounded chain complex $P^{âˆ™ , âˆ™ } â†  X^âˆ™$, then $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ (P) â†  X$ is a projective resolution.
  3. By a well-known characterisation of Noetherian rings, we take Eilenberg-Cartan coresolution of an unbounded chain complex $X^âˆ™ â†ª I^{âˆ™ , âˆ™ }$, then $X â†ª \mathrm{Tot}^{âˆ }(I)$ is an injective resolution.

For acyclic complex $C$ and projective complex $P$, if either one is bounded above, then $(P,C)_{K(\mathcal{A})} = 0$.

Let $f : P â†’ C$ be such chain map. Say $f$ is ok for $k$, when there is $s^{â‰¥ k}$ s.t. $f^l = ds^{l}+s^{l+1}d$ for all $l â‰¥ k$. By assumption $f$ is ok for large $k$. We show $f$ is ok for $k-1$ when it is ok for $k$.



We construct $s^{k-1} : P^{k-1} â†’ C^{k-2}$ as follows. The morphism $Î” := (f^{k-1} - s^k d_P^{k-1})$ belongs to $\ker d_X^{k-1}$, thus $Î”$ factors through $B^{k-1}(C)$. We take $s^{k-1} : P^{k-1} â†’ C^{k-2}$ by lifting property of projectives.

We denote $K^-(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$ the subcategory of $K(\mathcal{A})$ consisting of projective complexes bounded above.

  • The minus $(â‹… )^-$ means $X âˆˆ K^- (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$ almost lies in the negative part.

For Abelian category $\mathcal{A}$ with enough projectives,

  1. Quasi-isomorphisms in $K^-(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$ are precisely homotopy equivalences;
  2. Every $X âˆˆ K^-(\mathcal{A})$ admits a $K^- (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$-replacement $Ï X$ with epic quasi-isomorphism $c_X : Ï X â†  X$;
  3. It is possible to let $Ï$ be a triangulated functor right adjoint to the inclusion $K^-(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ ) â†ª K^-(\mathcal{A})$;
  4. $K^-(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$ are exactly the DG-projective complexes bounded above.

(1). Let $f : P â†’ Q$ be a quasi-isomorphism in $K^-(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$. Since $Q â†ª \mathrm{Cone}(f)$ is null-homotopic, $f$ is a homotopy equivalence.
(2). We take Cartan-Eilenburg resolution $c_X : ÏX â†  X$, which is assumed to be functorial by axiom of choice. In particular, $c_P : ÏP â†  P$ is a canonical isomorphim. The replacement means the natural isomorphism $(c_X)_âˆ— : (P, Ï X)_{K^-(ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ )} â‰ƒ (P, X)_{K^-(\mathcal{A})}$. This is due to $(P, \mathrm{Cone}(c_X)) = 0$.
(3). We show that $Ï$ is an additive functor right adjoint to the inclusion. The inclusion is triangle functor. By adjoint functor theorem, $Ï$ is also triangulated.
(4). We show that $P âˆˆ K^- (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$ is $K$-injective with projective terms. Hence it is DG-projective.

The following exercises requires some techniques of diagram chasing.

We know that $P âˆˆ C^- (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$ lifts epic quesiisomorphisms.

  1. For general $Q âˆˆ C (ğğ«ğ¨ğ£)$ and $Y âˆˆ C^- (\mathcal{A})$, show that any epic quasi-isomorphism $p : X â†  Y$ is lifted by $P$.
  2. Show the natural isomorphism: $$\begin{equation} \{f âˆˆ (X,Y) âˆ£ \text{epic quasi-iso.}\} \overset{1:1}â†” \{\widetilde {f} âˆˆ (X, (\operatorname{cok} (X)) Ã—_{\operatorname{cok} (Y)} Y) âˆ£ \text{epic}\}. \end{equation}$$

Resolutions via Brownâ€™s Rep

We discuss the projective resolutions of general Abelian category with exact arbitrary coproducts (AB3, AB3*) and a projective generator $U$ (e.g. $R$ for $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$).

Show the following properties of projective generators.

  • $(U, -)$ preserves and reflect exactness (e.g. monomorphisms and epimorphisms),
  • Moreover, if $Î¹ : L â†ª X$ is monic and $(U, Î¹)$ is an isomorphism, then $Î¹$ is an isomorphism. Hint: consider the pair of morphisms $\binom Ï€ 0 : X â‡‰ X / L$, where $Î¹ âˆ˜ Ï€ = Î¹ âˆ˜ 0$.
  • Show that the subobjects of $X$ form a set. Hint: $(U, -) : ğ’ğ®ğ› (X) â†’ ğ’ğ®ğ› ((U,X))$ is a strict inclusion. The latter is a set.

The latter two have nothing to do with projective.

The discussion are based on Brownâ€™s representability.

Unwinding its existence, we denote $K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}}$ as the class of projective resolutions of $K(\mathcal{A})$. We wish there is still a functor $Ï : K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}}$ right adjoint to the inclusion $K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}} â†ª K(\mathcal{A})$. That is,

$$\begin{equation} (i(-), Y) : K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}} â†’ ğ€ğ› \end{equation}$$

is represented by some $Ï Y$.

$\underline U$ is the perfect generator of the additive full subcategory $\mathrm{Loc}(\underline U)$.

  • $\mathrm{Loc}(\underline U)$ is the smallest triangulated category generated by $U$ under $Î£ ^Â±$, $âˆ$ and $âˆ—$.
  • $U$ is perfect in $\mathcal{T}$, provided $\mathrm{Loc}(\underline U) = \mathcal{T}$, and $(\underline U, âˆ _{i âˆˆ I} f_i)$ is surjection when every $(\underline U, f_i)$ is surjective.

(PG1). We show for any set of morphisms $f_i : A_i â†’ B_i$ with $(\underline U,f_i)$ surjective, the morphism $(\underline U, âˆ f_i)$ is again surjective. Note that

$$\begin{aligned} (\underline U, âˆ f_i)_{K(\mathcal{A})} &â‰ƒ ( U, H^0(âˆ (f_i)))_\mathcal{A} \overset {\text{Ab3*}}â‰ƒ (U, âˆ H^0(f_i))_\mathcal{A}\quad \text{is surj.}\\[6pt] & â†” âˆ H^0(f_i) \quad \text{is surj.}\\[6pt] & â†” \{H^0(f_i)\}_{i âˆˆ I} \quad \text{are surj.}\\[6pt] & â†” \{(U, H^0(f_i))_\mathcal{A}\}_{i âˆˆ I} \quad \text{are surj.}\\[6pt] & â†” âˆ (U, H^0(f_i))_\mathcal{A} â‰ƒ âˆ (\underline U, f_i)_{K(\mathcal{A})} \quad \text{is surj.}. \end{aligned}$$

(PG2). $\mathrm{Loc}(\underline U) = \mathrm{Loc}(\underline U)$ is clear.

We set $K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}} := \mathrm{Loc}(\underline U)$.

$i : K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}} â†ª K(\mathcal{A})$ admits a right adjoint $Ï : K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}}$, which is triangulated.

For any $X âˆˆ K(\mathcal{A})$, the functor $(i(-), X)_{K(\mathcal{A})} : K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}}^{\mathrm{op}} â†’ ğ€ğ›$ is cohomological, and sends $âˆ$ to $âˆ$. By functorial construction of Brownâ€™s representability, there is a natural isomorphism

$$\begin{equation} (-, Ï X)_{K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}}} â‰ƒ (i(-), X)_{K_{\mathrm{h \ proj}}} \end{equation}$$

Semi-(DG-)free Complexes

We have shown the existence and some functorial properties of DG complexes. A DG-projective complex $P$ has the following equivalent definitions:

  1. For any epic quasi-isomorphism $f$, then $(P, f)$ is a surjection.
  2. $\mathrm{Ext}^1(P,E) = \mathrm{Ext}^1_{dw}(P,E) = (P, Î£ E)_{K(\mathcal{A})} = 0$ for any acyclic $E$.
  3. $\mathcal{HOM}(P, -)$ preserves acyclic complexes, and quasi-isomorphisms.
  4. $\mathcal{HOM}(P, -)$ preserves exact sequences, and quasi-isomorphisms.
  5. Any surjective quasi-isomorphism (aka resolution) $f : P â†’ X$ is a homotopy equivalence, and $P$ has projective terms.
  6. â€¦

In early study of DG-algebra, the prefix DG- is replaced by semi-.

(Revised definition). Let $ğ”‰$ denote the collection of stalk complexes with free terms. Say $X$ is semi-free, provided $X âˆˆ ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (ğ”‰)$.

Semi-free complexes are DG-projective complexes with free terms.

Clearly $ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (ğ”‰) âŠ† {}^âŸ‚C_{ac}$. It remains to show semi-free modules has free terms. By termwise analysis, we show a transfinite filtration of free modules are free. For any free filtration

$$\begin{equation} 0 = F_0 âŠ† F_1 âŠ† \cdots âŠ† F_Î³ âŠ† \cdots F_Î± \end{equation}$$

We show the statement $P_Î³ : [F_{Î³} = âˆ _{Î² < Î³}\frac{F_{Î² + 1}}{F_Î² }]$ holds for all ordinals $Î³ â‰¤ Î±$.
(Initial). Clearly $F_1 = F_1 / 0$.
(Successor). Assume $P_Î³$ holds, then split ses shows $F_{Î³ + 1} = F_{Î³} âŠ• \frac{F_{Î³ +1}}{F_{Î³}}$. Hence $P_{Î³ + 1}$ holds.
(Limit). Assume $P_Î³$ holds for all $Î³ < Î²$ wherein $Î²$ is a limit ordinal. We see

$$\begin{equation} F_Î² = \varinjlim_{Î³ < Î² } \left[\frac{F_1}{0} \xrightarrow {\binom 10} \frac{F_1}{0} âˆ \frac{F_2}{F_1} \xrightarrow {\binom 10} \frac{F_1}{0} âˆ \frac{F_2}{F_1} âˆ \frac{F_2}{F_2} \xrightarrow {\binom 10} \cdots \right]. \end{equation}$$

Clearly, $âˆ _{Î³ <Î² } \frac{F_{Î³ + 1}}{F_Î³ }$ is also the colimit of this system.

Show that the above filtration can be deformed into a countable filtration.

Corollary, DG-projective complexes are exactly the summand of semi-free complexes. It suffices to use countable cardinal to characterise DG-projective complexes in sense of homotopy colimit.

We show some examples of DG-projective complexes.

  1. All projective complexes bounded above are DG-projective.
  2. The tensor product of two DG-projective complexes is DG-projective.
  3. Doldâ€™s well-known example $\cdots â†’ â„¤ / 4â„¤ \xrightarrow {Ã— 2} â„¤ / 4â„¤â†’ \cdots$ is NOT DG-projective.

DG-Flat

(DG-Flat). Say $F$ is a DG-flat complex, provided the following equivalent consitions.

  1. $F âŠ— -$ preserves monic quasi-isomorphisms;
  2. $F âŠ— -$ preserves exact sequences, and quasi-isomorphisms.

Show the following properties of DG-flat complexes.

  1. Any complex in $C^- (ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ )$ is DG-flat.
  2. The tensor product of two DG-flat complexes is again DG-flat.
  3. $F$ is DG-flat iff $F^+$ is DG-injective.

For the subcategory of DG-projective (resp. DG-injective) complexes, quasi-isomorphisms are precisely homotopy equivalence. This no longer holds for DG-flat complexes.

Let $Ï† : F â†’ F'$ be a quasi-isomorphisms between DG-flat complexes. Then

  • $Ï† ^+$ is a homotopy equivalence, i.e., $s : Ï†^+ âˆ¼ 0$.
  • Note that $(X âŠ— Ï†)^+ = (X, Ï† ^+)$ is a homotopy equivalence. Both $(X âŠ— Ï† )$ and $(Ï† âŠ— Y)$ are quasi-isomorphisms.
  • $Ï†$ is not necessary a homotopy equivalence, since $s$ does not take the form $t^+$ in general.

For example, we take bounded DG-flat complexes

  • $X = [\cdots â†’ 0 â†’ â„¤ â†ª â„š â†’ 0 â†’ \cdots ]$, and
  • $Y = [\cdots â†’ 0 â†’ â„š / â„¤ â†’ 0 â†’ \cdots ]$.

The quasi-isomorphism $X â†  Y$ is not a homotopy equivalence.

Derived Category and Its Closed Monoidal Structure

This is an easy approach to derived category, as X.W. Chen mentioned that

$$\begin{equation} \boxed{\text{resolutions make life easier, but not really easier}} \end{equation}$$

We explain derived functors $\mathrm R^âˆ™ \mathcal{HOM}(-, ?)$ and $\mathrm L_âˆ™ (- âŠ— ?)$ in DG-complexes. We write $ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}$ and $âŠ—^ğ‹$ for simplicity.

The functors are defined for general Abelian categories with enough projectives and injectives. We talk about $C(R)$ ($R$ commutative) only.

The right derived Hom-functor is defined as the endofunctor $$\begin{equation} ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}(M, -) := \mathcal{HOM}(ÏM, -) : D(R) â†’ D(R). \end{equation}$$

where $ÏM â†  M$ is chosen as a functorial resolution of $M$.

The above $ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}(M, -)$ is a well-defined triangle functor.

The assignment $C(R) â†’ C(R) â†’ D(R)$, $X â†¦ \mathcal{HOM}(ÏM, X)$ is uniquely defined.
To see this passing through the localisation $C(R) â†’ D(R)$, any quasi-isomorphism $f$ yields $\mathcal{HOM}(ÏM, f)$, which is again a quasi-isomorphism as $Ï M$ is DG-projective.
$\mathcal{HOM}(Ï M, -)$ is a triangle functor, since it preserves $\mathrm{Cone}$.

We also define $ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}$ from injective coresolution. $ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}(X, ?)(Y) â‰ƒ ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}(-, Y)(X)$ comes from the functorial quasi-isomorphisms in $C(R)$:

$$\begin{equation} \mathcal {HOM}(\rho M, N) â†’ \mathcal {HOM}(\rho M, \iota N) â† \mathcal{HOM}(M,\iota N). \end{equation}$$

Define and show the balance of derived tensor product

$$\begin{equation} (- âŠ— ^ğ‹ Y)(X) = X âŠ— Ï Y \xrightarrow[âˆ¼ ]{â‹†} Ï X âŠ— Y \xrightarrow[âˆ¼ ]{â‹†^{-1}} (X âŠ— ^ğ‹ ?)(Y) \end{equation}$$

One can use Yoneda lemma to see $(X âŠ— \mathrm{Cone}(f), -) â‰ƒ (\mathrm{Cone}(X âŠ— f), -)$.

  • Explain flat-resolution fails in $â‹†$, while the projective resolution works well.

One can also conclude some natural isomorphisms, inhererited from the closed monoidal structures of $C(R)$.

(Attempt). Once you attempt to show the monoidal structure of $D(R)$, you fails to show the identity $Ï (X âŠ— ^L Y) = Ï X âŠ— Ï Y$. This makes $(D(R), âŠ— ^L, \underline R)$ a lax monoidal category.

  • Thanks to MacLane, there is a way (possibly by a complicated conjugation) to reform the strict structure from the lax one.

We seek for a direct ways to obtain the strict monoidal structure of $D(R)$. Consider the quasi-isomorphisms:

$$\begin{equation} Ï (X âŠ— ^ğ‹ Y) = Ï (X âŠ— Ï Y) â† Ï (Ï X âŠ— Ï Y) \overset {c} â†’ ÏX âŠ— ÏY. \end{equation}$$

Note that $ÏX âŠ— ÏY$ is again DG-projective.

(The symmetric derived tensor). We redefine the assignment

$$\begin{equation} X âŠ—^L Y := Ï X âŠ— Ï Y\quad (\xrightarrow[âˆ¼ ] {c} Ï (Ï X âŠ— Ï Y)). \end{equation}$$

Set $Î± ^Ï = (c âŠ— 1)^{-1} âˆ˜ Î± âˆ˜ (1 âŠ— c)$. The rule of associativity writes



(The pentagon rule). Consider the identity in $C(R)$:

$$\begin{equation} (Î± _{X,Y,Z} âŠ— W) âˆ˜ (Î± _{X, Y âŠ— Z, W}) âˆ˜ (X âŠ— Î± _{Y, Z, W}) = (Î± _{XâŠ— Y, Z,W}) âˆ˜ (Î± _{X,Y,Z âŠ— W}). \end{equation}$$

We apply $(-)^Ï$ on both sides, and show

$$\begin{equation} (Î±^Ï _{X,Y,Z} âŠ—^ğ‹ W) âˆ˜ (Î±^Ï _{X, Y âŠ—^ğ‹ Z, W}) âˆ˜ (X âŠ—^ğ‹ Î±^Ï _{Y, Z, W}) = (Î±^Ï _{X âŠ—^ğ‹ Y, Z,W}) âˆ˜ (Î±^Ï _{X,Y,Z âŠ—^ğ‹ W}). \end{equation}$$

(The unit). $Ï (\underline R)$ is the unit in $D(R)$ with the (left) identity rule

$$\begin{equation} l_X^Ï : \underline R âŠ—^ğ‹ X = Ï \underline R âŠ— Ï X \xrightarrow [âˆ¼ ]{c âŠ— 1} \underline R âŠ— Ï X\xrightarrow {Î»} ÏX \xrightarrow [âˆ¼ ]{c} X. \end{equation}$$

Now feel free to verify $(D(R), âŠ— ^ğ‹ , \underline R)$ is closed monoidal. For instance, we verify the pentagon diagram of left unit,



with the commutative diagram



Here all parallel line with the same colour yields gives the commutative square by functoriality. $\blacktriangle$ is by definition, $â˜…$ is given by the monoidal structure of $C(R)$.

(Lax monoidal functor). Recall that we define the functor of resolution $Ï : D(R) â†’ K(R)$ with axiom of choice of the class. This extends to a lax monoidal functor

$$\begin{equation} Ï : (D(R), âŠ— ^ğ‹ , \underline R) â†’ (K(R), âŠ— , \underline R) \end{equation}$$

consisting of

  • a functorial assignment $X â†¦ Ï X$,
  • a natural transformation $Îµ : ÏX â†’ X$,
  • a natural transformation $Î¼ : Ï (X âŠ—^ğ‹ Y) â†’ Ï X âŠ— Ï Y$,

which preserves the associativity and unit rules.

  • The natural transformation $Îµ$ and $Î¼$ are isomorphisms in $D(R)$.
  • The word lax means not strict. It has nothing to do with Peter Lax.

We then proceed to the symmetric structure.

Note the isomorphism

$$\begin{equation} Ï„ ^Ï : X âŠ— ^ğ‹ Y = Ï (Ï X âŠ— Ï Y) \xrightarrow {Ï Ï„ _{Ï X, Ï Y}} Ï (Ï Y âŠ— Ï X) = Y âŠ— ^ğ‹ X. \end{equation}$$

One can verify the hexagon rule and the unit rule are satisfied.

$ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}$ is precisely the internal Hom of the symmetric monoidal category $(D(R), âŠ— ^ğ‹ , \underline R)$.

Recall the definiton $ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom} (-, ?) := \mathcal{HOM}(Ï (-), ?)$. A direct computation shows

$$\begin{aligned} & ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}(X âŠ—^ğ‹ Y, Z) = \mathcal{HOM}(Ï X âŠ— Ï Y, Z) \\[6pt] â‰ƒ \ & \mathcal{HOM}(Ï X ,\mathcal{HOM}(Ï Y, Z)) = ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}(X, ğ‘ \mathrm{Hom}(Y,Z)). \end{aligned}$$

Moreover, there is also finiteness conditions as we discussed in Lec0.

item.title: CT1
item.description:
• Lecture 1
    • Abstract
  • On Orthogonality
    • $âŸ‚$ for Objects
    • $â‹”$ for Morphisms
    • Complete Cotorsion Pair
  • Small Objects
    • Ordinals and Cardinals
    • Cofinality, and Small
    • Eklof-Trlifaj Lemma

Lecture 1

Abstract

During the initial few lectures, we follow RHA-1 and RHA-2.

The main theorem of this lecture is Eklof-Trlifajâ€™s theorem, which states that a cotorsion pair over $C(R)$ cogenerated by a set is complete; our proof is anagolous to Quillenâ€™s small object argument. We subsequently provide some criterion on determining whether a cotorsion pair is cogenerated by a set.

On Orthogonality

Cotorsion theory is usuall established over a category with good extension functor, e.g., triangulated categories, exact categories or simply Abelian categories. A generalisation is external triangulated categories. We denote $\mathcal{A}$ as a general Abelian category.

Recall that

  • Grothendieckâ€™s insight was to put emphasis on studying the morphisms between schemes as opposed to just the schemes by themselves.

In short, morphisms are the first-class citizens in category theory. Once we generalise the ideal of $\mathrm{Ext}$ to morphisms, we see that it is indeed a weak orthogonality.

The followings has to do with the concept of factorisation systems (FS), which provides a way of viewing category $\mathcal{C}$ as a compositional product of two classes of morphisms $\mathcal{L}$ and $\mathcal{R}$. The key requirements are the lifting property (weak orthogonality) and the (functorial) factorisation property.

Small Objects

Ordinals and Cardinals

We highlight a subtle point in the study of well-ordered sets (by the axiom of choice, every set may be well-ordered). A well-ordered set $(X, â‰¤)$ is totally ordered; that is, for any $i, j âˆˆ X$, one has $i â‰¤ j$ or $j â‰¤ i$. Zornâ€™s lemma demonstrates that an infinite strictly descending chain is prohibited; specifically, there is no $\cdots â‰¨ i_2 â‰¨ i_1 â‰¨ i_0$ in a well-ordered set. In particular, $(â„š, â‰¤)$ is not well-ordered.

We define ordinals and cardinals in the sense of J. von Neumann. For simplicity, we introduce neither ordinal arithmetic nor universe.

(Ordinal). The collection of ordinals refers to (a skeleton of) the category of well-ordered sets under the usual set-theoretic axioms favoured by algebraists. Inductively, any ordinal is obtained by the following procedures:

  2. for any ordinal $Î±$, the successor ordinal is defined as $Î±^+ := Î± âŠ” \{Î±\}$;
  3. if there exists a set of oridnals $S$, such that $0 âˆˆ S$ and $(Î² âˆˆ S) â†’ (Î² ^+ âˆˆ S)$, then we define $Î± = â‹ƒ S$ as a limit ordinal.

The existence of limit ordinal is clear. If we assume $n^+ = n+1$ for $n âˆˆ â„•$, then $Ï‰ = â„•$ is the first limit oridnal.

Hence, there exist non-$Ï‰$-filtered ordinals. One may consult this interesting example for deeper understanding.

The following corollary motivates the concept of small.

Let $Î±$ be $Îº$-filtered. For any set $X$ with $|X| = Îº$, and

  • for any $Î±$-transfinite composition of morphisms, i.e., a colimit-preserving functor $Y_âˆ™ : Î± â†’ \mathcal{C}$.

Then, any set map $Ï† : X â†’ \varinjlim Y_âˆ™$ factors through some $Y_Î³$.

For any $x âˆˆ X$, $Ï† |_x : x â†’ \varinjlim Y_âˆ™$ factors through some $Y_{Î³ _x}$. Select $x â†¦ Y_{Î³ _x}$ for arbitrary $x âˆˆ X$, which defines a map $Î³ _âˆ™ : X â†’ Î±$. By definition, $\sup (\operatorname{im}(Î³ _âˆ™ )) âˆˆ Î±$. Hence, $Ï†$ factors through $Y_{\sup (\operatorname{im}(Î³ _âˆ™ ))}$.

(Small object). Say $X$ is $Îº$-small if, for any $Îº$-filtered ordinals and $Î±$-transfinite compositions, the following is an isomorphism:

$$\begin{equation} \varinjlim _{Î³ < Î± } (X, Y_Î³ ) \xrightarrow âˆ¼ (X, \varinjlim _{Î³ < Î± } Y_Î³ ). \end{equation}$$

We have demonstrated that any set $X$ is $|X|$-small.

Demonstrate that $X âˆˆ C(R)$ is $\max (|X|, |R|, Ï‰)$-small. Hint: It suffices to show for graded modules, and thus for $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$. Note that $M âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ_R$ is $|R| â‹… |X|$-small by tracking the image of cyclic modules. The final answer is $|X| â‹… |R| â‹… Ï‰ = \max (|X|, |R|, Ï‰)$.

It appears that in good categories, every object is small (with respect to some cardinal). The following example shows that, in certain problematic categories, finite objects may not be small.

We begin with two kinds of topological spaces.

  • A SierpiÅ„ski space consists of $2$ points and $3$ open sets, which appears as $\boxed {x \ \boxed y}$.
  • A topological space over a limit ordinal $Î±$ has base set $Î±^+$ and open sets $\mathcal{O}_Î³ : = \{x âˆ£ x > Î³\}$. For $Î± = Ï‰$, the space appears as $\boxed{0 \ \boxed{1 \ \boxed{2 \ \boxed {\cdots Ï‰ }}}}$.

For any ordinal $Î±$, consider the $Î±$-transfinite composition

$$\begin{equation} \begin{matrix}\boxed{0 \ \boxed{1 \ \boxed{2 \ \boxed {\cdots Î± }}}}\\\boxed{0 \ \boxed{1 \ \boxed{2 \ \boxed {\cdots Î± }}}}\end{matrix} â†  \boxed{0 \ \begin{matrix}\boxed{1 \ \boxed{2 \ \boxed {\cdots Î± }}}\\ \boxed{1 \ \boxed{2 \ \boxed {\cdots Î± }}}\end{matrix}} â†  \boxed{0 \ \boxed {1 \ \begin{matrix}\boxed{2 \ \boxed {\cdots Î± }}\\ \boxed{2 \ \boxed {\cdots Î± }}\end{matrix}}} â†  \cdots \end{equation}$$

Consider the continuous map from the SierpiÅ„ski space to the colimit

$$\begin{equation} Ï• : \boxed{\begin{matrix}x \\ \boxed y\end{matrix}} â†’ \boxed{0 \ \boxed{1 \ \boxed{2 \ \boxed {\cdots \begin{matrix}Î±\\Î± \end{matrix} }}}}, \quad \binom{x}{y} â†¦ \binom{Î± _{â†‘}}{Î± _{â†“}}. \end{equation}$$

Since $Ï•$ never factors through any object in the composition; if it did, then there would exist some open neighbourhood of $Î± _â†‘$ whose preimage is $\{x\}$ (not open).

Demonstrate that the compact objects in topological spaces are precisely the finite discrete spaces.

Eklof-Trlifaj Lemma

We present the Eklof-Trlifaj lemma with a proof analogous to Quillenâ€™s small object argument, albeit considerably simpler.

Recall that the cotorsion pair cogenerated by a class of objects $\mathcal{X}$ is denoted by $(^âŸ‚(\mathcal{X}^âŸ‚ ), \mathcal{X}^âŸ‚ )$.

  • For those acquainted with cofibrantly generated model structures, the class $^âŸ‚(\mathcal{X}^âŸ‚ )$ is reminiscent of a closure of $\mathcal{X}^âŸ‚$ under coproducts with a certain transfinite filtration.

We begin with the following deduction: a cotorsion theory in $C(R)$ is cogenerated by a set of objects $\mathcal{X}$ if and only if it is cogenerated by a single object $S:= (âˆ \mathcal{X})$:

  • Since $S âˆˆ ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (\mathcal{X})$, one has $\mathcal{X}^âŸ‚ = (\{S\} âˆª \mathcal{X})^âŸ‚ âŠ† S^âŸ‚$;
  • Since $\mathcal{X} âŠ† ğ’ğ¦ğ (S)$, one has $S^âŸ‚ âŠ† \mathcal{X}^âŸ‚$.

(Eklof-Trlifaj lemma). For any object $S âˆˆ C(R)$, the cotorsion pair cogenerated by $S$ is complete.

Let $ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)$ denote the class of objects generated by $S$ under transfinite filtration. Clearly, $ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S) âŠ† {}^âŸ‚ (S^âŸ‚ )$. It suffices to show that $\mathrm{coCone}(S^âŸ‚ , ğ…ğ¢ğ¥ (S)) = C(R)$. In this case, the $S^âŸ‚$-term appears as a colimit of the transfinite $S$-filtration: $$\begin{equation} M = M_0 âŠ† M_1 âŠ† \cdots âŠ† M_Î³ âŠ† \cdots \quad (Î³ < Î±) \end{equation}$$ We begin with short exact sequences $0 â†’ K \xrightarrow i P \xrightarrow p S â†’ 0$ where $P$ is projective. The construction of $M_Î³$ is via a universal pushout



Here $Î¦ _Î³ âˆˆ (K^{âˆ (K, M_Î³ )}, M_Î³ ) â‰ƒ (K,M_Î³)^{(K, M_Î³ )} âˆ‹ 1_{(K,M_Î³)}$. In particular,

  • for any $g : K â†’ M_Î³$, the morphism $f_Î³ âˆ˜ g : K â†’ M_{Î³ +1}$ extends along $i : K â†’ P$.

Let $Î±$ be $(|K|, |R|, Ï‰ )$-filtered. It remains to show that $M_Î± âˆˆ {}^âŸ‚ S$. Equivalently, $(i, M_Î±)$ is surjective. For any $g : K â†’ M_Î± = \varinjlim _{Î³ < Î± } M_Î³$, we observe that $g$ factors through some $M_Î²$. The universal pushout yields the dashed arrow.



The composition $P â†’ M_{Î² +1} â†’ M_Î±$ is our desired morphism.

Construct the dashed arrow. Hint: $$\begin{equation} g' = K \xrightarrow {Î¹ _{g'}} K^{âˆ (L, M_Î²)} \xrightarrow {Î¦ _Î²} M_Î². \end{equation}$$

We do not require any of $\mathcal{S}$, $\mathcal{S}^âŸ‚$, or $^âŸ‚ (\mathcal{S}^âŸ‚ )$ to be closed under $Î£ ^Â±$. We only use that, $S$ is a $\max(|S|, |R|, Ï‰)$-small object.

We remark that Eklof-Trlifaj lemma holds in Grothendieck category with enough projectives.

item.description:

Lecture 0

Abstract

Throughout these lectures, we discuss and construct explicit examples of cotorsion theory. The categories of modules and chain complexes over rings serve as our principal examples, wherein we demonstrate how set-theoretic techniques may be employed to construct cotorsion pairs. Throughout these lectures, we discuss and construct explicit examples of cotorsion theory. The categories of modules and chain complexes over rings serve as our principal examples, wherein we demonstrate how set-theoretic techniques may be employed to construct cotorsion pairs.

During the initial few lectures, we follow RHA-1 and RHA-2.

We also introduce certain aspects of the theory of chain complexes over rings, which might be atypical in most standard textbooks.

Notations

Throughout,

  • $R$: a unital (not necessarily commutative) ring,
  • $ğŒğ¨ğ _R \quad (â‰ƒ ğğ’ğ¡_{ğ€ğ›}(R))$: the category of right $R$-modules,
  • $C(R)$: the category of chain complexes over $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$,
    • our convension is $\cdots â†’ X^k \xrightarrow {d^k} X^{k+1} â†’ \cdots$,
    • $Î£$ and $Î£ ^{-1}$ denote the suspension and desuspension functors respectively.
  • $ğğ«ğ¨ğ£ (\mathcal{C})$: the class (or full subcategory) of projectives in $\mathcal{C}$,
  • $ğˆğ§ğ£ (\mathcal{C})$: the class (or full subcategory) of injectives in $\mathcal{C}$.

Functors

We review some basic definitions and notions in homological algebra. We employ

  • $âˆ$ to denote coproducts,
  • $âˆ$ for products, and
  • $â¨$ specifically when $âˆ \xrightarrow{âˆ¼} âˆ$, For example, $â¨_{n âˆˆ â„¤} Î£^n M_n$ represents the sum of stalk complexes.

The symbols $\varinjlim$ and $\varprojlim$ are utilised for colimits (injective limits) and limits (projective limits), respectively; in particular, the superscript $fil$ in $\varinjlim^{fil}$ indicates the filtered colimits.

(Preserving, reflecting, and creating). We explain by functors between Abelian categories. Given $F : \mathcal{A} â†’ \mathcal{B}$:

  • $F$ is said to preserve or commute with $\ker$, if any $0 â†’ K \xrightarrow i X \xrightarrow f Y$ is exact in $\mathcal{A}$ implies $0 â†’ F(K) \xrightarrow {F(i)} F(X) \xrightarrow {F(f)} F(Y)$ is exact in $\mathcal{B}$.
  • $F$ is said to reflect $\ker$, if any $0 â†’ F(K) \xrightarrow {F(i)} F(X) \xrightarrow {F(f)} F(Y)$ is exact in $\mathcal{B}$ implies $0 â†’ K \xrightarrow i X \xrightarrow f Y$ is exact in $\mathcal{A}$.
  • $F$ is said to create $\ker$, if any $0 â†’ H \xrightarrow {Ï† } F(X) \xrightarrow {F(f)} F(Y)$ is exact in $\mathcal{B}$ implies the existence of the exact sequence $0 â†’ K \xrightarrow i X \xrightarrow f Y$ in $\mathcal{A}$, such that $F(K) = H$ and $F(i) = Ï†$.

Demonstrate that

  • a fully faithful functor reflects limits;
  • the left/right adjoint functor preserves all limits/colimits, respectively;
  • for a Freydal luff sub-diagram $Î¹ : Q' â†’ Q$, the functor $Î¹ ^âˆ— : ğ…ğ®ğ§ğœğ­ (Q, \mathcal{C}) â†’ ğ…ğ®ğ§ğœğ­ (Q', \mathcal{C})$ creates all limits and colimits,
    • corollary: the (co)limits in $C(R)$ are computed termwise!
  • the forgetful functor $ğŒğ¨ğ _R â†’ ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$ creates all limits and filtered colimits,
    • corollary: the filtered colimits and limits in $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ are computed elementwise!

(Exactness). Left/right exact functors are precisely those preserving finite limits/colimits, respectively. A functor is termed exact if it is both left and right exact.

(Grothendieckâ€™s AB conditions). See stacks, or n-lab.

  • The conditions AB3, AB3$^âˆ—$, AB4, AB4$^âˆ—$, and AB5 are standard in both $ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ and $C(R)$. We assert the isomorphisms such as $âˆ \operatorname{cok}(f_âˆ™ ) \xrightarrow âˆ¼ \operatorname{cok}(âˆ f_âˆ™ )$ without further elaboration throughout these lectures.
  • The author refined the statement of AB6 in n-lab during a rather uneventful afternoon. Nevertheless, AB6 is not considered significant within the context of homological algebra.

Here are some well-known properties of filtered colimits (over $ğŒğ¨ğ_R$, $C(R)$, or a general AB5 category). We take $Î¹ _0 : M_{i_0} â†’ \varinjlim ^{fil}_{i âˆˆ I} M_i$ as the structure morphism for filtered colimit.

  1. Any element $x : \{âˆ—\} â†’ \varinjlim ^{fil}_{i âˆˆ I} M_i$ factors through some $Î¹_i$. (As every point is small).
  2. $\ker (Î¹ _{i}) = â‹ƒ _{Î±_{j,i}^{(k)} : i â†’ j} \ker Î± _{j,i}^{(k)}$ (such set-theoretic union for modules is also a module).
    • In particular, a monic filtered system has monic structure map.
  3. Let $\{f_i : M_i â†ª N\}_{i âˆˆ I}$ be a collection of monomorphisms which is compatible with the filtered diagram $I$. Then $\varinjlim ^{fil}_{i âˆˆ I} M_i â†ª N$ is also monic.
  4. $âˆ‘_{Î» âˆˆ Î› } (V âˆ© U_Î») = V âˆ© âˆ‘_{Î» âˆˆ Î› } (U_Î»)$. This is another equivalent definition of AB5 condition.
  5. (Assuming enough $ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$). Let $F$ be a left adjoint. Then filtered colimit preserves its left derivatives, i.e., $\varinjlim ^{fil}(\mathrm L^k F)(M_âˆ™) â‰ƒ (\mathrm L^k F)(\varinjlim ^{fil}M_âˆ™)$ for $k â‰¥ 0$.
    • General left adjoint functors include colimits (e.g. coproducts), free functors (e.g. $X â†¦ R^{(X)}$, sheafification), realisations (e.g. geometric/categorical realisation of simplicial sets), $(? âŠ— -)$, inverse images of either sheaves or presheaves (e.g. stalks, constant sheaves, or the change of category in general).

On Rings and Modules

We recollect some basic properties of ring and modules.

An Interesting Example on Transfinite Filtration

This demonstrates the distinctions between finitely generated modules and those $M$ for which $âˆ (M, -) â†ª (M, âˆ (-))$ constitutes an isomorphism. An equivalent characterisation is provided via the cofinality of transfinite filtration.

We begin with an exercise in ring theory.

$M$ is finitely generated if and only if,

  • for any (non-empty) set of proper submodules $\{N_i\}_{i âˆˆ I}$ such that either $N_i âŠ† N_j$ or $N_i âŠ‡ N_j$ for any $i, j âˆˆ I$, the union $â‹ƒ N_âˆ™$ is never equal to $M$ itself.

($â†’$). We show $a â†’ b$ by showing that $a âˆ§ (Â¬ b) â†’ \text{false}$. By $(Â¬ b)$, there exists an ordered system of proper submodules $N_âˆ™$ whose union is $M$. Let $\{x_i\}_{i=1}^n$ be a generating set of $M$ (by $(a)$). Thus, for each $i$, there exists $x_i âˆˆ N_{k_i}$. The proper submodule $â‹ƒ _{i=1}^n N_{k_i} = \text{Largest}\{N_{k_i}\}$ yields a contradiction.

($â†$). We show $b â†’ a$ with $b âˆ§ (Â¬ a) â†’ \text{false}$. Consider the collection of proper submodules $N_âˆ™ = \{N âˆ£ M / N\ \text{ is not f.g.}\}$. The poset of proper submodules $N_âˆ™$ is both

  • non-empty by $(Â¬ a)$, and
  • contains no maximal elements by construction.

We examine the partially ordered set $P := \{\text{chains in } N_âˆ™\}$ with the binary relation $âŠ†$. Observe that each chain in $P$ possesses an upper bound, obtained by taking the common refinement. Therefore, by Zornâ€™s lemma, $N_âˆ™$ contains a maximal inclusion chain of proper submodules, denoted by $C_âˆ™$.
$C_âˆ™$ contains no maximal elements; thus, $â‹ƒ C_âˆ™ âˆ‰ N_âˆ™$. In this case $M / (â‹ƒ C_âˆ™)$ is f.g.. Consequently, there exists a finitely generated submodule $L$ such that $L + â‹ƒ C_âˆ™ = M$; however, $â‹ƒ (L + C_âˆ™) â‰  M$ by $(b)$. This leads to a contradiction.

In the above theorem, $N_âˆ™$ is taken over arbitrary totally-ordered set. For colimit $â‹ƒ$, it suffices to consider a cofinal subsystem indexed by an ordinal. Hence,

$M$ is f.g., iff any transfinite composition of proper submodules,

$$\begin{equation} 0 = M_0 âŠŠ M_1 âŠŠ \cdots âŠŠ M_Î³ âŠŠ \cdots, \end{equation}$$

satisfy $(â‹ƒ M_âˆ™) âŠŠ M$.

$M$ is f.g. if and only if every proper submodule is contained in a maximal submodule.

(â†’). Suppose that $M$ is f.g.. For any $M_0 âŠ† M$, $M / M_0$ is f.g.. Now it suffices to show that $(M / M_0)$ possesses a maximal submodule. If not, then there exists some transfinite inclusion of proper submodules whose union is $(M / M_0)$. This is a contradiction.
(â†). Conversely, denote the non-empty set $$\begin{equation} \mathcal{S} := \{N âˆ£ N âŠŠ M , N \ \text{is not contained in a maximal submodule}\}. \end{equation}$$

Note that $\mathcal{S}$ is closed under upward inclusion. The partially ordered set $\{\text{chains in} \ \mathcal{S}\}$ is closed under transfinite refinement. Hence, there exists a maximal chain $C_âˆ™ âŠ† \mathcal{S}$. Clearly, $â‹ƒ C_âˆ™ = M$, so $M$ is not f.g..

  • This criterion admits an inductive proof, which reduces to the case that every ring possesses a maximal ideal.

We slightly revise such characterisation to the following FAKE finitely generated cases.

(FAKE f.g.). A module $M$ is FAKE finitely generated if any $Ï‰$-composition of proper submodules,

$$\begin{equation} 0 = M_0 âŠŠ M_1 âŠŠ \cdots âŠŠ M_n âŠŠ \cdots \quad (n âˆˆ â„• ), \end{equation}$$

satisfy $(â‹ƒ_{n âˆˆ â„•} M_n) âŠŠ M$.

We show FAKE f.g. $M$â€™s are precisely those $âˆ (M, -) \xrightarrow âˆ¼ (M, âˆ (-))$ in the rest of this subsection. We call such $M$ a compact object in the underlying additive category, i.e., $(M, -)$ is coproduct preserving

  • compact objects in general additive categories corresponds to $âˆ$-preserving $(M, -)$;
  • compact objects in AB5 category (e.g. $ğŒğ¨ğ_R$) corresponds to $\varinjlim^{fil}$-preserving $(M, -)$ (e.g., f.p. modules).

Show the subfunctor $âˆ (M, -) â†ª (M, âˆ (-))$ for $ğŒğ¨ğ_R$ or $C(R)$.

If $M$ is FAKE f.g., then $M$ is compact in the underlying additive category of $ğŒğ¨ğ_R$.

We deduce the lemma to countable case, that is, $(M, -)$ preserves arbitrary coproducts if $(M, -)$ preserves countable coproducts.

  • Assume $âˆ_{i âˆˆ I} (M, N_i ) \overset {â‰ }â†ª (M, âˆ_I N_{i} )$, we can find $F : M â†’ âˆ _{i âˆˆ I}N_i$ such that $N_i âˆ© \mathrm{im}(F) â‰  0$ for infinitely many $N_i$â€™s. Hence, there is a countable coproduct $N = (âˆ _{n âˆˆ â„•} N_n) âŠ• (âˆ _{\text{the rest}}N_âˆ™)$ where the image of $F$ has non-zero intersection with each summand. This provides an example that $(M, -)$ does not preserve countable coproducts.

We take arbitrary $f$ in

$$\begin{equation} âˆ_{n âˆˆ â„•} (M,N_n) â†ª (M, âˆ_{n âˆˆ â„•} N_n) âˆ‹ f = (f_n)_{n âˆˆ â„•}. \end{equation}$$

Then $â‹‚ _{m â‰¥ n} \ker f_m$ is an ascending chain of submodules of $M$, satisfying

$$\begin{equation} \limsup (\ker f_âˆ™) = â‹ƒ_{n â‰¥ 0} â‹‚ _{m â‰¥ n} \ker f_m = M. \end{equation}$$

By FAKE f.g. condition, all but finite $â‹‚ _{m â‰¥ n} \ker f_m âŠ† â‹‚ _{m â‰¥ n+1} \ker f_m$ takes $âŠŠ$. Hence, there is $n_0$ such that $â‹‚ _{m â‰¥ n_0} \ker f_m = M$. In this case, $f$ is also characterised in $â¨ _{n â‰¤ n_0}(M, N_n)$.

Show the converse statement: when there exists $â‹ƒ M_âˆ™ = M$ for some inclusion sequence

$$\begin{equation} 0 = M_0 âŠŠ M_1 âŠŠ \cdots âŠŠ M_n âŠŠ \cdots \quad (n âˆˆ â„• ). \end{equation}$$

Show that $âˆ (M, -) â‰‡ (M, âˆ (-))$.

Hint: Let $Ï€ _n : M â†  M/M_n$ be quotient maps. The morphism $(Ï€ _n) âˆˆ (M, âˆ \frac{M}{M_n})$ lies in $(M, âˆ \frac{M}{M_n})$, since each support set $S_x := \{n âˆ£ Ï€ _n(x) â‰  0\}$ is finite. However, one can never find $?$ along

$$\begin{equation} ? âˆˆ âˆ(M,\frac{M}{M_n}) â†ª (M, âˆ \frac{M}{M_n}) â†ª (M, âˆ \frac{M}{M_n}) âˆ‹ (Ï€ _n). \end{equation}$$

Notice that $(Ï€ _n) âˆˆ (M, âˆ \frac{M}{M_n}) â‰ƒ âˆ (M, \frac{M}{M_n})$ never belongs to $âˆ (M, \frac{M}{M_n})$.

There exists of $Ï‰$-filtered ordinal, e.g., the first uncountable cardinal and $|â„|$ (these two coincides under continuum hypothesis).

We learn from analysis that $\mathcal{P}(X) = \mathrm{Hom}_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬}(X,ğ”½ _2)$ is an $ğ”½_2$-algebra ($âˆ… = 0$ and $âˆ© = Ã—$ for convention). Let $X$ be uncountable. Show that

  • The collection $X_Ï‰ := \{Y âˆ£ |Y| â‰¤ Ï‰ \}$ is an ideal of $\mathcal{P}(X)$;
  • $X_Ï‰$ is not f.g. as a $\mathcal{P}(X)$-module.
  • $X_Ï‰$ is uncountable, but any proper submodule of $X_Ï‰$ is countable.

Hence, $X_Ï‰$ is FAKE f.g. but not f.g.. This construction shows that for any cardinal $Îº$, there exists examples such that the generating set of some FAKE f.g. modules must be $â‰¥ Îº$.

On FAKE f.g. and f.g.. Show that

  1. f.g. are FAKE f.g..
  2. f.g. coincides FAKE f.g. for projective modules;
  3. FAKE f.g. are closed under quotients (and summands);
  4. FAKE f.g. are closed under extensions (and finite sums);
  5. For ses $K â†ª X â†  Y$ where $K$ is small in Y (e.g., radical inclusion), then $X$ is FAKE f.g. if so is $Y$.

For left modules, f.g. coincides FAKE f.g. over left perfect rings.

We show any FAKE f.g. module $M$ is f.g..

  • (by 5). the projective cover $P(M)$ is again FAKE f.g..
  • (by 2). such $P(M)$ must be f.g..

By $P(M) â†  M$, $M$ is also f.g..

Over a left/right perfect ring, there are no need to distinguish between

  • f.g. and FAKE f.g. modules,
  • projective modules and flat modules,
  • â€¦

The REAL Compact Modules

Say $M$ is compact, provided $(M, - )$ preserves all filtered colimits.

Compact objects are closed under finite colimits. In particular, f.g. projective modules and f.p. modules are compact.

By AB5, filtered colimits commutes with finite limits. By pentagon procedure,

$$\begin{aligned} (\varinjlim {}^{<âˆ} M_i, \varinjlim{}^{fil}_jN_j) & â‰ƒ \varprojlim {}^{<\infty}(M_i, \varinjlim{}^{fil}_j N_j) â‰ƒ \varprojlim {}^{<\infty} \varinjlim{}^{fil}_j (M_i, N_j)\\[6pt] &â‰ƒ \varinjlim{}^{fil}_j \varprojlim {}^{<\infty} (M_i, N_j) â‰ƒ \varinjlim{}^{fil}_j (\varinjlim {}^{<\infty} M_i, N_j). \end{aligned}$$

We see $\varinjlim {}^{<âˆ} M_i$ preserves $\varinjlim^{fil}$, thus is compact.

By definition, $f: \text{compact} â†’ \text{induction of small}$ is described by $f : \text{compact} â†’ \text{small}$ locally. We wish $\text{induction of small} = \text{all objects}$.

Finite sets are exactly compact objects in $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$, conversely, any set is a filtered colimit of its finite subsets (local compactness). It is reasonable for check whether a module is a filtered limit of the compact objects.

(Local compactness for modules). Every module $M$ is a filtered colimit of compact modules.

It suffices to show $M$ is a filtered colimit of f.p. modules. We take the canonical surjection $R^{(M)} â†  M$, and construct the filtered system as follows.

  • The system is indexed by a finite subset $I \subseteq M$ along with a finite subset of $\mathcal S \subseteq S_I\subseteq R^I$ which generates $\ker [R^I \hookrightarrow R^{(M)} \twoheadrightarrow M]$.

  • We denote $\Phi _{(I, \mathcal S)}$ as an element, which stands for a chain complex $âŸ¨\mathcal SâŸ© \hookrightarrow R^I \to M$.

  • We define the partial order $\Phi_{(I, \mathcal S)} \hookrightarrow \Phi_{(J, \mathcal T)}$.

The poset is clearly filtered. We show the induced $\alpha : \varinjlim_{\Phi_{(I,\mathcal S)}}R^I\to M$ is an isomorphism.

  • $\alpha$ is surjective, since any $x \in M$ is characterised by $R^{(x)} \to M$;

  • $\alpha$ is injective. If $[p] \in \Phi_{(I, \mathcal S)}$ and $[q] \in \Phi _{(J, \mathcal T)}$ has the same image $m\in M$ , then we take $\Phi _{(I \cup J \cup \{m\}, \mathcal S \cup \mathcal T \cup \{p-e_m, q-e_m\})}$ , an upper bound of $\Phi_{ (I, \mathcal S)}$ and $\Phi _{(J, \mathcal T)}$ where $[p]$ and $[q]$ has the same image.

We show that f.p. modules are precisely compact modules. Indeed we have the following equivalent characterisation.

In general, $M$ is finitely presented iff the following equivalent definitions holds.

  1. There is an exact sequence $R^m \to R^n \to M \to 0$,

  2. $M \otimes-$ commutes with $\prod$,

  3. $M \otimes R^{\Lambda} \simeq M^\Lambda$ for arbitrary index set $\Lambda$.

  4. $(M, -)$ preserves filtered colimits.

($1 \to 4$). We write $M = \mathrm{cok}(\varphi)$. Now

We summarise the tests for f.p. modules, proj. modules, inj. modules and flat modules at the very beginning.

$M$ is f.p., iff the following equivalent definitions hold.

$M$ is projective, iff the following equivalent definitions hold.

  2. $M$ is a summand of some free module $R^{(Î»)}$;

$M$ is injective, iff the following equivalent definitions hold.

$M$ is flat iff the following equivalent definitions hold.

    1. all inclusions of submodule;
    2. all inclusions of an ideal;
    3. all inclusions of two f.g. submodules;
    4. all inclusions of a f.g. ideal;
      • we remark that $M âŠ— I â†ª M âŠ— R$ is injective iff it is isomorphic to its image, that is, $M âŠ— I â‰ƒ MI$. As $M âŠ— I â†  MI$, this is equivalent to $M âŠ— I â†’ MI$ being injective.
  2. $\mathrm{Tor}_{â‰¥ 1}(M, -) = 0$, or $\mathrm{Tor}_1 (M, -) = 0$;

  4. Any morphism from f.p. module to $M$ factors through some f.g. projective module.

  6. $M$ is a filtered colimit of f.p. modules.

$M$ is f.g. projective iff the following equivalent definitions hold.

We commence with projective modules.

Projective modules (defined by summand of free modules) is a coproduct of countably generated projective modules.

See examples and propositions in this subsection.

$P$ is a projective (summand of free), iff there exists a subset $\{(e_i, f_i)\}_{i âˆˆ I} âŠ† P Ã— (P, R)$ such that any $x âˆˆ R$ is a finite sum of some $âˆ‘_{i âˆˆ I_0} e_i â‹… f_i (x)$. We call this projective basis.

In particular, $ğ¦ğ¨ğ_R$ is not closed under kernel in general. To fix this, we may require f.p. is automatically $3$-term f.p. (and thus $âˆ$-f.p.). This comes with coherency.

$R$ is (right) coherent provided (right) flat $R$-modules are closed under arbitrary products.

TFAE:

  1. $\mathrm{flat}(\mathrm{Mod}_R)$ is closed under $\prod$,
  2. $\prod _{\lambda \in \Lambda}R_R=:R^\Lambda$ is flat,
  3. every f.g. submodule (left ideal) of ${}_RR$ is f.p.,

We show ($1 \to 2 \to 3 \to 1$) with a set-theoritic analysis; and $(3\to 4 \to 5 \to 4)$ with a homological analysis.

($1 \to 2$) is clear.

($2 \to 3$). For any f.g. left ideal $I$ and index set $\Lambda$, we show $I^\Lambda\simeq R ^\Lambda\otimes I$ (recall the equivalent definitions of f.p. modules). The flatness shows injection, and the f.g. shows surjection.

($3 \to 1$). We show f.g. $\iota: _RI\hookrightarrow R$ is preserved by $R^\Lambda$ via Baerâ€™s criterion. Since f.p. = f.g. (by assumption), $\iota \otimes -$ commutes with $\prod$.

($3\to 4$). Note that f.p. modules are closed under extensions and cokernels. For ses $0 \to K \to X \to Y \to 0$ with $X$ and $Y$ f.p., we have $K$ f.g. in general. By horseshoe lemma, we obtain ses $0 \to \Omega_1 (K) \to \Omega_1 (X) \to \Omega_1 (Y) \to 0$ for $\Omega _1(X)$ and $\Omega_1 (Y)$ f.g.; by 3., $\Omega _1 (Y)$ and $\Omega _1(X)$ are f.p., hence $\Omega _1(K)$ is f.g.. ($4 \to 5$). By definition, we can choose the first syzygy of any f.p. module as some f.p. modules.

($5 \to 3$). When $I \hookrightarrow R$ is f.g. ideal, $R/I$ is f.p., thus is $\infty$-presentable by assumption. Now $I$ is also $\infty$-presentable.

We gives an example of coherent rings which is not Noetherian.

The ring $R = â„¤ [X_1, X_2, \ldots]$ is coherent but not Noetherian. The trivial representation $â„¤ = R / (x_1, x_2, \ldots)$ is constructed by quotienting a $âˆ$-generated ideal. Character Module

The character module rises in the standard injective resolution $â„¤ â†ª â„š â†  â„š / â„¤$. This yields a functor functor $(-)^+ := \mathrm{Ext}^1_â„¤ (-, â„¤) := (-, \mathbb Q / \mathbb Z)_{\mathbb Z}$, aka Pontryagin dual. Note that this functor is

  • faithful (as $\mathbb Q / \mathbb Z$ is a cogenerator) and
  • exact (as $\mathbb Q / \mathbb Z$ is injective).

Consequently, it preserves and reflects zero objects and exactness. In particular, $((-)^+)^{\mathrm{op}}$ preserves and reflects monomorphisms and epimorphisms.

We shall see this functor suprisingly transfers and reflects from injective modules to flat modules; the dual procedure applies for Noetherian rings.

If $F$ is flat, then $F âŠ— (-)^+ â‰ƒ (F âŠ— -)^+ â‰ƒ (F,-)^+$ is exact. Since $(-)^+$ reflects exactness, it follows that $F$ is projective.

A Discussion on the Homotopy Category $K(R)$

We present several formal approaches to computing the homotopy category $K(R)$. Here, $R$ may be replaced by a general Abelian category.

The following categories are isomorphic; that is, they possess the same class of objects and naturally isomorphic $\mathrm{Hom}$-sets.

  1. The $H^0(\mathcal{HOM})$-construction. (Observe that the Hom complex is defined for any Abelian category.)
  2. The localisation $C(R) [S^{-1}]$, where $S$ comprises homotopy equivalences, i.e., morphisms $f$ for which there exists a morphism $g$ such that $f âˆ˜ g$ and $g âˆ˜ f$ are homotopic to the identity morphisms.
  3. The additive quotient $C(R) / \mathcal{N}$, where $\mathcal{N}$ consists of split acyclic complexes (that is, contractible complexes).
  4. The homotopy category $C(R) / âˆ¼$, where $âˆ¼$ is an additive categorical equivalence relation on $\mathrm{Hom}$-sets, with $f âˆ¼ 0$ if and only if $f$ is null-homotopic.

We first demonstrate that $C(R) / âˆ¼$ is well-defined. Note that $s : f âˆ¼ g$ if and only if $s âˆ˜ h : f âˆ˜ h âˆ¼ g âˆ˜ h$, and the dual statement holds as well. We denote the category by $K_i$ $(i = 1,2,3,4)$ according to the constructions above.

  1. $(K_1 = K_4)$. This is evident.
  2. $(K_2 = K_4)$. The quotient $C \to K_4$ maps $S$ to isomorphisms, yielding $K_2 \to K_4$. To establish the converse functor, observe that the collection of homotopies $\{(s,f,g) âˆ£ s : f âˆ¼ g : X \to Y\}$ is represented by $(\mathrm{Cyl}(1_X), Y)$ via $Î£ X âŠ• X âŠ• X \xrightarrow {(s,f,g)} Y$. In this context, we have
    • $f = [X \xrightarrow {e_2} \mathrm{Cyl}(1_X) \xrightarrow {(s,f,g)} Y]$;
    • $g = [X \xrightarrow {e_3} \mathrm{Cyl}(1_X) \xrightarrow {(s,f,g)} Y]$.

    Observe that $e_2 = e_2$ in $K_2$. Thus, whenever $f = g$ in $K_4$, it follows that $f = g$ in $K_2$.

  3. $(K_3 = K_4)$. Since $K_4$ is additive, the zero morphisms are precisely those which factor through zero objects. This yields $K_3 \to K_4$. Conversely, when $f âˆ¼ g : X \to Y$ in $K_4$, we have $f âˆ¼ g$ in $K_3$ as it factors through the zero object $\mathrm{Cyl}(1_X)$. Therefore, $K_4 = K_3$.

It is unnecessary to demonstrate the additivity of the localisation $C â†’ K_2$; this is not obvious if one tries to show this directly. Here is a note on additive localisation.

The exact category $(C, \mathcal{E})$, where $\mathcal{E}$ consists of ses split termwise, is Frobenius; that is, the contractible complexes are precisely the injectives and projectives. Consequently, $K / ğğ«ğ¨ğ£$ is triangulated, where the desuspension is the syzygy.
