Hence, a compact object need not to be f.g..

  • If we choose $\mathcal{HOM}$ instead, then compact objects are exactly bounded complexes with f.p. modules.

In general, $C(R)$ can be regarded as a full subcategory of $ğŒğ¨ğ _{(R^â„¤) [d] / I}$, where $I$ is generated by

$$\begin{equation} \{d^2\} âˆª \{[d,r]\}_{r âˆˆ R} âˆª \{d âˆ˜ e_k - e_{k+1} âˆ˜ d âˆ£ e_l ^2 = e_l, \ \text{and} \ (R^â„¤)e_l = R^{(l\text{-th})}\}_{k âˆˆ â„¤}. \end{equation}$$

A chain complex $M^âˆ™$ is regarded as a graded module $â¨_{k âˆˆ â„¤ }M^k$ (with relations).

  • This definition is rarely used in practice; in this case, a functorial indentification $ğŒğ¨ğ _A â‰ƒ ğ…ğ®ğ§ğœğ­ (A^{\mathrm{op}}, ğ€ğ›)$ is more convenient.
  • This is not our/topological definition, at least $M^i âˆ© M^j = âˆ…$ for our convention.

We are interested in DG-projective/DG-injective complexes in practice.

Double Complexes

For a general theory of complex resolution, we shall introduce $C(C(R))$, which is equivalent to the category of double complexes.

(Double complex, or bicomplex). A double complex is a collection of objects $\{C^{p,q}\}_{p,q âˆˆ â„¤}$ with two differentials $d_h$ (horizontal) and $d_v$ (vertical), such that

$$\begin{equation} d_h âˆ˜ d_h = 0, \quad d_v âˆ˜ d_v = 0, \quad\text{and} \ \ d_h âˆ˜ d_v + d_v âˆ˜ d_h = 0. \end{equation}$$



We write $DC(\mathcal{A})$ as the category of double complexes over $\mathcal{A}$.

Show that if $\mathcal{A}$ is AB3/AB4/AB5/AB3*/â€¦/, has enough projectives/injectives, well powered, etc., then so is $DC(\mathcal{A})$.

(Total complexes). For either $â˜† âˆˆ \{âˆ , âˆ\}$, we define the functor

$$\begin{equation} \mathrm{Tot}^â˜† : DC(\mathcal{A}) â†’ C(\mathcal{A}), \quad (C^{p,q}, d_h , d_v) â†¦ (\underset{p+q = n}{â˜†}C^{p,q}, (d_v + d_h)). \end{equation}$$

Since ses for in either $DC(\mathcal{A})$ or $C(\mathcal{A})$ are verified termwise, $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ$ (resp., $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ$) is an exact functor when $\mathcal{A}$ is AB4* (resp., AB3*).

(Support). The support of $X^{âˆ™ , âˆ™}$ consists of the pairs $(p,q) âˆˆ â„¤ ^2$ such that $X^{p,q} â‰  0$. In particular,

  • say $X^{âˆ™ , âˆ™ }$ is finite, provided $\mathrm{Supp}(X)$ is finite;
  • say $X^{âˆ™ , âˆ™ }$ is locally finite, provided $\{(p,q) âˆˆ \mathrm{Supp}(X) âˆ£ p + q = m\}$ is finite for every $m âˆˆ â„¤$;
    • In this case, $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ (X) = \mathrm{Tot}^âˆ (X)$. We write $\mathrm{Tot}(X)$ for simplicity.
  • say $X^{âˆ™ , âˆ™ }$ is a $k$-th quadrant double complex if $\mathrm{Supp}(X)$ lies in the $k$-th quadrant under finite steps of translations;
  • we also use the expression including upper half plane double complex, $(m Ã— n)$ double complexes, etc.

Here are some criterion on exactness.

  1. Suppose $X$ is locally finite with exact rows (or columns). Then both $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ(X)$ and $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ(X)$ are exact.
  2. Suppose $X$ lies in upper (or left) half plane with exact columns. Then $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ(X)$ is exact.
  3. Suppose $X$ lies in upper (or left) half plane with exact rows. Then $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ(X)$ is exact.

It is always quicker to write a proof rather than to read a proof.

  • To remember this, just note that for complexes over upper half plane, $âˆ$ and column-exactness are not compatible; otherwise DG-projective complexes are meaningless!

We show some non-examples in accordance with the above proposition.

For $X â‰  0$, consider the following double complexes.



We see $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ (\text{Left})$ and $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ (\text{Right})$ are not acyclic; while $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ (\text{Right})$ and $\mathrm{Tot}^âˆ (\text{Left})$ are acyclic.

Some books refer $âŠ—$ and $\mathrm{Hom}$ as bifunctors of the type $C Ã— C â†’ DC$. Recall our convention is $C Ã— C â†’ DC \xrightarrow {\mathrm{Tot}^{â˜†}} C$, i.e.,

$$\begin{equation} (X âŠ— Y)^{âˆ™ , âˆ™ } â†¦ \underset{:= X âŠ— Y}{\underbrace{\mathrm{Tot}^{âˆ }(X âŠ— Y)}},\quad (\mathrm{Hom}(X,Y))^{âˆ™ , âˆ™ } â†¦ \underset{:= \mathcal{HOM}(X,Y)}{\underbrace{\mathrm{Tot}^{âˆ }(\mathrm{Hom}(X,Y))}}. \end{equation}$$

Bi-resolution shows the balanced property of $\mathrm{Ext}^k$, that is, there is a natural isomorphism

$$\begin{equation} \mathrm{Ext}^k(-, Y) (X) â‰ƒ \mathrm{Ext}^k(X, -) (Y). \end{equation}$$

We take projective resolution $X$ and injective resolution $Y$. Consider the black double complex which is locally finite:



By criterion of exactness, we see $\binom{ {\color{red}\text{çº¢}}\ {\color{purple}\text{ç´«}} }{\text{é»‘} \ {\color{blue}\text{è“}}}$, $\binom{ {\color{red}\text{çº¢}}}{\text{é»‘}}$, and $({\text{é»‘}\ {\color{blue}\text{è“}}})$ are exact. By ses

$$\begin{equation} 0 â†’ \text{é»‘} â†’ ({\text{é»‘}\ {\color{blue}\text{è“}}}) â†’ {\color{blue}\text{è“}} â†’ 0, \end{equation}$$

Hence, $Î£\mathrm{Tot}(\text{é»‘}) â‡  {\color{blue}\text{è“} }$ and $Î£\mathrm{Tot}(\text{é»‘}^âŠº) â‡  {\color{red}\text{çº¢} }$ are quasi-isomorphisms. We obtain

$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Ext}^k (-,Y)(X) & := H^k ({\color{red}\text{çº¢}}) â‰ƒ H^k (Î£ \mathrm{Tot}(\text{é»‘}))\\[6pt] & â‰ƒ H^k ({\color{blue}\text{è“}}) =: \mathrm{Ext}^k (X,-)(Y). \end{aligned}$$

The balance comes from $H^âˆ™ (\mathrm{Tot}^{â˜†}(X)) = H^âˆ™ (\mathrm{Tot}^{â˜†}(X)^âŠº \ )$.

(Balance) Suppose $T : â¨‰_{i=1}^n \mathcal{A}_i â†’ \mathcal{B}$ is a (covariant) multi-functor between Abelian categories. Say it is balances, provided

  • For any injective $I_k âˆˆ ğˆğ§ğ£ (\mathcal{A}_k)$, the functor $$\begin{equation} T(X_1, \ldots, (-)_j, \ldots , X_{k-1}, I_k, X_{k+1}, \cdots, X_n) : \mathcal{A}_j â†’ \mathcal{B} \end{equation}$$ is exact for arbitrary $\{X_k\}_{k âˆ‰ \{i,j\}}$.

For balanced functors, the derivatives are free of the choice of the variables.

$((-)^{\mathrm{op}} âŠ—(?)^{\mathrm{op}})^{\mathrm{op}}$ and $\mathrm{Hom}((-)^{\mathrm{op}},?)$ are balanced. The definition is introduced by Cartan-Eilenberg, and also by Weibel. They know no example of a balanced functor in three variablesâ€¦

item.title: Seminare on Cotorsion Theory
item.description:
Lectures

Lecture0. The preliminaries (basicc ring theories, complexes, etc.).

Lecture1. Orthogonality, cotorsion theory, complete cotorsion pairs. Ordinal and cardinals, small object, and Eklof-Trlifajâ€™s criterion.

Lecture2. Kaplansky class for reconstructing cogenerating sets, DG construction on cotorsion pairs, complete herediatary cotorsion paris and triples.

  • Supplementary Notes on DG Categories.

Lecture3. All cover/envelope theory studies projective covers. The defect of projective modules in covering theory. A criterion when (special) precover/preenvelope admits a (special) cover/envelope.

  • Supplementary Notes on Radicals and Covers.

Lecture4. Definable subgroups, purity, and associated cotorsion theory.

item.title: Notes on Completion of Triangulated Categories
item.description:
We follow the following references:

  • F. WILLIAM LAWVERE: METRIC SPACES, GENERALIZED LOGIC, AND CLOSED CATEGORIES, see the article (with author commentary), or in this website.
  • Amnon Neeman: Finite approximations as a tool for studying triangulated categories, video of the talk and slides.
  • Henning Krause: COMPLETIONS OF TRIANGULATED CATEGORIES (note for a master class at Aarhus University (March 22â€“ 24, 2023)).

Introduction

item.title: A Note on Quillen's Model Structure
item.description:
Note on Model Category

Abstract

This note serves as an introduction to the concept of model structures in the context of Quillenâ€™s work. It is intended for those who are familiar with basic knowledge of homological algebra, but little or no prior experience with topologies to understand the foundational aspects of model categories.

  • Note on Model Category
    • Abstract
  • Kan Extension
    • The Basic Definitions
      • Categories and Functors
      • Universe
      • Limits and Colimits
    • A note on Kan Extension
      • The Definition
      • Example: Homology from Limits
      • The Construction
      • On Derived Functors
  • Simplicial Methods
    • Simplicial Objects
      • Basics
      • The Truncation
    • The Topologies
      • Motivation for Simplicial Methods
      • A Categorical Overview
      • The Pointed Construction
      • Equivalences
      • The Geometric Realisation
      • CW-approximation
    • Cofibrantly Generating Class
      • The (W)FS
      • Quillenâ€™s Small Object Argument
      • Kan Complexes
      • Adjoint Lifting
    • Functors
      • Topological Space for Convenience
      • Hurewicz Map
      • DK Correspondence
      • (Homotopy) Spectra
      • Quillenâ€™s Equivalence
  • Quillenâ€™s Model Structure

Kan Extension

In this section, we endeavour to elucidate the universal construction known as the Kan extension. The concept originates from the book by H. P. Cartan and S. Eilenberg in 1956, wherein it was introduced for the computation of derived functors. Further computational aspects are explored in D. Kanâ€™s paper on adjoint functors in 1958. The general notion of extension, attributed to D. Kan, emerged circa 1960, and a modern treatment is presented in Mac Laneâ€™s book Categories for the Working Mathematician.

The Basic Definitions

Categories and Functors

We clarify some of the notations: General categories are written in \mathcal font, e.g., $\mathcal{C}$ for a category, where

  • $ğŠ _0 := ğ–®ğ–»$ denotes the class of objects and $ğŠ _1 := ğ–¬ğ—ˆğ—‹$ denotes the class of morphisms,
  • $(X, Y)_\mathcal{C}$ or $\mathrm{Hom}_\mathcal{C}(X,Y)$ denotes the set of morphisms in $\mathcal{C}$ from $X$ to $Y$,
  • $1_X$ denotes the identity morphism in $(X,X)_\mathcal{C}$,
  • the notion of composition is denoted as $f âˆ˜ g$, where $âˆ˜$ is of the type $ğŠ_1 Ã— _{ğŠ_0} ğŠ_1 â†’ ğŠ _1$.

Specific categories are denoted in \mathbf font, e.g., $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$ for the category of sets, $ğŒğ¨ğ_k$ for the category of right $k$-modules. A general functor category is denoted as $ğ…ğ®ğ§(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D})$ or simply $\mathcal{D}^\mathcal{C}$, where

  • a general functor $F$ is in italic font,
  • a general natural transformation $Î¸ = \{Î¸_X\}_{X âˆˆ ğ–®ğ–»}$ is a Greek letter in italic font,
  • the $\mathrm{Hom}$-object in the functor category is denoted as $ğğšğ­[F,G]$.

When it is valid to regard the superclass of categories as a category itself, the vertical and horizontal compositions of natural transformations are denoted by $âˆ˜$ and $âˆ—$, respectively. For instance, in the following diagram of natural transformations



$Î¸ _2 âˆ˜ Î¸ _1$ (of the type $ğŠ_2Ã— _{ğŠ_1}ğŠ_2$) denotes the vertical composition of natural transformations, whilst $Î¸ _2 âˆ— Î¸ _1$ (of the type $ğŠ_2Ã— _{ğŠ_0}ğŠ_2$) denotes the horizontal composition.

(Godementâ€™s interchange law). A well-known identity by R. Godement states $$\begin{equation} (Ï„ _2 âˆ˜ Ï„ _1) âˆ— (Î¸ _2 âˆ˜ Î¸ _1) = (Ï„ _2 âˆ— Î¸ _2) âˆ˜ (Ï„ _1 âˆ— Î¸ _1). \end{equation}$$

It is straightforward to verify the identity pointwise.

Discover a topological explanation of Godementâ€™s interchange law, and show that the $Ï€_1$-group of connected topological groups is Abelian.

Universe

The conception of a universe is introduced by A. Grothendieck in this appendix of SGA4, which enables one to circumvent the set-theoretic paradoxes, notably Russellâ€™s paradox. The assumption of a universe $ğ”˜$ specifies what is small, large, or uncontrollably large. Alternative approaches to avoiding such paradoxes exist; see M. A. Shulmanâ€™s note for further details. The following definition is adapted from a note by D. Murfet.

A universe is denoted in \mathfrak-font. It is a set, satisfying the following (overdetermined) properties:

  1. If $x âˆˆ A$ and $A âˆˆ ğ”˜$, then $x âˆˆ ğ”˜$;
  2. If $x âˆˆ ğ”˜$ and $y âˆˆ ğ”˜$, then $\{x,y\} âˆˆ ğ”˜$;
  3. If $x âˆˆ ğ”˜$, then the powerset $\mathcal{P}(x) âˆˆ ğ”˜$;
  4. For any $I âˆˆ ğ”˜$ such that $\{x_i\}_{i âˆˆ I} âŠ† ğ”˜$, one has $â‹ƒ_{i âˆˆ I}x_i âˆˆ ğ”˜$.

Show that the universe $ğ”˜$ is closed under the basic operation of Peano postulates for natural numbers:

  1. $0 := âˆ… âˆˆ ğ”˜$;
  2. If $x âˆˆ ğ”˜$, then $(x + 1) := (x âŠ” \{x\}) âˆˆ ğ”˜$;
  3. Show that $â„• âŠ† ğ”˜$, and find $ğ”˜$ such that $â„• âˆ‰ ğ”˜$ (Hint: try $â‹ƒ_{k âˆˆ â„•}\mathcal{P}^k(x)$ for finite $x$, that is, the von Neumann hierarchy generated by a finite set);
  4. Suppose that $â„• âˆˆ ğ”˜$, show that $â„¤$, $â„š$, $â„$ and $â„‚$ belong to $ğ”˜$.

This exercise is nothing but a verification that the general constructions of number fields never exceed the universe $ğ”˜$.

Show that the universe $ğ”˜$ is closed under the basic operation of category theory:

  1. If $x, y âˆˆ ğ”˜$, then the pair $(x,y) âˆˆ ğ”˜$ (the implicit axiom of universe in SGA4)
  2. $ğ”˜$ inherits the closed monoidal structure from $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$, i.e., $ğ”˜$ is non-empty with an element $1$, closed under Hom-set $(-, ? )_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬}$ and Cartesian product $- Ã— ?$.
  3. $ğ”˜$ is closed under sub-objects and quotient-objects.
  4. For $I âˆˆ ğ”˜$ such that $\{x_i \}_{i âˆˆ I} âŠ† ğ”˜$, all $âˆ _{i âˆˆ I}x_i$, $âˆ _{i âˆˆ I} x_i$, $â‹ƒ _{i âˆˆ I} x_i$ and $â‹‚ _{i âˆˆ I} x_i$ belong to $ğ”˜$.
  5. Hence, both limits and colimits indexed by $I âˆˆ ğ”˜$ exist in the universe.

We define the small, large, and uncontrollably large sets (relative to the universe $ğ”˜$) as follows:

Let $X$ be a set, say

  • $X$ is a $ğ”˜$-small set (or $X$ is $ğ”˜$-small for simplicity), provided $X âˆˆ ğ”˜$;
  • $X$ is a $ğ”˜$-class if $X âŠ† ğ”˜$;
  • in particular, $X$ is a proper class when $X âˆ‰ ğ”˜$ but $X âŠ† ğ”˜$;
  • $X$ is a $ğ”˜$-large set (or $X$ is $ğ”˜$-large for simplicity), provided $X \notâŠ† ğ”˜$.

We do not omit the prefix $ğ”˜$-, since the terminology small object has a different meaning.

Throughout, we adopt the axiom ZFCU, rather than NBGC.

(ZFCU). The axiom system of ZFCU consists of

  1. ZF axioms (Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms),
  2. the axiom of choice (AC),
  3. the axiom of universes (U), which states that every set belongs to some universe $ğ”˜$.

In conclusion, there exists a universe that accommodates the standard set-theoretic operations. Therefore, one may disregard the set-theoretic paradoxes and concentrate on the desired universe. The ensuing discussion is conducted under the assumption that the universe $ğ”˜$ is fixed; we underscore the selected universe when necessary.

Limits and Colimits

Before we proceed, it is advisable to be acquainted with the following phenomenon:

The functor of restriction is expected to commute with functors; under suitable circumstances, the restriction possesses bi-adjoints.

This likely arises from the principle of associativity, as the restriction operates on the right. Let $\mathcal{C}^â†’ = ğ…ğ®ğ§ğœğ­ (â†’ , \mathcal{C})$ denote the morphism category, wherein the collection of objects is $ğ–¬ğ—ˆğ—‹(\mathcal{C})$ and the morphisms are commutative squares.

Show in steps that

  1. the assignments $s,t : \mathcal{C}^â†’ â†’ \mathcal{C}$ determined by $f âˆˆ (s(f), t(f))_{\mathcal{C}}$ are functors;
  2. the trivial assignment $X â†¦ 1_X$ is a functor from $\mathcal{C}$ to $\mathcal{C}^â†’$;
  3. $t âŠ£ 1_âˆ™ âŠ£ s$ is an adjoint triple, $1_âˆ™$ restricts morphisms to objects;
  4. the adjoint triple extends to a quintuple when $\mathcal{C}$ exhibits initial and terminal objects.

When we generalise $â†’$ to a $ğ”˜$-small diagram $I$, the functor $1_âˆ™$ assigns each object $X$ to an $X$-valued diagram of type $I$. The bi-adjoints (if they exist) of $1_âˆ™: \mathcal{C} â†’ \mathcal{C}^I$ coincide with the definition of colimit and limit functor.

(Limit and Colimit). The limit and colimit of the functor from the $ğ”˜$-small diagram $I$ to $\mathcal{C}$ are defined as the adjoint triple $\varinjlim _I âŠ£ 1_âˆ™ âŠ£ \varprojlim _I$.

Show that the above definitions coincide with the standard definitions of limit and colimit in diagrams.

(Co)Limit is the universal (co)cone whose conic node is the most proximate to the base diagram.

(Completeness). Say the category $\mathcal{C}$ admits the (co)limit of type $I$, provided the existence of arbitrary (co)limits of type $I â†’ \mathcal{C}$. Say $\mathcal{C}$ is

  1. $ğ”˜$-(co)complete, provided it admits all (co)limits of type $I$ ($I âˆˆ ğ”˜$);
  2. finitely (co)complete, provided it admits all (co)limits of type $I$ ($I$ is finite);
  3. the term bicomplete stands for both complete and cocomplete.

Suppose that $\mathcal{C}$ is additive.

  1. Show that $\mathcal{C}$ is Abelian if and only if it is finitely bicomplete, and $\ker\operatorname{cok}=\operatorname{cok}\ker$.
  2. Find a finitely bicomplete $\mathcal{C}$ such that $\ker\operatorname{cok} â‰‡ \operatorname{cok}\ker$. (Hint: consider the category of finite filtration over abelian groups).

Let $F : \mathcal{C} â†’ \mathcal{D}$ be a functor, and $X_âˆ™ : I â†’ \mathcal{C}$ be an $I$-diagram in $\mathcal{C}$ (as an object in the functor category $\mathcal{C}^I$ assigning $i$ to $X_i$). We shall frequently adopt the following notation.

  • (Preserving). Say $F$ preserves (or commutes with) the limit of $X_âˆ™$, if the induced cone $F(\varprojlim _I X) â†’ FX_âˆ™$ is already the limit.
  • (Reflecting). Say $F$ reflects the limit of $X_âˆ™$, if, if the induced cone $F(Y) â†’ FX_âˆ™$ is the limit, then $Y$ is the limit of $X_âˆ™$ in the category $\mathcal{C}$.
  • (Creating). Say $F$ creates the limit of $X_âˆ™$, if the limit $\varprojlim _IFX$ exists in $\mathcal{D}$ and the entire cone is an image of the unique limit cone in $\mathcal{C}$ (in short, the limit in $\mathcal{C}$ is uniquely determined by that in $\mathcal{D}$).

The terminologies are clearly explained in the following example.

Let $F : \mathcal{C} â†’ \mathcal{D}$ be a functor between Abelian categories.

  1. Say $F$ preserves the limit of type $\ker$, if any exact sequence of the form $0 â†’ K \xrightarrow i X \xrightarrow f Y$ in $\mathcal{C}$ implies the exact sequence $0 â†’ FK \xrightarrow{Fi} FX \xrightarrow{Ff} FY$ in $\mathcal{D}$.
  2. Say $F$ reflects the limit of type $\ker$, if any exact sequence of the form $0 â†’ FK \xrightarrow{Fi} FX \xrightarrow{Ff} FY$ in $\mathcal{D}$ implies the exact sequence $0 â†’ K \xrightarrow i X \xrightarrow f Y$ in $\mathcal{C}$.
  3. Say $F$ creates the limit of type $\ker$, if any exact sequence of the form $0 â†’ H \xrightarrow{j} FX \xrightarrow{Ff} FY$ in $\mathcal{D}$ implies the exact sequence $0 â†’ K \xrightarrow i X \xrightarrow f Y$ in $\mathcal{C}$ such that $j = Fi$ and $H = FK$.

We summarise some special functors that preserve, reflect, or create limits and colimits.

  1. A left exact/right exact/exact functor is defined to preserve all finite limits/finite colimits/finite limits and colimits.
  2. A fully faithful functor reflects all limits and colimits.
  3. Concrete forgetful functors usually create small limits and filtered colimits, e.g., the forgetful functor from $ğŒğ¨ğ_k$ to $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$, from $ğ†ğ«ğ©ğ¬$ to $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$, from $ğ‚ğ‡$ (the category of compact Hausdorff spaces) to $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$, from sheaves to presheaves over algebraic structures, and from $C(\mathcal{B})$ the category of chain complexes to $\mathcal{B}^â„¤$, etc.

If a forgetful functor $U : \mathcal{C} â†’ \mathcal{D}$ creates the colimits or limits of type $I$, then it suffices to compute $\varinjlim _I$ or $\varprojlim_I$ in $\mathcal{D}$, so that the result automatically lies in $\mathcal{C}$.

(Pullback Functor). The pullback functor $Ï† ^âˆ— : \mathcal{C}^J â†’ \mathcal{C} ^I$ is defined as the functor that assigns to each $J$-valued diagram $F$ the precomposition $F âˆ˜ Ï†$, where $Ï† : I â†’ J$ is a functor between $ğ”˜$-small diagrams.

The trivial functor of diagrams $Ï† : I â†’ \{âˆ—\}$ induces the pullback functor $Ï† ^âˆ— = 1_âˆ™ : \mathcal{C} â†’ \mathcal{C}^I$. Whenever such a pullback has a right (left) adjoint, the (co)limit exists.

Suppose $Ï†$ is an inclusion of a subcategory that is bijective on objects (a lluf subcategory in the sense of P. Freyd). Demonstrate that $Ï†^âˆ—$ creates all limits and colimits, assuming $\mathcal{C}$ is bicomplete.

  • For example, the inclusion of chain complexes into the graded category $C(\mathcal{B}) â†’ \mathcal{B}^â„¤$ is induced by pullback. When computing the (co)limit of chain complexes, one may proceed degreewise.

A note on Kan Extension

The Definition

The ideal of Kan extension is simple: to find the biadjoints of the pullback functor $Ï† ^âˆ—$. Both limits and colimits are special cases of Kan extensions. We use $Ï†_!$ and $Ï†_âˆ—$ to denote the functorial construction of left and right Kan extension, respectively. The desired adjoints are $Ï†_! âŠ£ Ï†^! = Ï†^âˆ— âŠ£ Ï†_âˆ—$ (we shall not discuss the sheaf theory here, the notion is not misleading).

(Left Kan Extension). The left Kan extension of the functor $F : I â†’ \mathcal{C}$ along $Ï† : I â†’ J$ is the left adjoint $Ï†_! : \mathcal{C}^I â†’ \mathcal{D}^J$ to the pullback functor $Ï†^!$.

It is straightforward to demonstrate the universal property using diagrams. For example, the existence of $Ï† _! F$ signifies that $(F, Ï† ^âˆ— (-))$ is representable, as illustrated below.

We explain the universal property of $Ï† _!$ in diagrams.



The red pair $(Ï† _! F, Î±)$ satisfy the following universal property: for any commutative diagram $Î³ : F â‡’ R âˆ˜ Ï†$, there is a unique $Î¸$ making the diagram commute.

In short, $Î± : F â‡’ (Ï† _!F) âˆ˜ Ï†$ is initial amongst the pairs $? : F â‡’ (-) âˆ˜ Ï†$.

(Right Kan Extension). The right Kan extension of the functor $F : I â†’ \mathcal{C}$ along $Ï† : I â†’ J$ is the right adjoint $Ï†_âˆ— : \mathcal{C}^I â†’ \mathcal{D}^J$ to the pullback functor $Ï†^âˆ—$.

We elucidate the universal property of $Ï† _âˆ—$ using diagrams. In this context, all $2$-arrows are reversed (while the $1$-arrows remain unchanged) compared to the preceding diagram, and $Ï† _!$ is replaced by $Ï† _âˆ—$.



Here $Î± : (Ï† _âˆ— F) âˆ˜ Ï† â‡’ F$ is terminal amongst the pairs $? : (-) âˆ˜ Ï† â‡’ F$.

Show that (co)limits are special cases of Kan extensions via the diagrams below. The double arrow are nothing but the (co)unit of the adjunction.



Example: Homology from Limits

We show an example of Kan extension in theory of group representation. Any group $G$ is considered as a category $BG$ with a single object, and the morphisms are the group elements. A representation of $G$ in $ğŒğ¨ğ _k$ is exactly a functor $F : G â†’ ğŒğ¨ğ _k$.

(Fixed points as a limit). $M := F(âˆ—)$ is clearly a $kG$-module by definition. One may guess and verify that $\varprojlim_{BG} F â†’ F(âˆ—)$ is the inclusion of the fixed points $M^G$ into $M$. Show that this is also the $0$-th (relative) cohomology group $$\begin{equation} H^0(G,M) := \mathrm{Hom}_{kG}(k, M). \end{equation}$$ Here $(âˆ‘ c_i g_i) : k â†’ k,\quad a â†¦ âˆ‘ c_i a$ makes $k$ a trivial $kG$-module.
Hint: discuss the ses $0 â†’ IG â†’ kG â†’ k â†’ 0$, and identify $\mathrm{Hom}_{kG}(k, M)$ as a subgroup of $M$ via $(\operatorname{cok}(-),?) â‰ƒ \ker (-, ?)$.

(Orbits as a colimit). $M := F(âˆ—)$ is clearly a $kG$-module by definition. The Construction

We shall discuss the construction and existence of Kan extensions. Let $Ï† : I â†’ J$ be a functor between $ğ”˜$-small diagrams, and let $F : I â†’ \mathcal{C}$ be a functor from the diagram to the category $\mathcal{C}$.

  1. For each $j âˆˆ J$, associate a cone $j / I$ via the pullback of $j / J$ along $Ï†$, which amalgamates $j$ and $\operatorname{im} i$ in an appropriate category. As a category, the objects of $j / I$ are morphisms of the form $f : j â†’ Ï† (i)$, and the morphisms are commutative squares of the form $(1_j, Ï† (?))$.
  2. The functor $F$ is defined on $j / I$ via the pullback along the forgetful functor $j / I â†’ I,\quad (f , i) â†¦ i$.
  3. The assignment $j â†¦ \varprojlim F|_{j / I}$ is functorial, serving as the pointwise construction of $Ï† _âˆ— F$.
  4. The natural transformation $Î± : (Ï† _âˆ— F) âˆ˜ Ï† â‡’ F$ is induced by the universal property of the limit cone. For each $i âˆˆ I$, the morphism $Î± _i : \varprojlim F|_{Ï† (i) / I} â†’ F(i)$ is the structure morphism of the limit cone, where $F(i) = F|_{Ï† (i) / I} ((1_{Ï† (i)}), i)$.

Hence, when $\mathcal{C}$ is complete/cocomplete, the right/left Kan extension always exists.

On Derived Functors

The concept of derived functors was (probably) initially discovered by A. Grothendieck, albeit without a functorial formulation; a formal statement is attributed to J.-L. Verdier in his doctoral thesis in 1967. We follow P. R. Deligneâ€™s definition, which is, in my view, the most accessible. Subsequently, we provide an explanation in terms of Kan extension.

Broadly speaking, derived categories serve as a universal invariant of a category. For instance, the invariants of an algebra $A$, including $Z(A)$ the centre, $K_i(A)$ the $K$-groups, and $HH^âˆ™ (A,A)$ the Hochschild cohomologies, are defined over $D(A)$. Consequently, derived functors induce the morphisms between these invariants.

For the construction, let $F : \mathcal{A} â†’ \mathcal{B}$ be an additive functor between additive categories, which induces the triangular functors $C(\mathcal{A}) â†’ C(\mathcal{B})$ between chain complexes, and $K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ K(\mathcal{B})$ between the homotopy categories of chain complexes. When the categories are Abelian, the collection of quasi-isomorphisms forms a multiplicative system for the homotopy category (or the chain complex category), which yields a relatively straightforward construction of the localisation $Q_\mathcal{A} : C(\mathcal{A}) â†’ D(\mathcal{A})$. Since $F$ need not preserve quasi-isomorphisms, the functor $C(\mathcal{A}) â†’ C(\mathcal{B}) â†’ D(\mathcal{B})$ does not, in general, extend along the localisation $Q_\mathcal{A}$. It is futile to seek $D(\mathcal{A}) â†’ D(\mathcal{B})$ which renders the square commutative; Kan extensions appear to be the most suitable replacement.

We demonstrate, through exercises, that Deligneâ€™s construction of right derived functors is equivalent to the left Kan extension of the localisation, and clarify how a well-known criterion for the existence of right derived functors is a special case of the existence of Kan extensions.

(Deligneâ€™s construction of right derived functor $ğ‘ F$). Let $F : \mathcal{A} â†’ \mathcal{B}$ be additive between Abelian $k$-categories. We firstly define the bi-assignment $$\begin{equation} ğ« F : (D\mathcal{B})^{\mathrm{op}} Ã— (D\mathcal{A}) â†’ ğŒğ¨ğ _k, \quad (b,a) â†¦ (ğ« F)(b,a), \end{equation}$$ and then wish it to be represented by $(b, (ğ‘ F)(a))_{D\mathcal{B}}$. The $ğ”˜$-class $(ğ« F)(b,a)$ is defined as follows: the base set is a $ğ”˜$-class in general, consisting of the pairs of morphisms $$\begin{equation} \left(b \xrightarrow f Fa', a'\xleftarrow[\text{quasi-iso}] s a\right) âˆˆ ğ–¬ğ—ˆğ—‹(\mathcal{B}) Ã— ğ–¬ğ—ˆğ—‹(\mathcal{A}). \end{equation}$$

The equivalency relation $(f,s) âˆ¼ (g,t)$ is generated by the following relations:

Observe that the assignment $X â†¦ Q_\mathcal{A}(I(X))$ is functorial for $X âˆˆ \mathcal{A}$. It follows from the Eilenberg-Cartan resolution that the injective resolutions of chain complexes remain functorial when considered in $D(\mathcal{A})$.

When $\mathcal{A}$ possesses enough projectives, one may revise the aforementioned construction of $ğ‘ F$.

  1. One may restrict the complexes to be bounded below, and work with $D^+ \mathcal{A}$ instead;
  2. One may introduce $K_{\mathrm{h \ inj}}$, the homotopy injective (or $K$-injective) complexes, and replace the injective resolution with the $K$-injective resolution.

In order to combine Kan extension with derived functors, it is necessary to verify the following.

Suppose that $Q_\mathcal{A} : \mathcal{A} â†’ S^{-1}\mathcal{A}$ is the localisation of a general category with right multiplicative system $S$. For any cocomplete category $\mathcal{B}$ with the functor $F : \mathcal{A} â†’ \mathcal{B}$, the left Kan extension of $F$ along $Q_\mathcal{A}$ is given by the filtered colimit $$\begin{equation} (Q_\mathcal{A})_âˆ— F : X â†¦ \varinjlim _{X \xrightarrow[âˆˆ S]{s} Y} F(Y). \end{equation}$$

In the computation of derived categories, there are usually suitable conditions such that $\varinjlim _{X \xrightarrow[âˆˆ S]{s} Y} F(Y)$ is straightforward to compute.

(The existence of right derived functor). Let $F : \mathcal{A} â†’ \mathcal{B}$ be a functor of Abelian categories, with induced triangulated functor $F : K(\mathcal{A}) â†’ K(\mathcal{B})$ between homotopy categories. Suppose that there is a triangulated subcategory $\mathcal{T} âŠ† K(\mathcal{A})$ such that the following conditions hold:

Then the filtered colimit $(Q_\mathcal{A})_! F X$ is represented by $Q_\mathcal{B}(F(X_\mathcal{T}))$. In particular, the right derived functor $ğ‘ F$ exists, and is given by the Kan extension $(Q_\mathcal{A})_! F$.

Simplicial Methods

This note represents merely the tip of the iceberg concerning simplicial methods in model categories, which constitute a powerful tool in homotopy theory as well as the fundamental language of $âˆ$-categories. The aim of this note is to provide a foundation for further study of model structures. For a more comprehensive treatment of this subject, the reader is referred to kerodon.

Simplicial Objects

Before proceeding, it is illuminating to consider a perspective from F. Lawvere. Broadly speaking, to assert that $A$ is a $k$-algebra is to say that $A$ is a ring object in $ğŒğ¨ğ_k$. Analogously, one may say that a simplicial set is a simplicial object in $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$ and thenceforth focus on the simplicial structure.

Basics

(Basics of the category $Î”$). The category $Î”$ comprises finite ordinals (denoted by $[n]$ for $n âˆˆ â„¤ _{â‰¥ 0}$) and order-preserving maps. For $0 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n$, there exist two distinguished morphisms:

  • $d^i : [n-1] â†’ [n]$, an injection omitting $i$, known as the $i$-th face map;
  • $s^i : [n+1] â†’ [n]$, a surjection duplicating $i$, known as the $i$-th degeneracy map.

It is straightforward to summarise all automatic exchange relations of the face and degeneracy maps, and conclude that any morphism in $Î”$ may be uniquely written as a composition of $$\begin{equation} \underset{n _k > \cdots > n_1}{\underbrace{d^{n_k} âˆ˜ \cdots âˆ˜ d^{n_1}}} âˆ˜ \underset{m _1 < \cdots < m_l}{\underbrace{s^{m_1} âˆ˜ \cdots âˆ˜ s^{m_l}}}. \end{equation}$$

(Simplicial objects). A simplicial object in the concrete category $\mathcal{C}$ is a functor $X : Î”^{op} â†’ \mathcal{C}$. The $n$-th object of $X$ is denoted by $X([n])$ or $X_n$, serving as a collection of all $n$-dimensional objects. The pullbacks $s^i$ and $d^i$ are denoted by $s_i$ and $d_i$, respectively.

For $\mathcal{C} = ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$, the simplicial sets are precisely the simplicial objects. A representative functor $Î” ^n := (-, [n])$ is known as a standard $n$-simplex, since an element in $X_n$ is characterised by a morphism in $(Î” ^n , X)$.

The Truncation

An $n$-simplex is an element $Ïƒ âˆˆ X_n â‰ƒ (Î” ^n , X)$, denoted by $(Ïƒ , [n])$ or simply $Ïƒ$. The (combinatorial) dimension $\dim Ïƒ$ is defined as the largest $m$ such that $Ïƒ$ factors through $Î” ^m$. The simplex $(Ïƒ, [n])$ is said to be non-degenerate if and only if $\dim Ïƒ = n$. The boundary $âˆ‚ Î” ^n$ assigns to $[m]$ the set of non-surjective morphisms in $Î” ^n ([m]) = ([m], [n])$, or, equivalently, is given by the colimit $\mathrm{coeq}\left(âˆ _{0 â‰¤ i < j â‰¤ n}Î” ^{n-2} â‡‰ âˆ _{0 â‰¤ k â‰¤ n} Î” ^{n-1}\right)$.

((Co)skeleton). For a simplicial set $X$, the $n$-skeleton functor may be defined in any of the following equivalent manners:

  • as the colimit obtained by amalgamating all $n$-simplices contained within $X$ (that is, truncating to the part with $\dim â‰¤ n$), i.e., $\mathrm{sk}_n (X) = \varinjlim _{(Ïƒ , [n])} Î” ^n$;

Dually, the $n$-coskeleton functor may be defined in any of the following equivalent manners:

  • we omit the inductive definition here, see Postnikov tower.

The purpose of the $n$-coskeleton is to fill all chambers of dimension $â‰¥ n$, so that all $Ï€ _{â‰¥ n}$ vanish. In the language of Kan extension, the inclusion $Ï† : Î” _{ â‰¤ n} â†’ Î”$ yields the restriction $Ï† ^! = Ï† ^âˆ—$. One demonstrates the existence of left and right Kan extensions, $Ï†_!$ and $Ï† _!$, as $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$ is bi-complete. The adjoint triple $L âŠ£ M âŠ£ R$ induces the adjoint endofunctor $ML âŠ£ MR$. In this case, $Ï† ^!Ï† _!$ and $Ï† ^âˆ— Ï† _âˆ—$ are the $n$-skeleton and $n$-coskeleton functors, respectively.

The Topologies

Motivation for Simplicial Methods

What is the origin of the concept of simplicial methods? How should one understand simplicial objects in a concrete, particularly geometric manner? The introduction of topological ideas provides a framework to address these questions.

A Categorical Overview

The usual category of topological spaces, $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$, consists of topological spaces as its objects, and continuous maps as the morphisms. $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ possesses equalisers (with subspace topology) and arbitrary products (with product topology); in particular, the limit exists. $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ also possesses coequalisers (with quotient topology) and arbitrary coproducts (with coproduct topology); in particular, the colimit exists.

$ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ is bicomplete. In particular, $âˆ…$ is initial and $\{âˆ…\}$ is terminal in $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$, equipped with the unique topology.

The forgetful functor to the underlying set admits the left adjoint assigning each set the discrete topology, and a right adjoint assigning each set the $\{\{âˆ…\}, \text{all}\}$-topology.

By adjoints, the forgetful functor commutes with limits and colimits. Hence, the underlying set of the (co)limit of topological spaces is computed elementwise.

The category $(ğ“ğ¨ğ©, Ã—, \{âˆ—\})$ is symmetric monoidal. The $\mathcal{HOM}$-functor occasionally exists for special subcategories. The Hom space $(X, Y)_{ğ“ğ¨ğ©}$ is equipped with the compact-open topology wherein the topological basis is characterised by $$\begin{equation} \mathcal{O}_{U, K} = \{f âˆ£ f(K) âŠ† U\}_{K \ \text{is compact,}\ U \ \text{is open}}. \end{equation}$$ We denote the topological Hom object by $\mathcal{HOM}(X,Y)$. When $Y$ is locally compact Hausdorff, there is a natural isomorphism (currying): $$\begin{equation} (-, \mathcal{HOM}(Y, ?))_{ğ“ğ¨ğ©} â‰ƒ (- Ã— Y, ?)_{ğ“ğ¨ğ©} ,\quad Ï† â†¦ [(t,y) â†¦ (Ï†(t))(y)]. \end{equation}$$

We generally prefer a convenient category of topological spaces in which the internal $\mathcal{HOM}$ exists; moreover, such a category ought to include fundamental objects such as CW complexes, and be bicomplete (not necessarily inherited from $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$). $k$-spaces or compactly generated Hausdorff spaces (with proper mappings as the morphisms) are frequently employed, as the inclusion admits left adjoints ($k$-functor or Stone-ÄŒech compactification, respectively).

The Pointed Construction

The definition of $Ï€$-groups necessitates base points, which in turn requires the introduction of pointed topological spaces $ğ“ğ¨ğ© _+$ defined as the category of topological spaces equipped with a distinguished point.

($ğ“ğ¨ğ©_+$). The category $ğ“ğ¨ğ©_+$ is the slice category from the terminal object of $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$. The objects are defined as pairs $(X, x)$ where $x âˆˆ X$. A morphism is of the form $f : (X, x) â†’ (Y, y)$ where $f : X â†’ Y$ is a continuous map, and $f(x) = y$.

We remark upon certain categorical properties of $ğ“ğ¨ğ©_+$. The most distinguished property is that $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ is pointed, meaning that the initial and terminal objects coincide (we refer to $0 := \{âˆ—\}$ as the zero object). In general, the limit of the system $\{(X_i, x_i)\}_{i âˆˆ I}$ is $\varprojlim_I X_i$ with the base point $(x_i)_{i âˆˆ I}$. The colimit of $\{(X_i, x_i)\}$ is a quotient of $\varinjlim_I X_i âˆˆ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ obtained by identifying all $x_i$ as the new base point.

For example, let $S_âˆ™ âˆˆ ğ“ğ¨ğ© _+$ denote the unit circle with a specified base point and underlying topological space $S âˆˆ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$. Observe that $S Ã— S$ is a torus, and $S_âˆ™ Ã— S_âˆ™$ is a pointed torus with the same underlying base topological space as $S Ã— S$. However, $S âŠ” S$ is a disjoint union of two circles, whereas $S_âˆ™ âŠ” S_âˆ™$ is an $8$-shaped space formed by identifying the two base points in $S âŠ” S$.

The base point makes the cateogory algebraic, as one can define fibre sequence (analogue of exact sequence). There is a functor $(-)_+ : ğ“ğ¨ğ© â†’ ğ“ğ¨ğ© _+$ sending $X$ to $X âŠ” 0$ with the coproduct topology. $(-)_+$ is the left adjoint of the inclusion $ğ“ğ¨ğ©_+ â†’ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$; there is no adjoint triple here since neither $(-)_+$ preserves terminal objects nor the forgotful functor preserve initial objects. It is highlighted that $(-)_+$ preserves the symmetric monoidal structure, where

  • $(X âŠ” Y)_+ â‰ƒ X_+ âˆ¨ Y_+$, where $P âˆ¨ Q$ is the usual coproduct in $ğ“ğ¨ğ© _+$;
  • $(X Ã— Y)_+ â‰ƒ X_+ âˆ§ Y_+$, where $P âˆ§ Q := \frac{P Ã— Q}{P âˆ¨ Q}$ is the smash product.

The functor $(-)_+$ is strongly monoidal, which carries the monoidal structure. We restrict $(-)_+$ onto the $ğ‹ğ‚ğ‡$ and obtain $(-)_+ : ğ‹ğ‚ğ‡ â†’ ğ‹ğ‚ğ‡_+$, which also admits a right adjunction. The category $ğ‹ğ‚ğ‡$ is closed symmetric monoidal with internal Hom space $\mathcal{HOM}_{ğ‹ğ‚ğ‡} (X,Y)$ endowed with the compact-open topology. Analogously, $\mathcal{HOM}_{ğ‹ğ‚ğ‡ _+ }(X_+, Y_+)$ is also the internal Hom of $ğ‹ğ‚ğ‡ _+$ whose base point is the zero morphism $0_{Y,X}$.

Another well-known monoidal functor from $ğ‹ğ‚ğ‡$ to $ğ“ğ¨ğ© _+$ is the functor of one-point-compactification, whose essential image is precisely the pointed compact topological spaces. We do not examine this further here.

We clarify several types of equivalences of topological spaces, the (classical) homotopy equivalence, the weak homotopy equivalence.

(Homotopy by classical definition). We fix $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$. Let $I$ be the unit interval. The morphisms $f,g : X â†’ Y$ are said to be homotopic, provided the morphism $(f,g) : X âŠ” X â†’ Y$ factors through $(1,1) : X âŠ” X â†’ X Ã— I$. (Weak homotopy equivalence). As a convention, we write $[X, Y]_{\mathcal{C}} := (X, Y)_{\mathcal{C} / âˆ¼}$ for $\mathcal{C} âˆˆ \{ğ“ğ¨ğ© , ğ“ğ¨ğ© _+ , \ldots\}$. We focus on the category $ğ–§ğ—ˆ \ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$. A general morphism in $ğ–§ğ—ˆ \ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ is a finite zig-zag diagram in the sense of Gabriel-Zisman localisation. The Geometric Realisation

We introduce the adjunction between $ğ“ğ¨ğ© â‡† ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}$ in this section, where the localised adjunction is the well-known Quillen equivalence. Here $(a,x) âˆ¼ (b,y)$ via $Ï† : [n] â†’ [m]$.

The geometric realisation labels all possible $|Î”^n|$ with $X_n$, and quotients by the relation generated by the face and degeneracy maps. ($\operatorname{Sing}$). The functor $\operatorname{Sing}$ is defined as $$\begin{equation} \operatorname{Sing} : ğ“ğ¨ğ© â†’ ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}, \quad T â†¦ (|Î” ^- |, T)_{ğ“ğ¨ğ©}. \end{equation}$$

CW-approximation

The term CW complexes was introduced by J. H. C. Whitehead in 1946, providing a means to approximate topological spaces in a straightforward manner when one is concerned solely with the homotopy groups. We refer to the appendix by A. Hatcher as an elementary introduction to CW complexes. The following are more categorical in nature.

We shall first present a basic idea: the term CW denotes Closure-finiteness and Weak topology, wherein

  • Closure-finiteness signifies that each cell intersects only finitely many other cells (thus it is compactly generated, and locally contractible);
  • Weak topology refers to the topology related to $Ï€_âˆ™$-groups.

The goal of this section is to

  • show the existence of CW-approximation, and the functoriality is due to counit $|\operatorname{Sing} (X)| â†’ X$ serves as such a CW-approximation for any $X âˆˆ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$;
  • prove the Whiteheadâ€™s theorem, which states that the weak homotopy equivalence is equivalent to homotopy equivalence for CW complexes.

(The definition and construction of CW complexes). A CW complex $K$ is constructed by the following procedure. $K_0$ is a set with the discrete topology. The induction $K_{n-1} â†’ K_n$ is obtained by attaching several $|Î” ^n|$ to $|âˆ‚ Î” ^n|$ with respect to a collection of continuous maps $\{a_n ^Î» : |âˆ‚ Î” ^n| â†’ K_{n-1}\}_{Î» âˆˆ Î›_n}$. Categorically, one may view this as a pushout



A CW-complex is the union $\varinjlim _{n â‰¥ 0} K_n$ with such sequential pushouts, and every CW complex is obtained in this manner. We denote $K_n$ as the $n$-skeleton of $K$, and this definition is enlightened by the idea of the $n$-skeleton of a simplicial set, which studies homotopy theory in a purely combinatorial approach.

Show that every CW complex is the geometric realisation of a simplicial set; hence, the counit $|\operatorname{Sing}(K)| â†’ K$ is a homotopy equivalence for any CW complex $K$. Hint: the left adjoint functor preserves pushouts and colimits.

We present the principal steps of CW-approximation as follows. We assume that $X âˆˆ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ is path-connected, since the approximation is performed for each path-component separately. We aim to find for each $n â‰¥ 0$ a functorial morphism $f_n : K_n â†’ X$, where

  1. $K_n$ is a CW complex with $(K_n)_n = K_n$, and
  2. $Ï€ _k (f_n)$ is bijective for $k < n$, and is a surjection for $k = n$.

We refer to such $f_n$ as a weak homotopy $n$-equivalence or an $n$-equivalence for simplicity. The inclusion of $K_n âŠ† K$ is clearly an $n$-equivalence.

We take the $0$-equivalence $f_0 : \{âˆ—\}\ ( =: K_0) â†’ X$ and fix $x_0 := f_0(âˆ—)$ as the base points. Then we recursively construct $f_{n+1}$ from $f_{n}$ by the following steps.

  • Construct $f_{n+1}' : K_{n+1}' â†’ X$ such that $Ï€ _{â‰¤ n}(f)$ are isomorphisms by filling the (possibly) non-zero kernel of the surjection $Ï€ _n (f_n): Ï€ _n (K_n, K_0) â†’ Ï€ _n (X, x_0)$.

We assign each group element $g$ in the kernel $\ker_n$ with a map $a_g : |âˆ‚ Î” ^{n+1}| â†’ K_n$. Then there is a pushout diagram inducing $f_{n+1}' : K_{n+1}' â†’ X$:



Since $Î¹_n$ is the inclusion of $n$-truncation, the induced $f_{n+1}'$ is also an $n$-equivalence. We show that $Ï€ _n (f_{n+1}')$ is moreover injective (hence a bijection). To see this, any $h âˆˆ \ker Ï€ _n (f_{n+1}')$ has an $S_âˆ™ ^n$-representative in $K_{n+1}'$, which is assumed to be in $K_n$ by cellular approximation. By construction, $h$ is trivial.

Another concern is that $Ï€ _{n +1} (f_{n+1}')$ may be non-surjective. Hence, we need to make refinements to $f_{n+1}'$ so that $f_{n+1}$ is an $(n+1)$-equivalence.

  • To address this, we coproduct $K_{n+1}'$ with several $S_âˆ™ ^{n+1}$ labelled by non-images of $Ï€ _{n+1} (f_{n+1}')$.

To be explicit, we denote $C_n$ as the set $Ï€ _{n+1}(X,x_0) âˆ– \operatorname{im}(Ï€ _{n +1} (f_{n+1}'))$, and define $K_{n+1} := K_{n+1}' âˆ¨ â‹ _{C_n} S_âˆ™ ^{n+1}$. We assign the $h$-th $S_âˆ™ ^{n+1}$ with the corresponding non-image representative in $Ï€ _{n+1}(X, x_0)$. The induced $f_{n+1} : K_{n+1} â†’ X$ is given by coproduct, which is both surjective for $Ï€ _{n+1}$ and bijective for $Ï€ _{ â‰¤ n}$. Hence, $f_{n+1}$ is an $(n+1)$-equivalence.

We denote the CW complex $K := \varinjlim _{n â‰¥ 0} K_n$ as the CW-approximation of $X$. The construction is functorial at each step.

The following well-known theorem due to J. H. C. Whitehead (also appearing in combinatorical homotopy) is useful. The proof concerns a series of theory in algebraic topology, such as the cellular approximation, mapping cone and mapping cylinder, and the relative homotopy groups. We state only the main theorem and a sketch of the proof.

(Whiteheadâ€™s theorem). Let $f : X â†’ Y$ be a map between CW complexes. $f$ is a weak homotopy equivalence if and only if $f$ is a homotopy equivalence.

  • (special case). If $f$ is either an inclusion or a quotient, then it establishes a strong deformation retract.
  • (special case). An $n$-connected space is defined to have trivial $Ï€ _{â‰¤ n}$ groups. Over the procedure of the CW-approximation of an $n$-connected space, one may choose $K_{â‰¤ n} = \{âˆ—\}$.
  • (general case). The Whiteheadâ€™s theorem holds for relative homotopy groups. Let $f : (X, A) â†’ (Y,B)$ be a weak equivalence of relative CW complexes such that $f : A â†’ B$ is a homotopy equivalence. Then $f : (X, A) â†’ (Y, B)$ is a homotopy equivalence of pairs.

Without loss of generality, we assume $X$ and $Y$ are path-connected and $f : X â†’ Y$ is cellular (by cellular approximation). Moreover, we assume $f$ is an inclusion of subcomplexes via the homotopic equivalence $Y â†’ \mathrm{Cyl}(f)$ to the cylinder object.

When $f$ is a weak homotopy equivalence, the relative homotopy groups $Ï€_âˆ™ (Y,X)$ vanish. By the long exact sequence $Ï€ _âˆ™ (\mathrm{Cone}(f))$ vanishes, hence the mapping cone $\mathrm{Cone}(f)$ (as a CW complex) is contractible. The homotopy equivalence $\mathrm{Cone}(f) â†’ \{âˆ—\}$ constructs the strong deformation retract of $X âŠ† Y$.

Show that $|\operatorname{Sing} (X)|$ is canonically homotopy equivalent to $K$, the CW-approximation of $X$. Hint: apply $|\operatorname{Sing}(-)|$ at $K â†’ X$, and use Whiteheadâ€™s theorem.

We remark that the Whiteheadâ€™s theorem provides a (functorial) bi-fibrant replacement of objects, serving as an important technique in the study of homotopy category for model structures.

Cofibrantly Generating Class

Cofibrantly generated model structure is ubiquitous in the study of model categories. In this chapter, we do not introduce the concept of model category in general, but introduce the cofibrantly generating class and the weak factorisation system instead. The ideal traces back to D. Quillen in 1967.

The (W)FS

We begin with the concept of factorisation systems (FS), which provides a way of viewing category $\mathcal{C}$ as a compositional product of two classes of morphisms $\mathcal{L}$ and $\mathcal{R}$. The key requirements are the lifting property (orthogonality) and the (functorial) factorisation property. The writer is not certain about its origin, but it was probably introduced by G. M. Kelly in 1980. A nice introduction can be found in the CatLab of A. Joyal.

(FS). Let $\mathcal{L}$ and $\mathcal{R}$ be subclasses of $ğ–¬ğ—ˆğ—‹ (\mathcal{C})$ which are closed under compositions, isomorphisms and retracts.

  • The pair $(\mathcal{L}, \mathcal{R})$ is said to be strongly orthogonal (or orthogonal) provided that for any $l âˆˆ \mathcal{L}$, $r âˆˆ \mathcal{R}$ and any morphism $l â†’ r$ (as a commutative square), there exists a unique morphism $s : t(l) â†’ s(r)$ making the triangles commutative. We denote $\mathcal{L} âŸ‚ \mathcal{R}$.
  • The pair $(\mathcal{L}, \mathcal{R})$ is said to be weakly orthogonal provided that for any $l âˆˆ \mathcal{L}$, $r âˆˆ \mathcal{R}$ and any morphism $l â†’ r$ (as a commutative square), there exists some (not necessarily unique) morphism $s : t(l) â†’ s(r)$ making the triangles commutative. We denote $\mathcal{L} â‹” \mathcal{R}$.
  • The pair $(\mathcal{L}, \mathcal{R})$ is said to be factorial if every morphism in $\mathcal{C}$ admits some factorisation $f = r âˆ˜ l$ with $l âˆˆ \mathcal{L}$ and $r âˆˆ \mathcal{R}$.

A (weak) factorisation system, abbreviated as (W)FS, comprises $\mathcal{L}$ and $\mathcal{R}$ satisfying the axioms of (weak) orthogonality and factorisation.

Show that for either FS or WFS, one has $\mathcal{L} = {}^âŸ‚(\mathcal{L}^âŸ‚)$ or $\mathcal{L} = {}^â‹” (\mathcal{L}^â‹”)$. In general, an arbitrary class of morphisms generates two (W)FSâ€™s by a Galois connection-like construction. Quillenâ€™s Small Object Argument

We enumerate the relevant set-theoritic definitions in this section, and prove Quillenâ€™s small object argument without hesitation. Simplicial and topological explanations are given in the proceeding sections.

The notion small is over-used, this does not the same as $ğ”˜$-small introduces a priori. When there is a class of morphisms $S$ which is considered to be relatively small to some ordinal $Î±$, it is possible to construction a WFS by a reasonable induction. The construction is not canonical since it depends on the choice of $Î±$.

We firstly explain the notion of small based on the cofinality of ordinals. We identify an ordinal (ususally a limit oridnal) $Î³$ as a poset category with $ğ–®ğ–»(Î³ ) = \{Î² âˆ£ Î² < Î³ \}$. A $Î³$-sequence in $\mathcal{C}$ is a functor $Î³ â†’ \mathcal{C}$. Say $Î³$ is $Î³ '$-filtered if $Î³$ has stronger confinality than $Î³ '$, i.e., for any inclusion $Î¹ : Î³ ' â†’ Î³$ of posets, the limit oridinal $\varinjlim Î¹$ is strictly smaller than $Î³$. We remark that

  • It suffices to define $Î³$-filtration where $Î³'$ is a cardinal;
  • For a finite cardianl $Îº$, the $Îº$-filtered oridnals are exactly the limit oridnals.
  • For any cardinal $Îº$ (as a limit oridnal), the least $Îº$-filtered ordinal is precisely the successor cardinal of $Îº$.

(Small in Quillenâ€™s sense). Let $\mathcal{C}$ be category with colimits. A $Îº$-small object $X$ is such that the functor $(X, -)_\mathcal{C}$ preserves all colimits indexed by $Îº$-filtered ordinals. A small object is defined as a $Îº$-small object for some cardinal $Îº$.

An $Îº$-small object relative to a class of morphism $S$ is such that $(X, - )_\mathcal{C}$ preserves all colimits idenxed by $Îº$-filtered ordinals while taking value in $S$. Say $X$ is small relative to $S$, if it is $Îº$-small relative to $S$ for some cardinal $Îº$.

For either $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬$ or $ğŒğ¨ğ_k$, an general object $X$ is a $ğ”˜$-small colimit (controlled by $Îº$) of compact objects (i.e., $(K, -)$ preserves filtered colimits, for instance $|K|$ is finitely presented). Now $(X, - )$ is $Îº$-small, as $Îº$-filtered colimits commutes with limits controlled by $Îº$. In particular, any set or modules are small.

(Cofibrant generation). Let $S$ be a non-empty class of morphisms in a cocomplete category. The class $S_{inj} := S^â‹”$ and $S_{cof} := ^â‹”(S^â‹”)$ denote the $S$-injective class and $S$-cofibrant class respectively. We may wish to generate $S_{cof}$ from $S$ using pushouts, coproducts, transfinite compositions and retractions. Hence, we denote by $S_{cell}$ the $S$-cell class consisting of $S$ closed under pushouts, coproducts, and transfinite compositions. Note that $S âŠ† S_{cell}âŠ† S_{cof}$.

The following small object argument demonstrates the weak orthogonality and functoriality of the pair $(S_{cell}, S_{inj})$. We show later that $S_{cof}$ is the completion of $S_{cell}$ under retractions, thus it returns to the WFS $(^â‹” (S^â‹”), S^â‹”)$.

(Small Object Argument). Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a cocomplete category with $S$ a set of morphisms. If the domains of $S$ are small relative to $C_{cell}$, then there exists a functorial factorisation of morphisms with respect to the pair $(S_{cell}, S_{inj})$.

Let $f : X â†’ Y$ be an arbitrary morphism. We demonstrate the factorisation by the following functorial construction. We set $X := X_0$, and construct $X_0 â†’ X_1$ by pushing out all commutative squares (where such exist) from an $S_{cell}$ morphism to $f$:



Clearly $X_0 â†’ X_1$ is in $S_{cell}$. We may extend the above construction to an arbitrarily long transfinite chain $S_âˆ™$ of morphisms in $S_{cell}$; however, it suffices to stop at a $Îº$-filtered ordinal $Î³$ (the domains of $S_{cell}$ are $Îº$-small by assumption). This yields the functorial factorisation $$\begin{equation} X \xrightarrow[âˆˆ S_{cell}]{} \varinjlim {}_{< Î³ } X_âˆ™ = X_Î³ \xrightarrow[âˆˆ S_{inj}] {f_Î³ } Y. \end{equation}$$

It remains to show that $f_Î³ âˆˆ S_{inj} = S^â‹”$. We take an arbitrary commutative square from $j âˆˆ S$ to $f_Î³$ in the left diagram. The morphism $u_j$ factors through $t_j$ by the definition of $Îº$-smallness. By construction of $X_Î± â†’ X_{Î± + 1}$, the entire commutative square in the left diagram factors through $f_{Î± +1}$ in the right diagram:



Now the structure map $X_{Î± +1} â†’ X_{Î³ }$ ensures the entire diagram commutes, which gives rise to the factorisation $t(j) â†’ X_{Î³ }$.

Kan Complexes

We provide a concrete exmaple of $S_{inj}$, $S_{cell}$, and $S_{cof}$ in terms of (simplicial) Kan fibrations. The class of Kan fibration ($S_{inj}$) and anodyne morphisms ($S_{cof}$) serve as the class of trivial cofibrations and fibrations in simplicial model category. The corresponding fibrant object are Kan complexes which admits a closed monoidal structure. The topological version is translaed from the adjoint lifting property.

We introduce the basic notions of simplicial complex. Let $\mathcal{I}$ denote a collection of subsets of $[n]$ ($\mathcal{I} âŠ† \mathcal{P}([n])$ for power set notion). This defines a subfunctor $Î” ^\mathcal{I} âŠ† \mathcal{D}^n$ by

$$\begin{equation} Î” ^\mathcal{I} ([m]) := \{f : [m] â†’ [n] âˆ£ âˆƒ S âˆˆ \mathcal{I}, f([m]) âŠ† S\}. \end{equation}$$

In particular, one has the standard simplex $Î” ^{n} = Î” ^{\mathcal{P}([n])}$, and the boundary $âˆ‚ Î” ^n = Î” ^{\mathcal{P}([n]) âˆ– [n]}$. A simplicial complex is of the form $Î” ^{\mathcal{I}}$ for $\mathcal{I}$ closed under taking subsets. We remark the followings

  • intuitively, if an edge belongs to a simplicial complex, then so are its end points;
  • any simplex in a simplicial complex has non-overlapping boundaries at every dimensions, e.g., the simplicial circle $Î” ^1 / âˆ‚ Î” ^1$ is never a simplicial complex;
  • one may generalise the definition to a good subfunctor of $Î” ^âˆ$ as how we define $âˆ$-CW complexes; there is no need at this moment.

We may rephrase some usual construction for categories in simplicial language. We usually view $ğ–®ğ–»(\mathcal{C})$, $ğ–¬ğ—ˆğ—‹ (\mathcal{C})$, etc, as special subcategory with operations; and may wish to state such operation atomatically. This motivate the definition of nerve, enabling tools from topology (e.g., homotopy groups, cohomology) to analyse categorical structures. We denote $ğ‚ğšğ­$ the category of $ğ”˜$-small categories ($2$-category), which is also $ğ‚ğšğ­$-enriched as the hom-sets are the usual functor categories.

(Nerve). We view each object $[n] âˆˆ Î”$ (with monotone maps) as distinct subcategories, which gives the inclusion of full subcategory $â„“ : Î” â†’ ğ‚ğšğ­$. Now the categorical object in $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}$ ($âˆ$-cateogry more precisely) $\mathrm N(\mathcal{C}) := (â„“ (-), \mathcal{C})_{ğ‚ğšğ­}$ is called the nerve of the category.

Show the left adjoint of $\mathrm N(?)$. Hint: the functor $Ï† := |Î”^âˆ™| : Î” â†’ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ defines $\operatorname{Sing} : ğ“ğ¨ğ© â†’ ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}$ by pulling back the Yoneda embedding. Here we replace $Ï†$ by $â„“ : Î” â†’ ğ‚ğšğ­$. Once we show the existence of such left adjoint $ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}} â†’ ğ‚ğšğ­$, verify the following is our desired construction:

  • $ğ–®ğ–» (\mathrm h (X)) := X_0$,
  • $ğ–¬ğ—ˆğ—‹ (\mathrm h (X)) := X_1 / âˆ¼$ by identifying $s_0(v) := 1_v$ and $d_0 (e) âˆ˜ d_1 (e) = d_2 (e)$.

Unlike $|-| âŠ£ \operatorname{Sing}$, the functor $\mathrm N$ is fully faithful. The counit morphism tautologically assign the folding of freelised category to itself, which is a natural isomorphism. Unlike general topology, category has no $âˆ$-path as in topologistâ€™s sine function. This is how $ğ‚ğšğ­$ better than $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ in some aspect. Whereas one good thing of $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ is that all paths are invertible, which we shall see as follows.

We denote $Î›^n _i := Î” ^{\mathcal{P}([n]) âˆ– \{[n], [n]âˆ– \{i\}\}}$ as the $i$-th horn of $Î”^n$. Graphically, $Î› ^n_i$ is obtained by deleting the interior and the $i$-th face of $Î”^n$. $Î› ^n _i$ is an inner horn, provided $0 < i < n$. The inclusions maps are called (inner) horn inclusions. We show the definition of $âˆ$-category by the following fact:

Any singular set of a topological complex lifts horn inclusions. Explicitly, for any horn inclusion $Î¹ : Î› _i ^n â†ª Î” ^n$, the morphism $Ï† : Î› _i ^n â†’ \operatorname{Sing} (X)$ lifts up to $\widetilde Ï† : Î” ^n â†’ \operatorname{Sing}(X)$ via $Î¹$. Hint: $(Î¹ , \operatorname{Sing} (X))_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}}$ is surjective iff so is $(|Î¹|, X)_{ğ“ğ¨ğ©}$.

We call such those simplicial sets lifting all (inner) horn fillings (weak) Kan complexes. By invertibility of all paths, any singular set of a topological complex are Kan complexes; a general category is a weak Kan complex as only the composition rule works fine. A category with all invertible paths (aka groupoid) is a Kan complex, the converse holds true by combinatoric verification.

Let $S$ denote the horn fillings temporality. The simplicial set $X$ is a Kan complex if and only if $X â†’ \{âˆ…\}$ belongs to $S_{inj}$. We call $S_{inj}$ the class of Kan fibrations. By general theory of lifting property, Kan fibrations are closed under retracts, pullbacks, products, and transfinite co-composition of a tower. The class left lifting class $S_{cof}$ are called the acyclic cofibrations, or anodyne morphisms. By Quillenâ€™s small object argument, $S_{cof}$ is precisely the closure of horn inclusions under isomorphisms, transfinite compositions, coprodcuts and retracts. The terms anodyne or acyclic means to be inoffensive or harmless to homology groups: the transdental induction keeps on filling the holes in the construction of Quillenâ€™s small object argument.

Adjoint Lifting

We introduce the smash product of morphisms and morphism spaces for simplicial comlexes, which shows more closure properties of $S_{inj}$ and $S_{cof}$. Many of the categories in practice are self-enrichend, meaning that every Hom-set is a object in the same category. We may obtain better results analogous of currying (the tensor-hom adjunction). The adjoint lifting serves as a bridge connecting the smash product for cofibrations and morphism spaces for fibrations. We complete this section by showing a criterion (probably initially discovered by A. Joyal, see quasi-categories):

  • $X$ is a Kan complex ($(âˆ,1)$-category), if and only if $\mathcal{HOM}(Î”^1, X) \xrightarrow {(Î” ^0 â†ª Î” ^1) ^âˆ— }\mathcal{HOM}(Î”^0, X)$ belongs to $ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨ ^â‹”$;
  • $X$ is a weak Kan complex ($âˆ$-category), if and only if $\mathcal{HOM}(Î”^2, X) \xrightarrow {(Î›^2_1 â†ª Î” ^2) ^âˆ— }\mathcal{HOM}(Î›^2_1, X)$ belongs to $ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨ ^â‹”$.

The key requirement of $âˆ$-categories ($(âˆ,1)$-categories) is to be closed under compositions (invese maps).

The product and coproducts of simplicials sets are defined pointwise as they are presheaves over $Î”$. We remark that the product of standard simplicial sets $Î” ^m$ and $Î” ^n$ is of dimension $m+n$ by shuffle construction. The prodcut of degenerated objects are not necessary degenereted, as shown in previous dimensional analysis. One concrete example is $\binom{[001]}{[011]} âˆˆ Î” ^1 Ã— Î” ^1$.

(The morphism space). The morphism space is given by a bi-functor $$\begin{equation} \mathcal{HOM}(-, ?) : (ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}})^{\mathrm{op}} Ã— ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}} â†’ ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}, \end{equation}$$

such that $(âˆ™ , \mathcal{HOM}(-,?))_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}} â‰ƒ (- Ã— âˆ™ ,?)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}}$ is a functorial adjunction.

We show the existence of morphism spaces by construction. Firstly show that the endofunctor $K Ã— -$ preserves all colimits. Then consider the natural isomorphisms

$$\begin{aligned} (K Ã— X, Y)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}} & â‰ƒ (\varinjlim_â„• K Ã— Î” ^n, Y)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}} \\ & â‰ƒ \varprojlim_â„• (Î” ^n, (K Ã— Î” ^âˆ™, Y)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}})_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}} \\ & â‰ƒ (X, (K Ã— Î” ^âˆ™, Y)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}})_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}} \xlongequal{ \text{def} } (X, \mathcal{HOM}(K, Y))_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}}. \end{aligned}$$

The simplicial set $[n] â†¦ (K Ã— Î” ^n, Y)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}}$ is the morphism space $\mathcal{HOM}(K,Y)$.

We remark that

  • the usual set of morphism $(K,Y)_{ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}}}$ is $\mathcal{HOM}(K,Y)$ at $0$-th degree;
  • by Yoneda, the $(K Ã— -) âŠ£ \mathcal{HOM}(K,-)$ is the same thing as the natural isomorphism $\mathcal{HOM}(K Ã— -, ?) â†’ \mathcal{HOM}(-, \mathcal{HOM}(K, ?))$;
  • the enriched composition $\mathcal{HOM}(Y, Z) Ã— \mathcal{HOM}(X,Y) â†’ \mathcal{HOM}(X,Z)$ is characterised degree-wise, where the morphisms $g_k : Y Ã— Î” ^k â†’ Z$ and $f_k : X Ã— Î” ^k â†’ Y$ gives $(g âˆ˜ f) _k : X Ã— Î” ^k \xrightarrow{X Ã— \text{diagonal}} X Ã— Î” ^k Ã— Î” ^k â†’ Z$;
  • the pull backs are reasonable constructions of morphism spaces, e.g., $\varprojlim \mathcal{HOM}(A_âˆ™ , -)$ is represented by $\mathcal{HOM}(\varinjlim A_âˆ™, -)$ by Yoneda lemma, and $\varprojlim \mathcal{HOM}(-, B_âˆ™)$ is corepresented by $\mathcal{HOM}(-, \varprojlim B_âˆ™)$ by commuting right adjoints.

We pointout a functorial construction of mapping space.

For simplicial morphisms $f : X â†’ Y$ and $g : A â†’ B$, we consider the morphism induced by the pullback:



We denote $â‹† : (âˆ™ , \mathcal{HOM}(-, ?)) â‰ƒ (- Ã— âˆ™ , ?)$ the natural isomorphism, and $f âˆ§ m$ is obtained by pushout morphism of the functorial square $(f, m) : X Ã— P â†’ Y Ã— Q$. Then, the existence of the lifting map $s$ in the up diagram is equivalent to that of $t$ in the down diagram:



This also shows that for collection of morphisms $S$ and $T$, one has $T âˆ§ (^â‹” S) = {}^â‹” (Î¦ (T,S))$. To conclude, the intersections of pre-images is again saturated.

For a fixed morphism $Ï†$, the left adjoint functor $Ï† âˆ§ (-)$ preserves retractions, transfinite compositions, coproducts, and pushouts. When Quillenâ€™s small objects argument holds, $Ï† âˆ§ (-)$ preserves the left morphism class of WFS.

The smash product of morphisms is compatible with the usual smash product for pointed simplicial sets, defined as ${X âˆ Y} / {X âˆ Y}$, as explained in the following exercise.

Suppose all simplicial sets are non-empty! Let $\operatorname{cok} : (ğ’ğğ­ğ¬^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}})^â†’ â†’ (ğ’ğğ­ğ¬^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}})_+$ denote the cokernel functor whose right adjoint is the inclusion $(X, x_0) â†¦ ((x_0, x_0) â†’ (X,x_0))$. Show that such adjunctions preserves smash product:



Hint: deduce this to smash product of monomorphisms.

Similarly, for $a : \{âˆ—\} â†’ A$ and $b : \{âˆ—\} â†’ B$, the morphism $Î¦ (a,b)$ identifies the pointed mapping space $((A,a), (B,b))_{(ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}})_+}$.

We use smash product to simplify the discription of generating set of horn inclusions. We fix $Ï† : \{âˆ—\} â†ª Î” ^1$ as the inclusion of $0$, and show that the following collections of morphisms generate the same $S_{cof}$ class:

  1. ($S$). the collection of horn inclusions $Î› ^n _i â†ª Î” ^n$ for $0 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n$;
  2. ($T$). the collection of $Ï† âˆ§ f$, for $f$ an arbitrary monomorphism.

The class $S$ consisting of horn inclusions and $T := Ï† âˆ§ ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨$ generates the same $(-)_{cof}$ class.

We show that $S âŠ† T_{cof}$ by verifying that any horn inclusion $i$ is a retract of $Ï† âˆ§ i : \square â†’ Î”^1 Ã— Î” ^n$. We firstly consider the case $i : Î› _k^n â†’ Î” ^n$ for $k < n$. Let $Î¹ _1 : ? â†ª (Î” ^1 Ã— ?)$ denote the functorial inclusion to cordinate $1$. It is straightforward to construct the commutative diagram:



The choice of $p$ is not unique; we want to find $p$ such that the dashed arrow exists. We take $p$ as follows:



Back to the retraction diagram. The composition of the bottom line is identical, since $p$ is identical on $\{1\} Ã— Î” ^n$. The inclusion $Î” ^1 Ã— Î› ^n _k â†ª \square$ attach $Î”^n$ over $\{0\} Ã— Î› ^n _k$, which degenerates into $Î›^n _k$ via $p$. This completes the proof for $k < n$. One can similarly show the case $k = n$ by replacing $Î¹ _1$ with $Î¹_0$, and define $p$ as follows:



Conversely, we show that $T âŠ† S_{cof}$. We note that any monomorphism of simplicial sets are obtaiend by adjoining cells. Hence, it suffices to show for all boudaray inclusions $c^n : âˆ‚ Î” ^n â†ª Î” ^n$ in $ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨$. We show that $(Ï† âˆ§ c^n) âˆˆ S_{cof}$.

We know that there are $n+2$ non-degenrated standard simplices $Î” ^{n+1}$ in $Î” ^1 Ã— Î” ^n$ determined by $(p,q)$-shuffle. We iteratively attaching $Î› ^{n+1}_k$-horns with $0 â‰¤ k â‰¤ (n+1)$ along the buttom edge:



Crearly, $i âˆ§ S_{cof} âŠ† S_{cof}$ for any monomorphism $i$. We apply adjoint lifting to the above equivalent characterisation of $S_{cof}$, and see that $Î¦ (i, -)$ preserves Kan fibrations for arbitrary monomorphism $i$. In particular, for any simplicial set $X$ and Kan complex $F$, the morphism space $\mathcal{HOM}(X,F)$ is again a Kan complex. Hence we obtain a criterion for Kan complexes:

  • $F$ is a Kan complex ($(âˆ,1)$-category), if and only if the pullback $\mathcal{HOM}(Î” ^1 , F) \xrightarrow {Ï† ^âˆ— } F$ lifts all monomorphisms.

This criterion has to do with path-homotopy. When $F^I â†’ F$ lifts all monomorphisms, $F$ has invertible edges.

Let $S'$ denote the set of inner horn inclusions. Show that $S'_{cof}$ is also generated by $Ïˆ âˆ§ ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨$ for $Ïˆ : Î› ^2_1 â†ª Î” ^2$. Hint: by $\{c_n : âˆ‚ Î” ^n â†ª Î” ^n\}_{cof} = ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨ _{cof}$, it suffices to show

  1. $(Ïˆ âˆ§ c_n) âˆˆ S'_{cof}$, and
  2. any inner horn inclusions belongs to $(Ïˆ âˆ§ ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨)_{cof}$.

The proof of 1. is similar to the above. The retraction $Î” ^n â†ª Î” ^1 Ã— Î” ^n â†  Î” ^n$ may constructed as follows. The monomorphism is



The epimorphism is



The proof of 2. show inductively that $\square â†ª Î” ^2 Ã— Î” ^n$ is nothing but a completion of compositions.

The above criterion (along with adjoint lifting) shows that for any $i âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨$, $Î¦ (i, -)$ preserves trivial Kan fibrations. In particular,

  • for any simplicial set $X$, the functor $\mathcal{HOM}(X, -)$ preserves weak Kan complexes ($âˆ$-categories);
  • $V$ is a weak Kan-complex ($âˆ$-category), if and only if the pullback $\mathcal{HOM}(Î” ^2, V) \xrightarrow {Ïˆ ^âˆ— }\mathcal{HOM}(Î› ^2_1, V)$ lifts all monomorphisms.

Functors

Topological Space for Convenience

We explain the convenient topological category, usually selected as $ğ‚ğ†ğ‡$ (compactly generated Hausdorff space, or $k$-spaces). We clearify the morphisms ($k$-morphisms) in $ğ‚ğ†ğ‡$ and the left adjoint functor ($k$-fication) $k : ğ“ğ¨ğ© â†’ ğ‚ğ†ğ‡$ with respect to the inclusion $ğ‚ğ†ğ‡ â†’ ğ“ğ¨ğ©$ (not full!).

Hurewicz Map

Following the principle $\text{realisation} âŠ£ \text{nerve}$, we have constructed the adjunctions



In order to study homologies, we introduce the free-forgetful adjunction of Abelisation $â„¤ (-) : ğ€ğ› ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}} â‡† ğ’ğğ­ğ¬ ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}} : U$. The homologies are calculated by the homology groups of the singular chain complex $C(â„¤ (X))$. The Hurewitz map points out that the functor $â„¤ (-)$ lost some information of $Ï€ _âˆ™$ groups, while exactly makes it into $H_âˆ™$. The map says $Ï€ _âˆ™ (|U(-)|) â‰ƒ H_âˆ™ (-)$ are the same functor of the type $ğ€ğ› ^{Î” ^{\mathrm{op}}} â†’ ğ†ğ« (ğ€ğ›)$, which generalise the result of $\mathrm{Ab}(Ï€ _1) = H_1$.

DK Correspondence

There are also theories revising the assignment $X â†¦ C(â„¤ (X))$, e.g. the Dold-Kan complex correspondence.

(Homotopy) Spectra

The pointed construction makes topological spaces algebraic. The homotopy spectra $Î£ ^âˆ : ğ“ğ¨ğ© _âˆ™ / âˆ¼ â†’ ğ‡ğ¨ğ’ğ©ğğœ$ moreover linearise it ($âˆ§ = âˆ¨$ under $Î£ ^âˆ$!).

  • the development: due to Lima around 1950s probably, and revolutioned by Adams in stable homotopy theory (1974);
  • it has nothing to do with the spectra in algebraic topology, or spectal of operator (the word is over used).

Quillenâ€™s Equivalence

The adjunction $|-| âŠ£ \operatorname{Sing}$ descents to an equivalence for there homotopy category. It is acceptable to enlarge $ğ‚ğ†ğ‡$ to the entire $ğ“ğ¨ğ©$.
